story:
Hi!  My Name is Wesley Thornberry

Over the last 3 years I have had the amazing opportunity to work with a non profit in Mongolia called The Mongol Ecology Center.  MEC has one single goal...to establish a National Park infrastructure for the amazing, unpolluted and pristine wilderness areas of Mongolia to preserve them for future generations.  Specifically I have been involved in working with MEC to establish the infrastructure for Lake Hovsgol National Park.  But this place is on the verge of being destroyed if we don't act now.  It has been kept pristine because it is extremely remote and very difficult to get to.  But a paved road is nearing completion from the capital of Mongolia, Ulaanbataar, and the amount of visitors to the lake will skyrocket.  In addition the lake is threatened from illegal poaching of endangered wildlife, illegal mining and logging.  MEC is working tirelessly with the help of the US National Park Service and the European Union to insure the infrastructure is in place to handle the increase in visitation to the park.  But Mongolia is a developing country and the funding just isn't available to cover everything...mainly the equipment the rangers need to enforce the rules.

One day we were working at the lake when we caught a poacher red handed.  The park ranger we were with took off after the guy on his $700 Chinese motorcycle which proceeded to break down and the poacher sped off into the distance in his Toyota Landcruiser.  We decided at that moment that we would raise the money needed to get these rangers the equipment they need to adequately protect this amazing place.  And thus the Mongolian Motorcycle Rally was born...

Fifteen motorcyclists from around the world are raising money to buy each of the 15 rangers at Lake Hovsgol a quality Yamaha off road motorcycle so they can have the tools to chase these guys down and end the poaching of endangered wildlife, illegal mining and logging that is threatening Lake Hovsgol.  Each participant will also pay out of their own pockets to fly to Mongolia this July and ride the bikes from Ulaanbataar to the lake to deliver the bikes in person to the rangers.  We are doing this Rally to bring worldwide attention to the significance of this lake.  The Rally is being documented by a film company and will be made into a documentary this November and will be covered by Asian media.

The park is patrolled by rangers, mostly on horseback, on foot or decrepit old motorcycles which were never really meant for off-road use.  The rangers need better transportation to do their job catching poachers and illegal developers, and the motorcycles they have are old, tired and inadequate.  The horses are even less effective and it's not easy to cover vast expanses of wilderness on foot or catch up with poachers driving 4-wheel drive jeeps. New off-road motorcycles will greatly help them to do their jobs. And the Mongolian government has agreed to provide all maintenance, parts and fuel for the motorcycles.

I am raising funds to buy one motorcycle and safety gear to outfit a ranger.  On my own dime I am going to go to Mongolia to deliver it to the ranger in person. Entire airfare comes out of my own pocket, and I am volunteering my time both here with fundraising and coordination, and in Mongolia with coordination and delivery.

Lake Hovsgol is one of the last best places!

The Lake and surrounding wildlife area is a National Park bigger than Yellowstone and strictly protected as a transition zone between Central Asian Steppe and the Siberian Taiga.  It's one of 17 ancient lakes that are more than 2 million years old, and the water is so clean you can drink it without any treatment.  There are a number of indigenous people that live around it and depend on it for their water supply.  In fact  it contains 70% of all the surface freshwater supply for the whole country of Mongolia.  There is no body of water this clean and this large in America. None.  Imagine what Lake Tahoe was like 400 years ago...thats what Lake Hovsgol is now and its 4 times as big.

So what's threatening it?

Illegal poaching, including illegal drift net fishing, illegal logging: The lake has fish, including two endemic species, and since it's a lake, those fish can easily become overfished as every other fish population in the world has become.  The surrounding parklands are home to a number of really awesome animals, including ibex, argali, elk, wolf, wolverine, musk deer, brown bear, Siberian moose, and sable.

Mongolia has done a good job designating this area as a wildlife preserve to protect the survival of these animals, but enforcement is challenging.  Rangers have been stabbed and injured trying to enforce the law against poachers, who stand to make a great deal of money in the short term.

Illegal development and tourism: It shouldn't be news to Americans that people in and from outside Mongolia are eager to develop properties around the lake.  Rangers have caught individuals simply building around it without permits. Run off and pollution from illegal development and road building is certain to pollute the lake, as well as impact wildlife habitat.  Additionally outsiders have come in and started developing environmental tourism projects without necessarily caring for the habitat or obtaining permission.

But they have rangers to enforce the laws, right?

Yes, the whole park is about 4,600 square miles (1.2mm hectares) and there are 15 permanent rangers and a few seasonal ones.  Each ranger patrols over 300 square miles of park, which is about the same size as all the boroughs in New York City.  And they do it mostly on horseback.  For reference, Yellowstone is smaller and has 300 permanent Park Rangers.   Imagine if there was only one policeman in a space as big as the five boroughs of New York City, and he was on horseback chasing bad guys in jeeps.

The poachers and illegal users in the park tool around in jeeps, 4x4's, and other vehicles.  Did I also mention the poachers are armed?

The rangers have asked for help in the form of offroad motorcycles, gear, and training.  With modern offroad motorcycles, they could patrol more effectively and discourage lawbreakers.

So why do I care, and how can I help?

It's true, Mongolia is halfway around the world, but I care, and here's why:

  • We don't have that many wild places left in the world.  
  • We don't have that much wildlife left in the world.
  • I love nature, I spend a lot of time in nature, and it's not often that I get to actually do hands-on volunteering to not only help protect one of the last pristine natural places in the world, but at the same time help improve the work life of an individual who is protecting this area. That's just awesome!

Even if you aren't moved by this situation, I ask that you support me in my effort to keep this wild area as pristine as possible. You can help by donating to help cover the cost of a motorcycle and equipment.

Where does the money go?

100% of the money you donate is tax-deductible, and goes to buy and ship the motorcycle and equipment. I am paying my own ticket over, and the Mongol Ecology Center is not taking any of it for administration, it all goes directly to equipment for the rangers! 

I am trying to fund one motorcycle and equipment.  Each motorcycle and equipment, along with shipping, costs $7,550.   I am trying to raise enough to outfit one ranger.  Any additional money goes to buying a second motorcycle if I exceed my fundraising goal.  

If I raise additional funds, but not enough for an entire motorcycle and gear, the Mongol Ecology Center has agreed to pool it with the funds raised by other volunteers to fund another complete motorcycle.
story_txt:
Hi!  My Name is Wesley ThornberryOver the last 3 years I have had the amazing opportunity to work with a non profit in Mongolia called The Mongol Ecology Center.  MEC has one single goal...to establish a National Park infrastructure for the amazing, unpolluted and pristine wilderness areas of Mongolia to preserve them for future generations.  Specifically I have been involved in working with MEC to establish the infrastructure for Lake Hovsgol National Park.  But this place is on the verge of being destroyed if we don't act now.  It has been kept pristine because it is extremely remote and very difficult to get to.  But a paved road is nearing completion from the capital of Mongolia, Ulaanbataar, and the amount of visitors to the lake will skyrocket.  In addition the lake is threatened from illegal poaching of endangered wildlife, illegal mining and logging.  MEC is working tirelessly with the help of the US National Park Service and the European Union to insure the infrastructure is in place to handle the increase in visitation to the park.  But Mongolia is a developing country and the funding just isn't available to cover everything...mainly the equipment the rangers need to enforce the rules.One day we were working at the lake when we caught a poacher red handed.  The park ranger we were with took off after the guy on his $700 Chinese motorcycle which proceeded to break down and the poacher sped off into the distance in his Toyota Landcruiser.  We decided at that moment that we would raise the money needed to get these rangers the equipment they need to adequately protect this amazing place.  And thus the Mongolian Motorcycle Rally was born...Fifteen motorcyclists from around the world are raising money to buy each of the 15 rangers at Lake story:
Blue Water Initiative (BWI) is a South Florida based 501c3 nonprofit organization committed to the conservation of oceans and the rehabilitation of damaged reef ecosystems through community awareness, research, education, and active restoration. 

BWI's current core project is the methodical removal of thousands of old "rogue" automobile tires at Osborne Reef - a failed 1970's artificial habitat comprised of over a million tires located off Ft. Lauderdale. These tires, drifting from the main field in storm surges, can negatively impact sensitive live corals and sponges in the vicinity.

While BWI's has already identified a remarkable number of rogue tires creeping away from the main field, storm surges like 2012's Hurricane Sandy can suddenly relocate tires causing them to further damage nearby coral reefs, smothering delicate marine life and destroying natural habitiat.

With your financial assistance, BWI will conduct a survey dive in November and/or December 2012 to determine the number of newly deposited tires threatening natural reef by Hurricane Sandy's storm surge. If conditions allow, we will remove the most dangerous marine debris with the expert help of specially trained salvage divers.

BWI is hoping to raise our goal by the end of November with a chance to receive a $500 matching gift from Indiegogo in November. As a flexible grassroots organization, we will do good work with whatever funds we receive, and the more money we raise beyond our goal, the more we can do in 2012 and 2013.

Please see our "perks" on the right for premiums in return for your contribution. Any amount you can donate helps our cause. And since BWI is a 501c3 Nonprofit Group, your gift is tax deductible to the full extent of the law.

For more information and additional ways to help support BWI, please email us at: info@bluewaterinitiative.org 

 

Thank You!

story:
*Please note: This campaign is about much more than financial donations. See below for ways to get involved in hands-on learning*

 

My Story

Hey everyone! My name is Danny Clark and I'm really into human health and ecology (ie, nature). I studied biology/archaeology in school, yet I've always been more of a big picture philosophical type than a typical scientist. Integration is more my jam than studying little pieces of things (both are needed, of course!). Thus, this project - which is about studying the connection between us and our environment, via movement, food systems, and sensory development - is really the "lab" I've decided to work in.

A little more about me (feel free to skip ahead):

I grew up in suburban New Jersey (know to some as the "armpit" of America). There was a small patch of marshy woods near the house where I grew up.  My dad took me fishing occasionally, and we vacationed in the Poconos. There's really no logical explanation for why Im so incredibly passionate about all this nature stuff. None of my friends or family are. Yet, for some reason I am.  Big time. Its an inner itch of curiosity that's always been there, and drives me relentlessly down a fairly untrodden path.  Its a trail that ultimately lead me to MovNat (an education system that connects people to natural patterns of movement) and Permaculture (the study of nature's patterns to inform human habitation and technology). See my mentor Ben Falk's site for more info on Permaculture (and Ben will be a big part of the project!).

Recently, I found myself hitting a wall. As I continued my studies and did my best to apply them to my life, I knew I had to take it to the next level. Further, while I knew that my own small actions/choices do have an impact on the world, I tend to think big. These pursuits aren't just about me, after all....if nature teaches us one thing, its that everything is inextricably connected; that we're all in this together.  Thus, the vision of this project was born...

 

 

The Vision

What does nature have to offer humans beyond the feel-good, stress combating "beauty" we all recognize and raw materials for civilization?

And, if one were so inclined, why is it so friggin' hard to actually make living close/deeply connected to nature happen?

These were the base questions that drove me to make a truly scary, yet exciting decision: to buy 30 acres in rural Vermont with little financial resources and virtually zero building experience.  What I did have was a willingness to be very uncomfortable, plus a knowledgeable mentor (Ben Falk of Whole Systems Design, who is playing an active part in this project).

As I considered making the property purchase, I thought back to those two questions.  I visualized that if the answers were thoroughly explored and resources were developed to help others with little to zero experience do the same (to any even small degree), the world would change in some meaningful way.

Then, I pulled the trigger, and set out make that vision become reality.

 

The Impact

There are a few ways to contribute to this project, and all of them are much appreciated:

- Show up, move with us, and get some hands-on learning (more about that below) - included are daily lessons in movement ergonomics and restoration practices.

- Pitch in a few bucks 

- Help expose the ideas - whether it be this particular project, MovNat, or Permaculture

- Start your own practice (which hands-on learning will expedite, guaranteed) 

Here's what you are contributing to:

- The creation of small house (640 sq feet) so I can live on the property year round without freezing my arse off in the harsh Vermont climate

- Infrastructure for guests (water, driveway, waste, tent/movement platforms, shower, and food systems)

- The greater vision, which includes my prototype Permaculture site development and eventual not-for-profit initiatives for helping others do the same (Permaculture isn't just about moving out to the "sticks" - it can be done anywhere)

- The greater greater vision, which is for human thought to mature and understand/integrate the spiritual richness and economic value of fitting better into the world that we inhabit.

My track record is full of accomplishing the things I set out to do - with the collaborative effort and input of many - so there's no question all of the above will happen!

 

The Cabin Build

Here's the specs on the cabin:

- 32' x 20' footprint w/ lofted second floor. Passive solar orientation

- The foundation will be a rubble trench

- The exterior walls will be done using slipform stone masonry, a beginner friendly and cheap (yet little known) construction technique

- The interior walls will be a wood lathe, covered in clay plaster

- The first floor will be Earthen (clay) with hydronic heat inlay

- The second floor and roof structure will be made using traditional timber framing (tenon and mortise joinery)

- The power will be 100% supplied by solar photovoltaic panels (this property is "off grid")

- The water source will be a spring (already dug) to cistern gravity flow system

- The heat source (beyond the passive solar design) will be a custom made wood stove that burns wood and also heats domestic water and under floor radiant system

- The septic will likely be a composting toilet, though a conventional septic will be dug to fulfill requirement by the state of Vermont.

*A separate campaign of the same nature will be initiated next year for the food systems (and ecosystem creation) part of the project.

 

The Location

This research site is located in the beautiful White River Valley (exceptional swimming will be happening on the reg) in the foothills of the Green Mountains.  The site is about 3 miles from Rochester, Vermont up 1.25 miles a town maintained dirt road.  Four wheel drive not required.

 

The Obstacles

1) Human power

The whole land ownership thing has never sat well with me.  Right away, we create our own barriers, and amplify our own hardships. I want people, animals, and life in general moving freely (and relaxing) on my "property." And, that's a big theme of this project - moving beyond our own personal fitness space, our delusions of "self," and actually doing something helpful with our movement.

Long story short: I need some helping hands. Not because Im too cheap to pay some teenagers or big machines to do the work with me. Rather, we need to revive a culture of movement, hands-on learning, and connection. It starts here and will not end here. That's a pledge.

2) Finances

Even if I had the financial power, I wouldn't want to "muscle" this project forward just by throwing money at it.  Yet, money is just a modern reality...I envision it as the gas the fuels the vehicle.  Just one vital component of making forward progress.

So, money is a limiting factor.  Frankly, I have no idea how Im going to afford everything.  I'm shooting at the hip on that front. Not really though - if you are interested in the financial/budgeting aspect of the project, just email me.  Or I can post about it in an "update"

3) Timeline

Vermont has a very short season that is amicable to getting things done.  Hence, obstacles 1 & 2 are much more necessary compared to many other bioregions.

4) Work

I have a full-time job, running and teaching for MovNat. Luckily, I work from home and my travel schedule is light for the late summer/early Fall. My time dedicated toward this project is limited though - which is good news for participants who want to enjoy swimming, exploring, and relaxing in this beautiful place! 

 

Get Involved and Spread the Word

Ok, here's the nuts and bolts of how to get involved:

- Come pitch in during various phases of the project 

- Make a donation on this page

- Share this page

- Email me with questions

If you want to pitch in, here's the current opportunities:

- July 26-27: Stone Gathering / Form Building

- August 3-Sept 26: Slipform Stone Wall construction

- Sept 27-29: Workshop with Matt Eddy on Traditional Timber Framing, plus roof raising (a $100/day fee (or $249 for all 3 days) to cover Matt's expenses and expertise will be required for this workshop...more details soon).

- Sept 30 - Nov 1: Earthen floor, clay walls, misc finishing details

--

I recommend you stay for at least 2-3 nights to settle in and really enjoy the experience. Kids are welcome. More opportunities will likely be available for later phases of the project. See FAQ for more or email me.

 

How to get involved: email me at drc5n@virginia.edu to reserve your timeframe.

 

Thank you, thank you, thank you for reading and supporting!!

- Sept 27-29: Workshop with Matt Eddy on Traditional Timber Framing, plus roof raising (a $100/day fee (or $249 for all 3 days) to cover Matt's expenses and expertise will be required for this workshop...more details soon).
- Sept 30 - Nov 1: Earthen floor, clay walls, misc finishing details
--
I recommend you stay for at least 2-3 nights to settle in and really enjoy the experience. Kids are welcome. More opportunities will likely be available for later phases of the project. See FAQ for more or email me.
 
How to get involved: email me at drc5n@virginia.edu to reserve your timeframe.
 
Thank you, thank you, thank you for reading and supporting!!

story:
Short Summary

Clean cities. Healthy lifestyles. Doing our part to slow climate change. For these reasons and with your help, The University YMCA and our LINC friends (ENG 315) will launch a bike share program.

Funding

Funding will go towards purchasing quality bikes, safety equiptment (including helmets, locks, relectors, etc., and maintenance tools for the Y. The Community Foundation of East Central Illinois has made an incredible commitment to fund nearly $2,000 in equipment, it's up to YOU to help raise the remainder and make this a reality!

The Impact

Ever need to get somewhere fast? Most peole would hop in their car, or borrow a friend's car. With Y bikes, you could hop on a bike and save the Carbon emissions. This ultimately makes our streets safer, people healthier, and atmosphere cleaner. This is a pilot program that we hope to expand to a much larger, multi-location bike share in collaboration with other organizations and units in our community.

The Y: A Place for Change

In the late 1960’s, the University YMCA joined a growing number of pioneers in environmental sustainability. In over forty years, the Y has become a hub for environmental initiatives on campus and in our communities. Five student programs (Students for Environmental Concerns, Red Bison, Campus Vegetarian Society, Engineers Without Borders, and the Green Observer) collectively have had a tremendous impact. Their mission is “protecting the integrity of our natural world.”

story:
Short Summary

Immersion Travel Magazine is a monthly digital publication that showcases culturally sensitive and environmentally conscious travel destinations across the nation and the world. Escape to vivid landscapes. Explore welcoming and spirited communities. Taste exotic cuisine from colorful markets. Sample captivating music and art. Discover wildlife in thriving habitats. Learn what people around the world are doing to improve the travel experience for visitors, locals, and the environment. Immersion Travel delivers genuine and reliable content for travelers who are curious about their world; aren’t afraid to get their hands dirty; enjoy putting their feet up once in a while; and are craving a new and honest look at travel. Experience the thrill of Immersion Travel, where every article, photograph, and video will keep you coming back for more.

What We Need & What You Get

Immersion Travel is still in the infant stages of its development. While we are very excited to share relevant and exciting information about the most sustainable and thoughtful places on Earth, we need a little help getting there.

We have the business plan, the writer's guidelines, the media kit, and the gumption to get things going, but what we really need is your support and a trip to the annual Ecotourism and Sustainablity Conference in Nairobi, Kenya, taking place the last week of September 2013.

Attending this conference is a major step toward getting noticed by compassionate companies like Patagonia, Cliff Bar, and Kleen Kanteen, as well as 500 other travel companies from across the world. This is a chance to make connections with individuals who are passionate about conserving the planet, preserving cultures, building local economies, and having a great time while traveling. With these connections and help from you, we can publish the first few issues of Immersion Travel and inspire readers to think about a whole different kind of travel.

This campaign is only for our trip to Kenya and won't be used to fund our first issues. Our goal is to make lasting connections with others in the community and then see which strategic steps we need to take from there to raise funds.  

For more information, please visit our website: www.immersiontravelmag.com or check us out on Twitter: @ImmersionTravel

The Impact

Immersion Travel isn't the kind of magazine that features giant resorts on white sandy beaches. You won't catch us sitting on a beach drinking umbrella-topped cocktails. We are passionate about walking the streets outside of the resorts, eating local cuisine, witnessing the beauty of untouched landscapes, and learning as much as possible from local environments and communities we travel to. We are travelers, not tourists. We believe that every destination has an impact on the people that travel to it and it is our mission to share that impact with readers across the world.

Challenges

Starting any type of business is risky. It is true that magazines are harder to launch than other businesses; however, I have spent the last two years diligently planning and working out every detail alongside experts in the magazine industry. I earned my master's degree in magazine writing and journalism at the University of Oregon's School of Journalism and Communication, where I also earned a certification in journalism ethics (during this time, I also accomplished a certification in ecotourism planning and management from Humboldt State University). I took every class on the industry that was offered and worked with as many people as possible, including multimedia guru, Christopher Scotti, who put hundreds of hours into designing Immersion's website and layout for multiple digital platforms.

I was met with skepticism until my plan was so squeaky clean that even the hardest of critics were confident that my plan would work and Immersion Travel would become a success.

My competition is fierce. Travel magazines are not exactly rare entities. However, Immersion Travel is different in several ways: it only features destinations that have proven to be environmentally sustainable, socially just, economically sound, and unforgettable; it stands on a strong ethical foundation of honesty, transparency, responsibility, and diligence; it does not operate on bribes or compensations from businesses--all investigations and reviews are conducted anonymously and are fully funded by Immersion Travel; it is digital, saving over 800,000 trees a year and millions of dollars; it is innovative and technologically savvy bringing you the best images, videos, and articles possible; and it is affordable: $12 per year will bring you twelve issues as well as four specialty issues and a back-stage pass on our website, where you will find more information about responsible travel.

If you have any questions or would like to see our complete business plan, please visit our website: www.immersiontravelmag.com

story:
I am a native of California. I’m a singer-songwriter and music producer. I play guitar lead and rhythm, bass guitar, drums and percussion. Also, I’m sole proprietor of a small mechanical construction business called: Inness Mechanical Design and Maintenance. For soul satisfaction, I have been an avid motorcycle rider and racer for most of my life, learning to ride a motorcycle at the age of 14. The racing started in 2004 using my motocross, off-road and desert riding experience to learn a new motorcycle discipline called super Moto, which is motocross on 70% asphalt and 30% dirt with motocross like terrain. Also in this later part of my life, I would like to apply all my experiences to help with the preservation of our natural resources of the planet, people must realize this is ever so important these days and the consciousness must be recognized with discipline. I have a big heavy heart as far as trying to do this momentous task of helping preserve this great lake of Mongolia called “Lake Hovsgol”.

The park is patrolled by rangers, mostly on horseback, on foot or decrepit old motorcycles which were never really meant for off-road use.  The rangers need better transportation to do their job catching poachers and illegal developers, and the motorcycles they have are old, tired and inadequate.  The horses are even less effective and it's not easy to cover vast expanses of wilderness on foot or catch up with poachers driving 4-wheel drive jeeps. New off-road motorcycles will greatly help them to do their jobs. And the Mongolian government has agreed to provide all maintenance, parts and fuel for the motorcycles.

I am raising funds to buy one motorcycle and safety gear to outfit a ranger.  On my own dime I am going to go to Mongolia to deliver it to the ranger in person. Entire airfare comes out of my own pocket, and I am volunteering my time both here with fundraising and coordination, and in Mongolia with coordination and delivery.

Lake Hovsgol is one of the last best places!

The Lake and surrounding wildlife area is a National Park bigger than Yellowstone and strictly protected as a transition zone between Central Asian Steppe and the Siberian Taiga.  It's one of 17 ancient lakes that are more than 2 million years old, and the water is so clean you can drink it without any treatment.  There are a number of indigenous people that live around it and depend on it for their water supply.  In fact  it contains 70% of all the surface freshwater supply for the whole country of Mongolia.  There is no body of water this clean and this large in America. None.  Imagine what Lake Tahoe was like 400 years ago...thats what Lake Hovsgol is now and its 4 times as big.

So what's threatening it?

Illegal poaching, including illegal drift net fishing, illegal logging: The lake has fish, including two endemic species, and since it's a lake, those fish can easily become overfished as every other fish population in the world has become.  The surrounding parklands are home to a number of really awesome animals, including ibex, argali, elk, wolf, wolverine, musk deer, brown bear, Siberian moose, and sable.

Mongolia has done a good job designating this area as a wildlife preserve to protect the survival of these animals, but enforcement is challenging.  Rangers have been stabbed and injured trying to enforce the law against poachers, who stand to make a great deal of money in the short term.

Illegal development and tourism: It shouldn't be news to Americans that people in and from outside Mongolia are eager to develop properties around the lake.  Rangers have caught individuals simply building around it without permits. Run off and pollution from illegal development and road building is certain to pollute the lake, as well as impact wildlife habitat.  Additionally outsiders have come in and started developing environmental tourism projects without necessarily caring for the habitat or obtaining permission.

But they have rangers to enforce the laws, right?

Yes, the whole park is about 4,600 square miles (1.2mm hectares) and there are 15 permanent rangers and a few seasonal ones.  Each ranger patrols over 300 square miles of park, which is about the same size as all the boroughs in New York City.  And they do it mostly on horseback.  For reference, Yellowstone is smaller and has 300 permanent Park Rangers.  Imagine if there was only one policeman in a space as big as the five boroughs of New York City, and he was on horseback chasing bad guys in jeeps.

The poachers and illegal users in the park tool around in jeeps, 4x4's, and other vehicles.  Did I also mention the poachers are armed?

The rangers have asked for help in the form of offroad motorcycles, gear, and training.  With modern offroad motorcycles, they could patrol more effectively and discourage lawbreakers.

So why do I care, and how can I help?

It's true, Mongolia is halfway around the world, but I care, and here's why:

  • We don't have that many wild places left in the world.  
  • We don't have that much wildlife left in the world.
  • I love nature, I spend a lot of time in nature, and it's not often that I get to actually do hands-on volunteering to not only help protect one of the last pristine natural places in the world, but at the same time help improve the work life of an individual who is protecting this area. That's just awesome!

Even if you aren't moved by this situation, I ask that you support me in my effort to keep this wild area as pristine as possible. You can help by donating to help cover the cost of a motorcycle and equipment.

Where does the money go?

100% of the money you donate is tax-deductible, and goes to buy and ship the motorcycle and equipment. I am paying my own ticket over, and the Mongol Ecology Center is not taking any of it for administration, it all goes directly to equipment for the rangers! 

I am trying to fund one motorcycle and equipment.  Each motorcycle and equipment, along with shipping, costs $7,400.   I am trying to raise enough to outfit one ranger.  Any additional money goes to buying a second motorcycle if I exceed my fundraising goal.  

If I raise additional funds, but not enough for an entire motorcycle and gear, the Mongol Ecology Center has agreed to pool it with the funds raised by other volunteers to fund another complete motorcycle.

story:
Last May I received a letter from county weed control stating that a neighbor had complained about my tall lawn. Ordinances explain that lawns must be kept at 6" or shorter, and some patches of my lawn were at or just above that length (taller lawns have deeper roots and conserve more soil moisture). I vowed that if I ever received such a letter I would finally tear out most of my front lawn -- a small, wasted space that's never used and fries in the summer -- replacing it with a sustainable, low maintenance landscape full of Nebraska native prairie plants that will inspire and educate folks in our city and beyond. I'm full of hope and fear: what will the neighbors think? Can I be one of the few local examples of a professionally designed, aesthetically pleasing, wildlife supporting front yard in a time of shrinking bee and butterfly numbers? Will I get another letter in the mail? Will you come visit us when we're done?

I'm Benjamin Vogt, part time English teacher by day, and by night owner of Monarch Gardens, a prairie garden consulting and design business. Over the years I've visited dozens of homes, acreages, and school landscapes. While working with clients it's become clear that there are few to no home gardens that feature native plants, and even fewer that feature them in an artfully designed way; this fact means that a homeowner wishing to create a more sustainable garden has little to draw inspiration from. Well, I'm willing to be the guinea pig. Remaking my front yard will help me teach clients, my neighborhood, and the city of Lincoln, all while combating the myth that native plants are weedy. I'll host tours and workshops and use this transformation in talks and articles. My 1,500' backyard garden (75% natives) was named a 2012 top outdoor space by Apartment Therapy, has appeared on two public tours, and has been featured online at Fine Gardening and Garden Design. I also contributed plant picks to the how-to book Lawn Gone!, write a weekly design and wildlife garden column at Houzz (my pieces have received over 1 million views), and run the pollinator-supporting Facebook page MILK the WEED. 

(above -- my back garden)

By creating a garden of relative size to many front yard landscapes (500-1,000 square feet), and using drought tolerant native plants in a site-specific design, I will create a stunning display showing off landscaping practices that should be the norm in the 21st century. In addition, the plants will be placed artfully in drifts and masses, one element of combating the "weedy / messy" stereotype that native plants have. A 6' wide strip of lawn will remain as a pathway leading up to the house and around to the back, which will soften the transformation while also showing design intent. The diverse structure of the landscape will be appealing to all sorts of wildlife by using grasses, wildflowers, shrubs, and trees in scale with the small lot size -- the core mantra of Rick Darke and Doug Tallamy's latest book, The Living Landscape.

You'll not only be helping me create a workable and sustainable example of native plant design, but you'll be helping insect pollinators and other wildlife. Kids today see 35% fewer moths and butterflies than their parents did 40 years ago, and nearly 30% fewer birds, fish, and mammals. In a time of shrinking habitats and climate change every home landscape plays a crucial role in stemming the tide of species loss, rainwater runoff, and intense management of lawns with poisonous machines, dangerous fertilizer / pesticides, and wasteful irrigation. Help me hone my garden design skills and create a low maintenance space for homeowners to draw inspiration from -- not to mention a wildlife nirvana for native bees, butterflies, and prairie plants that restore soil fertility.

I'll be using this project as an educational resource in my teaching, blogging, social media, writing, speaking -- and hosting tours. So you bet the game doesn't stop at just funding this project!

Most of the plants will be sourced from a local nonprofit nursery that uses many local genotype seeds.

* Any amount over $1,500 will go straight into the start-a-nursery-find-some-prairie fund. My wife and I are looking for 40-80 acres of prairie and plan to start an all native plant nursery, create a 1 acre display and trial garden, have an artist residency program, host weddings, and hold prairie gardening education classes and events (within a year or two). You'll be sponsoring small business dreams and helping me practice my art all at once!

PROJECT PLAN & GOALS

  • After a successful campaign (right?) have lawn removed in one week and prepped for planting.
  • Purchase and order plants. None of the plants will exceed 3-4' in height, and taller plants will be in the middle of the beds. I will use at least 75% straight species natives or wild-found cultivars.
  • Remove two struggling red twig dogwood shrubs around the Virginia chokecherry tree (the larger dogwoods along the sidewalk -- a cultivar named 'Arctic Fire' purported to be 3-4' tall at maturity -- will be maintained at half their current height of 6-7').
  • Have plants in the ground by October 15.

PROJECTED COSTS

  • $850 -- Plant material, plugs (includes tax, shipping) -- I will source as many plugs as I can from local nurseries
  • $200 Lawn removal and prep
  • $200 -- Mulch for 1st year establishment (in subsequent years mulch won't be needed as plants fill in, aka green mulch)
  • $50 -- Information sign about project for neighborhood acceptance
  • Indiegogo fees – 4% of total project funding
  • Paypal fee -- 3-5% of total project funding
  • Reward costs and shipping -- unknown

REWARDS

$10 -- Our deepest thanks for encouraging this work.

$25 -- All of the above + a 4x6" signed print of a monarch on Liatris ligulistylis


$50 -- All of the above + a signed copy of my memoir Sleep, Creep, Leap: The First Three Years of a Nebraska Garden

$100 -- All of the above + a mixed packet of organically grown, open pollinated prairie wildflower seed from my garden (winter sowing is perfect!).

$250 -- All of the above + a signed copy of my poetry collection Afterimage and an 8x10" signed print of a monarch on Liatris ligulistylis.

POTENTIAL ISSUES

Planting may have to happen in stages over the fall, as plants are sourced (ideally we'd do it all at once in one day). Establishment of plants will take 1-3 years, but in essence the landscape will be completed by mid October and watered in well. If plants die over the winter they will be replaced at our expense. Hopefully, the neighbors will also respond well to the design -- it's very possible that the non-lawn landscape will be reported to county or city authorities, but I am confident that through education, as well as having a clear design element, it will carry the day for years to come.

the plants will be placed artfully in drifts and masses, one element of
combating the "weedy / messy" stereotype that native plants have. A
6' wide strip of lawn will remain as a pathway leading up to the house and
around to the back, which will soften the transformation while also showing
design intent. The diverse structure of the landscape will be appealing to all
sorts of wildlife by using grasses, wildflowers, shrubs, and trees in scale
with the small lot size -- the core mantra of Rick Darke and Doug Tallamy's
latest book, The Living Landscape.


You'll not only be helping me create a workable and sustainable example of
native plant design, but you'll be helping insect pollinators and other
wildlife. Kids today see 35% fewer moths and butterflies than their parents did
40 years ago, and nearly 30% fewer birds, fish, and mammals. In a time of
shrinking habitats and climate change every home landscape plays a crucial role
in stemming the tide of species loss, rainwater runoff, and intense management
of lawns with poisonous machines, dangerous fertilizer / pesticides, and
wasteful irrigation. Help me hone my garden design skills and create a low
maintenance space for homeowners to draw inspiration from -- not to mention a
wildlife nirvana for native bees, butterflies, and prairie plants that restore
soil fertility. I'll be using this project as an educational resource in my teaching, blogging, social media, writing, speaking -- and hosting tours. So you bet the game doesn't stop at just funding this project! Most of the plants will be sourced from a local nonprofit nursery that uses many local genotype seeds.* Any amount over $1,500 will go straight into the
start-a-nursery-find-some-prairie fund. My wife and I are looking for 40-80
acres of prairie and plan to start an all native plant nursery, create a 1 acre
display and trial garden, have an artist residency program, host weddings, and
hold prairie gardening education classes and events (within a year or two).
You'll be sponsoring small business dreams and helping me practice my art all
at once!
PROJECT PLAN & GOALS

After
     a successful campaign (right?) have lawn removed in one week and
     prepped for planting. 
Purchase
     and order plants. None of the plants will exceed 3-4' in height, and
     taller plants will be in the middle of the beds. I will use at least 75%
     straight species natives or wild-found cultivars. 
Remove
     two struggling red twig dogwood shrubs around the Virginia chokecherry
     tree (the larger dogwoods along the sidewalk -- a cultivar named 'Arctic
     Fire' purported to be 3-4' tall at maturity -- will be maintained at half
     their current height of 6-7').
Have
     plants in the ground by October 15. 

PROJECTED COSTS

$850
     -- Plant material, plugs (includes tax, shipping) -- I will source as many
     plugs as I can from local nurseries
$200
     Lawn removal and prep
$200
     -- Mulch for 1st year establishment (in subsequent years mulch won't be
     needed as plants fill in, aka green mulch) 
$50
     -- Information sign about project for neighborhood acceptance
Indiegogo fees – 4% of total project funding 
Paypal fee -- 3-5% of total project funding

Reward
     costs and shipping -- unknown

REWARDS
$10 -- Our deepest thanks for encouraging this work.
$25 -- All of the above + a 4x6" signed print of a monarch on Liatris
ligulistylis


$50 -- All of the above + a signed copy of my memoir Sleep, Creep, Leap: The First Three Years of a Nebraska Garden

$100 -- All of the above + a mixed packet of organically grown, open
pollinated prairie wildflower seed from my garden (winter sowing is perfect!).$250 -- All of the above + a signed copy of my poetry collection Afterimage
and an 8x10" signed print of a monarch on Liatris ligulistylis.

POTENTIAL ISSUESPlanting may have to happen in stages over the fall, as
plants are sourced (ideally we'd do it all at once in one day). Establishment
of plants will take 1-3 years, but in essence the landscape will be completed
by mid October and watered in well. If plants die over the winter they will be
replaced at our expense. Hopefully, the neighbors will also respond well to the
design -- it's very possible that the non-lawn landscape will be reported to
county or city authorities, but I am confident that through education, as well
as having a clear design element, it will carry the day for years to come.

story:
I hope you can join Earth Celebrations, reaching out from New York with our creative strategies that we implemented to preserve the community gardens and highlight the restoration of the Hudson River, now for the first time across the globe to India, to restore the magnificent Vaigai River, in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South India!


Felicia Young, Founder / Executive Director of Earth Celebrations

Earth Celebrations, a non-profit organization founded in 1991 in New York City,  is dedicated to engaging communities to effect change on ecological issues through educational art projects and creative social action.


Vaigai River Restoration 

Pageant Project

Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South India

A project to restore the Vaigai River in Madurai, India that is in a severe crisis due to pollution, waste dumping, and the drying effects of climate change 

Founders: Earth Celebrations and DHAN Foundation 
Co-Sponsors: Earth Celebrations, DHAN Foundation, Asia Initiatives
January - April, 2015

Help Earth Celebrations launch our new project to restore the Vaigai River in India.

DONATE NOW

Top: Image Source: Paulthy of Flickr, Bottom: Big Blue Orb

What is the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project?

The Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project is an educational, ecological art project that engages the local community, raises public environmental awareness, and mobilizes direct action and support to restore the water quality, species, habitats and health of India’s famous Vaigai River in the ancient temple city of Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South India. 

The project raises awareness to mitigate the severe crisis of pollution and contamination of a major natural water resource by waste dumping, toxic chemical pollution, poor water flow, and promotes sustainable solutions for agricultural irrigation, safe drinking water, and restoration plans of this vital natural resource that the community depends on for their survival.

Earth Celebrations’ Hudson River Pageant to restore native species, habitats, and address climate change, New York City. Photo by William Bourassa Jr.

CREATIVE STRATEGIES: Community Building, Public Awareness, Education, Social Action, and Implementation of Solutions

Through the innovative and creative strategy and model of the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project, we will engage community participants in a grassroots educational and social action campaign. We will utilize community-based art and the theatrical pageant (a procession with site specific performances), an indigenous art-form to mobilize the community to identify the issues, raise public awareness, participate in direct action and implement solutions to mitigate the severe environmental crisis of pollution and contamination of a major natural water resource and to counter the effects of climate change.

An educational workshop series builds community engagement and awareness of the Vaigai River for 3 months from January to April, 2015 leading up to the culminating Vaigai River Restoration Pageant. Through the workshops, environmental educators inspire community participants to learn about the river issues and solutions. This work provides the inspiration and a “place-based” learning process that is foundation for the creative ideas for the pageant. Community participants work with local artisans/artists-in-residence to create giant mobile sculptures, puppets, costumes, visual artwork, and performances to highlight the Vaigai River, its history, habitat, water quality, related issues of sanitation and climate change, and future restoration. The workshops are offered free of cost to the community and culminate in the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant in April 2015.

The culminating Vaigai River Restoration Pageant includes a procession of giant mobile sculptures, spectacular costumes, and musical bands with site-specific performances of theater, music, storytelling, poetry, and dance by local folk performing groups, organizations, schools, and community participants that highlight the issues and solutions of the Vaigai River. 

Location / Procession Route: The performances are presented at significant sites along the banks of the Vaigai River from Villangudi to Albert Victor Bridge and the Maiya Mandapam, in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South India.

 

Image Source: Nabuur.com

MADURAI 

Madurai, situated on the banks of the Vaigai River, in Tamil Nadu, Southern India, is known as the Temple City of India. Marco Polo called Madurai the most splendid province on Earth. The magnificence of Madurai as a cultural center since the Tamil Era 2,500 years ago, as well as the beauty of the Vaigai River that runs through it, has been celebrated for thousands of years in Indian literature and sacred texts. Here the ancient past exists alongside the modern world, with its people still practicing sacred and ancient traditions rooted in its legendary history. Meenakshi Temple is known for its magnificent Dravidian architecture with gopurams (gateways) completely covered with intricate colorful sculptural images of gods, animals, and mythical creatures. Madurai’s significance as a center for textiles dates back to its ancient past. Madurai is also the place where in 1921 Mahatma Gandhi relinquished his western clothing to wear a loincloth made of khadi (homespun cloth) as an act to align himself with the people, and as an act of social change.

GOALS: Community Building, Social Action, & Solutions

The project plans for the Vaigai River Restoration include the following:

• Raising awareness for better waste management practices among communities.

• Raising awareness for restoration of water quality, efforts to provide safe drinking water, and  DHAN Foundation’s existing projects such as Vayalagam Tankfed Agriculture Development Program (VTADP).

• Building partnerships of stakeholders and engaging city officials, corporations, environmental organizations, activists, farming groups, schools and universities to be mobilized and participate in solutions to restore the river

• Engaging community participation in creative ecological art project and pageant performance to bring attention to the river, its history, and efforts to restore the health of the river for drinking water, agriculture, recreation, and peaceful open space within the city 

• Highlight and initiate proposals for visions for the future of the river such as a river park along the banks of the Vaigai and other recreational uses that promote the care and appreciation of the river, its historical legacy, and future as an ecological oasis within the city

Top: R. Ashok; “And Quietly Flows a Much Sullied Vaigai,” The Hindu, Bottom: R. Ashok; Photo Feature in The Hindu turns PIL Petition, The Hindu 

STATEMENTS OF NEED 

“Once the preliminary work of clearing garbage is completed, measures will be taken to stop public from letting sewage water into the river. We have invited suggestions from people and activists to keep the river clean.”   - Mayor V.V. Rajan Chellappa of Madurai

“The major area of pollution falls within the city limit… solid waste, plastic waste, untreated sewage water from institutions and houses act as the major pollutants. Only by increasing the water flow of the river, it can be brought to life again. Mixing of sewage water and dumping of solid waste should also be stopped to set it right.”   - Professor G Balaji, Department of Architecture, Thiagarajar College of Engineering

“A proper vision from all stakeholders will help preserve our rivers.”   - K Kalidas, President of Osai, an environmental NGO

“Untreated effluents have raised the pollution level of water. The concentration of total dissolved solids (TSD) in water here is 3,500 to 4,000 ppm, when the acceptable level should be below 500 ppm. Resultantly, the areas adjoining Chinnalapatti are fast becoming barren due to underground pollution. Agriculture is also affected.” - S Mahendran, Manager of the Agriculture Technology Management Association

Mayor V.V. Rajan Chellappa inspects a mass cleaning program, Vaigai Bed Loses Litter, The Hindu

PROJECT TIMELINE

• The public launch of the project is scheduled for Mahatma Gandhi's birthday, October 2, 2014 by Dhan Foundation.

• Educational Community Building / Public Awareness Workshops:

January 2015 - April 2015

• Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Event: April 2015

STRATEGY: Raise Awareness, Mobilize Action & Implement Solutions

One of the first steps to restoring the Vaigai River is building a collaborative partnership of stakeholders, including environmental organizations, schools, universities, farming groups, activists, government representatives, cultural institutions, artisans, performers, and the people of Madurai, who will be mobilized and work together to positively impact the future of the Vaigai River. Through the innovative and creative strategy, we will engage community participants in a grassroots educational and social action campaign. The community will help identify the issues, raise public awareness, and participate in direct action and implementation of solutions. 

Actions Already Underway since April 2014:

• Stakeholders Meetings in Madurai being organized by the DHAN Foundation

• Building partnerships and collaborations for the workshops and pageant with numerous schools and organizations including TheThiagarajar College of Engineering and The World Storytelling Institute in Chennai. The group of partner organizations and community participants is growing every day, along with our global support network from New York, California, Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai, Madurai, and beyond.

• Enlisting artisans of folk art and performing traditions from clay sculpture, paper mache, handloom weavers, Sungadi sari makers, artisans utilizing traditional organic vegetable dye techniques, painters, kavadi headdress builders, as well as performers of music, dance, theater, poetry, storytelling, and ceremony.

• Gathering key environmental educators to work alongside the artisans for the educational workshops.

Earth Celebrations Workshops in 2012 engaging children in NYC to create Stewards of the River Robes using homemade paint made from fruits, vegetables, and plants.

Educational Community-Building Workshops: January — April 2015:

Free workshops will be conducted by the artists-in-residence/workshop instructors in collaboration with environmental educators to engage community members and students, educating the participants on the issues of the Vaigai River and solutions to be implemented. Asia Initiatives will bring in their unique system of Social Capital Credits (SoCCs) as a way to incentivize the community to attend the workshops and contribute towards the river restoration. The work created in the workshops will raise awareness for specific issues and will be presented in the Pageant.

The workshop series engages youth and adults for 3 months to:

•  Explore the diversity of plant and animal life as indicators of the river’s health, as well as discuss current issues concerning pollution and waste through a ‘place-based’ learning process.

•  Work with artists-in-residence to create spectacular visual arts works such as mobile sculptures/puppets and costumes for the procession inspired by the species, habitats, issues, and restoration efforts of the river.

•  Utilize ecologically friendly practices in the creation of art projects, incorporating the use of recycled, natural and organic materials.

•  Engage local artisans to participate in the project creating visual art projects highlighting their folk art traditions such as: clay sculptures, costumes, handloom textiles, bamboo/paper-maché sculpture, decorative processional staffs, headdresses, masks, face painting, palanquins/processional sculpture carts, kolam rice/chalk powder drawings, Sungudi saree and dyeing techniques, that revive traditional vegetables dyes rather than chemical dyes that pollute the river.

•  Social Capital Credits (SoCCs), a virtual currency for social good, will be used to implement the above processes not only during the workshops, but as a long term practice for sustainable ecological and social development. People will be able to earn SoCCs by helping with the pageant, and river cleaning actions such as waste management, maintaining irrigation channels and water tanks, planting trees etc. They will be able to use the SoCCs thus earned to get services like subsidized electricity, telephone talk time, school scholarships, healthcare, etc.

(CLICK HERE TO LEARN HOW SoCCs WILL HELP IN VAIGAI RIVER RESTORATION)

•  Develop solutions for river restoration.

Image Sources Starting from Top: K. Ananthan, The Hindu;
Earth Celebrations Hudson River Pageant Puppet Workshop, New York City; S. James, The Hindu

VAIGAI RIVER RESTORATION PAGEANT:
Procession with Site-Specific Performances: April 2015 

The educational community-building workshop series is planned to culminate in the Vaigai River Pageant. The pageant will feature a procession of giant mobile sculptures, spectacular costumes, and musical bands highlighting the Vaigai River.  Performances by local artists and community groups will be presented at significant sites along the route, following the river bank in Madurai.  Performances will include theater, dance, songs, music, poetry, and ceremony highlighting the history, current issues, and future restoration of the river. 

Mulaipari festival at Koovathupatti, Tamil Nadu,  HenkOochappan, TrekEarth 

Visual Art and Performances for the Pageant:  

• Giant mobile sculptures on traditional processional carts and puppets utilize local folk traditions to represent native species, habitat, history, issues, and efforts to restore the river. 

• Costumes will utilize folk traditions and incorporate handloom textiles and Sungudi fabrics, a traditional craft of Madurai. Craftsmen will be incentivized to use traditional vegetable dyes rather than chemical pigments that pollute the river.

• Educational performances by local performing and community groups address: legacy of Vaigai River in mythological and historic texts; native river species and habitats; issues of waste and sewage dumping; industrial and chemical pollution; and restoration efforts to improve water quality, water flow, and health of the river.   

• Organic Planting Performance celebrating the river as a life source for agriculture and sustainable organic farming and importance of water storage tank restoration for irrigation.

• River Cleansing Ceremony will engage community participants in a choreographed movement and clean-up along the river bank. 

• Live Fish Release: ceremonial action - children offer fish back to the river.

Pageant Date: April 2015: Prior to Chithirai Festival in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South India

Top: Mulaipari festival at Koovathupatti, Tamil Nadu; Terres de Charme,
Middle: Young students performing traditional dances, Lokvani, 
Bottom: Men in procession carrying large decorative ambala kalvadis, The Hindu

WHO WE ARE

FOUNDING CO-SPONSORS –The Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project is produced by Earth Celebrations, a non-profit environmental and arts organization based in New York City, in partnership with the DAHN Foundation, an NGO and non-profit organization working to restore the Vaigai River in Madurai, South India.

Earth Celebrations– Earth Celebrations is a New York City based non-profit organization founded by Felicia Young which works to engage communities to address and effect change on ecological issues through the arts. Earth Celebrations’ creative environmental and arts programs address and effect change on issues such as:  climate change, river species and habitat restoration, and the preservation of community gardens, parks, and a healthy urban environment, while highlighting ecological sustainability. Earth Celebrations’ innovative theatrical pageants and community-based arts programs address crucial ecological issues, including our 15 year effort that led to the preservation of community gardens on the Lower East Side and throughout New York City and the Hudson River Pageant to raise awareness for the restoration of the Hudson River and addressing climate change. 

Earth Celebrations Past Sponsors include: World Financial Center, Brookfield Properties, Bank of America, Con Edison, Citibank, Chase Bank, Colgate-Palmolive, Eileen Fisher, New York State Council on the Arts, Lower Manhattan Cultural Council and The Hudson River Park Trust.

earthcelebrations.com

DHAN Foundation– Development of Humane Action (DHAN) Foundation, an NGO and nonprofit organization based in Madurai, South India, has a mission to “build people and institutions for development innovations and upscale (them) to enable poverty reduction and self-reliance in poor communities.” The program has identified ‘water’ as a unique tool for alleviating poverty and has evolved into a separate people’s institution, the ‘DHAN Vayalagam (Tank) Foundation (DVTF)’. The Foundation aims to restore water quality and access water through tank-based watershed development supporting agriculture needs. DHAN is also engaged in programs to clean and restore the Vaigai River from waste dumping and contaminants, and to raise community awareness and participation in these efforts. DHAN (Development of Human Action) Foundation, was awarded the India NGO award in 2009 by The Rockefeller Foundation.

DHAN Foundation Sponsors include: Ford Foundation, Sir Rata Tata Trust, Axis Bank Foundation, International Water Management Institute-RUAF Foundation and the Department of Tourism, Tamil Nadu. dhan.org

Asia Initiatives– Asia Initiatives (AI), a New York registered non-profit organization undertakes projects that are pro-environment and pro-poor. AI has pioneered the use of Social Capital Credits (SoCCs) to incentivize local people to undertake social good activities, and will develop the SoCCs system to incentivize attendance in the workshops, and the restoration the Vaigai River, working closely with the local community and other stakeholders. This initiative is leadby Dr. Geeta Mehta, Professor of Architecture and Urban Design at Columbia University and the Founder/President of Asia Initiatives.

Asia Initiatives Corporate Partners include: Aveda, Japan Citigroup Services (Japan) Ltd., Credit Suisse, First Boston Securities, Daimler Chrysler, and Ford Motor Company to name a few. asiainitiatives.org

PROJECT LEADERSHIP

Felicia Young, Co-Founder/Co-Director is a theatrical pageant director and founder of Earth Celebrations a non-profit organization dedicated to engaging communities to address and effect change on ecological issues through the arts. She has produced large-scale theatrical pageants for the past 25 years such as the Rites of Spring: Procession to Save Our Gardens (1991-2005) on the Lower East Side of New York City, which mobilized a grass-root effort and directly led to the preservation of many community gardens on the Lower East Side and throughout New York City. In 2009 Felicia launched the Hudson River Pageant to restore the species and habitats of the Hudson River and address climate change in New York City. She has produced and directed theatrical pageants and community-based arts projects for numerous organizations including: the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, the Alternative Museum, Lincoln Center for The Performing Arts, Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, Brookfield Properties> arts World Financial Center, The World Trade Center, and Earth Day New York. She has a BA in Art History from Skidmore College, 1987, and a MA degree in Performance Studies from New York University, 1994. earthcelebrations.com

Rajasekaran Jesudasan, Co-Founder/Co-Director is a Trustee of Arunachalam Jesudasan Trust and Field Director CM Centre Madurai Services for International Scholars, Educators, Researchers & Students in South India, where he is currently on a sabbatical for a year until May 2015. He served for more than 25 years as Resident Coordinator for the University of Wisconsin’s College Year in India Programme, Madurai, and during that time also assisted a great many visiting scholars from USA and European Universities. As Field Director at CM Centre, Sekar organizes every resource necessary to provide for the needs of scholars and students, ranging from setting up meetings with government agencies, NGOs, individuals, private institutions or business houses to interviewing a village shaman. For the past 20 years Sekar has been researching and documenting the Vaigai River and is Co-Author of Stretch of Life on the Vaigai River with Peter Nabakov. Rajasekaran as Co-Director of the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project will coordinate with DHAN Foundation and Earth Celebrations, engage collaborating community partners, artists, and performers, and manage production logistics. Sekar is also a social activist and a musician who performs throughout Tamil Nadu, including the Hard Rock Cafe in Madras. He has a B.A. degree in English Literature from American College in Madurai . cmcentre.org

Dr. M.P. Vasimalai, Phd, Co-Founder/Co-Sponsor is the Founder/ Executive Director of the DHAN Foundation in India. Mr. M.P. Vasimalai, Executive Director of DHAN Foundation is a post graduate in Agriculture and a management graduate from the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad. He has over three decades of experience in development work and is one of the key people in setting up Professional Assistance for Development Action (PRADAN). He was instrumental in setting up DHAN Foundation in 1997. He has specialized in community organization, designing development interventions in the fields of natural resource management, livelihood promotion and institutional development. He has traveled extensively within and outside India and has presented papers on these themes. He is also holding various positions in national and international forums, working groups, task forces and missions of Central and State governments on these themes. He was instrumental in promoting various network organizations. His areas of interest are institution building, leadership development and promoting various development themes for poverty reduction.

Dr. David Blake Willis, PhD, Project Advisor, Professor of Anthropology, Fielding Graduate University, Santa Barbara, USA Doctoral faculty – School of Human & Organizational Development.  Lived and worked in Madurai, South India, and lived 35 years in Asia, including Kobe, Japan, where rivers are a prime cultural/ecological feature of the landscape. 

Dr. Geeta Mehta, PhD, Project Co-Sponsor, Founder/President of Asia Initiatives. Geeta is the Adjunct Professor of Architecture and Urban Design at Columbia University in New York.  She serves on the advisory board of Millennium Cities Initiatives at the Earth Institute at Columbia University. She has worked on community focused design and poverty alleviation projects in India, Ghana, Kenya, Jamaica, Brazil, and Colombia. She is also the Co-Founder of “URBZ: User Generated Cities” (www.urbz.net), a think tank committed to empowering people at the community level to improve their own neighborhoods. Geeta is the past President of the American Institute of Architects’ Japan Chapter. asiainitiatives.org

We also invite others throughout the world who appreciate the Vaigai River and its deep history around Madurai to join us.

FUNDING

At this point we need funding to make this project possible. Our campaign is here specifically to fund our Educational Community-Building Workshop Series that is part of the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project.

The Future of the Vaigai River

With your support, the Vaigai River will be renewed with creative inspiration and collaborative efforts of the community as well as the support of the many individuals and organizations in Madurai and beyond who care about the future of the rivers, natural resources, ecological sustainability, and water on which we all depend for our future survival.

top:Boys jumping in Vaigai River, Henk Oochappan, TrekEarth, middle: K K Sundar; Through the Xpress Lens, bottom: Continents Insolites

How You Can Make an Impact
Share our mission with your friends and networks.

DONATE NOW! 

Your support will enable us to launch the Vaigai River Restoration Project!

A donation of $1,000 or $5,000 includes a wearable art scarf by Indian artist Siona Benjamin.

http://artsiona.com/sionaware.php

Wearable art scarf by Siona Benjamin, 72" x 22"

Fund This Campaign

  • The Vaigai River Restoration Project 
  • Twitter
  • Facebook
  • Instragram

For More Information

  • The Vaigai River Restoration Project 
  • Earth Celebrations
  • DHAN Foundation
  • Asia Initiatives

SUPPORT

DONATE NOW! 

Join Us - Help Earth Celebrations Launch our new project to restore the Vaigai River in India! 

Earth Celebrations is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization since 1992. All donations are tax-deductible to the full extent of the law.

CONTACT

Felicia Young
Project Co-Founder/Co-Director/ Co-Sponsor
Founder/Executive Director, Earth Celebrations
New York City, New York, USA
347-752-0854
felicia@earthcelebrations.com 
earthcelebrations.com

Felicia Young, Founder / Executive Director of Earth Celebrations

A project to restore the Vaigai River in Madurai, India that is in a 
severe crisis due to pollution, waste dumping, and the drying effects of
