Madurai’s significance as a center for textiles dates back to its ancient past. Madurai is also the place where in 1921 Mahatma Gandhi relinquished his western clothing to wear a loincloth made of khadi (homespun cloth) as an act to align himself with the people, and as an act of social change.GOALS: Community Building, Social Action, & SolutionsThe project plans for the Vaigai River Restoration include the following:• Raising awareness for better waste management practices among communities.• Raising awareness for restoration of water quality, efforts to provide safe drinking water, and  DHAN Foundation’s existing projects such as Vayalagam Tankfed Agriculture Development Program (VTADP).• Building partnerships of stakeholders and engaging city officials, corporations, environmental organizations, activists, farming groups, schools and universities to be mobilized and participate in solutions to restore the river• Engaging community participation in creative ecological art project and pageant performance to bring attention to the river, its history, and efforts to restore the health of the river for drinking water, agriculture, recreation, and peaceful open space within the city • Highlight and initiate proposals for visions for the future of the river such as a river park along the banks of the Vaigai and other recreational uses that promote the care and appreciation of the river, its historical legacy, and future as an ecological oasis within the cityTop: R. Ashok; “And Quietly Flows a Much Sullied Vaigai,” The Hindu, Bottom: R. Ashok; Photo Feature in The Hindu turns PIL Petition, The Hindu 
STATEMENTS
OF NEED “Once the preliminary work of clearing garbage is completed, measures will be taken to stop public from letting sewage water into the river. We have invited suggestions from people and activists to keep the river clean.”   - Mayor V.V. Rajan Chellappa of Madurai
“The
major area of pollution falls within the city limit… solid waste, plastic
waste, untreated sewage water from institutions and houses act as the major
pollutants. Only by increasing the water flow of the river, it can be brought
to life again. Mixing of sewage water and dumping of solid waste should also be
stopped to set it right.”   - Professor G
Balaji, Department of Architecture, Thiagarajar College of Engineering
“A
proper vision from all stakeholders will help preserve our rivers.”   - K Kalidas,
President of Osai, an environmental NGO
“Untreated
effluents have raised the pollution level of water. The concentration of total
dissolved solids (TSD) in water here is 3,500 to 4,000 ppm, when the acceptable
level should be below 500 ppm. Resultantly, the areas adjoining Chinnalapatti
are fast becoming barren due to underground pollution. Agriculture is also affected.” - S
Mahendran, Manager of the Agriculture Technology Management Association
Mayor V.V. Rajan Chellappa inspects a mass cleaning program, Vaigai Bed Loses Litter, The Hindu
PROJECT TIMELINE
•
The public launch of the project is scheduled for Mahatma Gandhi's birthday,
October 2, 2014 by Dhan Foundation.

• Educational Community Building / Public Awareness Workshops:January 2015 - April 2015
• Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Event: April 2015

STRATEGY: Raise Awareness, Mobilize Action &
Implement Solutions

One of the first steps to
restoring the Vaigai River is building a collaborative partnership of
stakeholders, including environmental organizations, schools, universities,
farming groups, activists, government representatives, cultural
institutions, artisans, performers, and the people of Madurai, who
will be mobilized and work together to positively impact the future of the
Vaigai River. Through the innovative and creative strategy, we will
engage community participants in a grassroots educational and social
action campaign. The community will help identify the issues, raise public
awareness, and participate in direct action and implementation of
solutions. 
Actions Already Underway since April 2014: 
• Stakeholders Meetings in Madurai being organized by the DHAN Foundation
• Building partnerships and collaborations for the workshops and pageant
with numerous schools and organizations including TheThiagarajar
College of Engineering and The World Storytelling Institute in Chennai. The
group of partner organizations and community participants is growing every day,
along with our global support network from New York, California, Delhi, Mumbai,
Chennai, Madurai, and beyond.
• Enlisting artisans of folk art and performing
traditions from clay sculpture, paper mache, handloom weavers, Sungadi sari
makers, artisans utilizing traditional organic vegetable dye techniques,
painters, kavadi headdress builders, as well as performers of music, dance,
theater, poetry, storytelling, and ceremony. 
• Gathering key environmental educators to work
alongside the artisans for the educational workshops.
Earth Celebrations Workshops in 2012 engaging children in NYC to create Stewards of the River Robes using homemade paint made from fruits, vegetables, and plants.
Educational Community-Building Workshops: January — April 2015:Free workshops will be conducted by the artists-in-residence/workshop instructors in collaboration with environmental educators to engage community members and students, educating the participants
on the issues of the Vaigai River and solutions to be implemented. Asia
Initiatives will bring in their unique system of Social Capital Credits
(SoCCs) as a way to incentivize the community to attend the workshops and
contribute towards the river restoration. The work created in the workshops will
raise awareness for specific issues and will be presented in the Pageant.
The workshop series engages
youth and adults for 3 months to:
•  Explore
the diversity of plant and animal life as indicators of the river’s
health, as well as discuss current issues concerning pollution and waste through
a ‘place-based’ learning process.
•  Work with artists-in-residence to create spectacular
visual arts works such as mobile sculptures/puppets and costumes for the
procession inspired by the species, habitats, issues, and restoration efforts
of the river.
•  Utilize ecologically friendly practices in the
creation of art projects, incorporating the use of recycled, natural and
organic materials.
•  Engage local artisans to participate in the project creating visual art projects highlighting their folk art traditions such as: clay sculptures, costumes, handloom textiles, bamboo/paper-maché sculpture, decorative processional staffs, headdresses, masks, face painting,
palanquins/processional sculpture carts, kolam rice/chalk powder drawings,
Sungudi saree and dyeing techniques, that revive traditional vegetables dyes
rather than chemical dyes that pollute the river.
•  Social Capital Credits (SoCCs), a virtual currency for social good, will be used to implement the above processes not only during the workshops, but as a long term practice for sustainable ecological and social development. People will be able to earn SoCCs by helping with the pageant, and river cleaning actions such as waste management, maintaining irrigation channels and water tanks, planting trees etc. They will be able to use the SoCCs thus earned to get services like subsidized electricity, telephone talk time, school scholarships, healthcare, etc. 
(CLICK HERE TO LEARN HOW SoCCs WILL HELP IN VAIGAI RIVER RESTORATION)
•  Develop solutions for river restoration.
Image Sources Starting from Top: K. Ananthan, The Hindu; Earth Celebrations Hudson River Pageant Puppet Workshop, New York City; S. James, The Hindu

VAIGAI
RIVER RESTORATION PAGEANT:Procession
with Site-Specific Performances: April 2015 
The educational
community-building workshop series is planned to culminate in the Vaigai River
Pageant. The pageant will feature a procession of giant mobile sculptures,
spectacular costumes, and musical bands highlighting the Vaigai River. 
Performances by local artists and community groups will be presented at
significant sites along the route, following the river bank in Madurai.  Performances will include theater, dance,
songs, music, poetry, and ceremony highlighting the history, current issues,
and future restoration of the river. Mulaipari festival at
Koovathupatti, Tamil Nadu,  HenkOochappan, TrekEarth 

 Visual Art and Performances for the Pageant:   
• Giant mobile sculptures on traditional processional carts and puppets utilize local folk traditions to represent native species, habitat, history, issues, and efforts to restore the
river. 
• Costumes will utilize folk traditions and incorporate handloom textiles and Sungudi fabrics, a traditional craft of Madurai. Craftsmen will be incentivized to use traditional vegetable dyes rather than chemical pigments that pollute the river. 
• Educational performances by local performing and community groups address: legacy of Vaigai River in mythological and historic texts; native river species and habitats; issues of waste and sewage dumping; industrial and chemical pollution; and restoration efforts to improve water quality, water flow, and health of the river.    
• Organic Planting Performance celebrating the river as a life source for agriculture and sustainable organic farming and importance of water storage tank restoration for irrigation.
• River Cleansing Ceremony will engage community participants in
a choreographed movement and clean-up along the river bank. 
• Live Fish Release: ceremonial action - children offer fish
back to the river.
Pageant Date: April 2015: Prior to Chithirai Festival in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South IndiaTop: Mulaipari festival at Koovathupatti, Tamil Nadu; Terres de Charme,Middle: Young students performing
traditional dances, Lokvani, Bottom: Men in procession carrying large
decorative ambala kalvadis, The Hindu
WHO WE ARE
FOUNDING CO-SPONSORS –The Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project is produced by Earth Celebrations, a non-profit environmental and arts organization based in New York City, in partnership with the DAHN Foundation, an NGO and non-profit organization working to restore the Vaigai River in Madurai, South India.
Earth Celebrations– Earth
Celebrations is a New York City based non-profit organization founded by
Felicia Young which works to engage communities to address and effect change on ecological issues through the arts. Earth Celebrations’ creative environmental and arts programs address and effect change on issues such as:  climate change, river species and habitat restoration, and the preservation of community gardens, parks, and a healthy urban environment, while highlighting ecological sustainability. Earth Celebrations’ innovative theatrical pageants and community-based arts programs address crucial ecological issues, including our 15 year effort that led to the preservation of community gardens on the Lower East Side and throughout New York City and the Hudson River Pageant to raise awareness for the restoration of the Hudson River and addressing climate change.  
Earth Celebrations
Past Sponsors include:
World Financial Center, Brookfield
Properties, Bank of America, Con
Edison, Citibank, Chase Bank,
Colgate-Palmolive, Eileen Fisher,
New York State Council on the Arts,
Lower Manhattan Cultural Council
and The Hudson River Park Trust. 
earthcelebrations.com

DHAN
Foundation– Development
of Humane Action (DHAN) Foundation, an NGO and nonprofit organization based in Madurai, South India, has a mission to “build people and institutions for
development innovations and upscale (them) to enable poverty reduction and
self-reliance in poor communities.” The program has identified ‘water’ as a unique tool for alleviating poverty and has evolved into a separate people’s institution, the ‘DHAN Vayalagam (Tank) Foundation (DVTF)’. The Foundation aims to restore water quality and access water through tank-based watershed development supporting agriculture needs. DHAN is also engaged in programs to clean and restore the Vaigai River from waste dumping and contaminants, and to raise community awareness and participation in these efforts. DHAN (Development of Human Action) Foundation, was awarded the India
NGO award in 2009 by The Rockefeller Foundation.
DHAN Foundation Sponsors include: Ford Foundation, Sir Rata Tata Trust, Axis Bank
Foundation, International Water Management Institute-RUAF Foundation and the Department of Tourism, Tamil Nadu. dhan.org

Asia Initiatives– Asia Initiatives (AI), a New York registered non-profit organization undertakes projects that are pro-environment and pro-poor. AI has pioneered the use of Social Capital Credits (SoCCs) to incentivize local people to undertake social good activities, and will develop the SoCCs system to incentivize attendance in the workshops, and the restoration the Vaigai River, working closely with the local community and other stakeholders. This initiative is leadby Dr. Geeta Mehta, Professor of Architecture and Urban Design at Columbia University and the Founder/President of Asia Initiatives. 
Asia Initiatives Corporate Partners include: Aveda, Japan Citigroup Services
(Japan) Ltd., Credit Suisse, First Boston Securities, Daimler Chrysler, and Ford Motor Company to name a few. asiainitiatives.org

PROJECT LEADERSHIP
Felicia Young, Co-Founder/Co-Director
is a theatrical pageant director and founder of Earth Celebrations a non-profit
organization dedicated to engaging communities to address and effect change on
ecological issues through the arts. She has produced large-scale theatrical
pageants for the past 25 years such as the Rites of Spring: Procession to Save
Our Gardens (1991-2005) on the Lower East Side of New York City, which
mobilized a grass-root effort and directly led to the preservation of many
community gardens on the Lower East Side and throughout New York City. In 2009
Felicia launched the Hudson River Pageant to restore the species and habitats
of the Hudson River and address climate change in New York City. She has
produced and directed theatrical pageants and community-based arts projects for
numerous organizations including: the New York City Department of Parks and
Recreation, the Alternative Museum, Lincoln Center for The Performing Arts,
Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, Brookfield Properties> arts World
Financial Center, The World Trade Center, and Earth Day New York. She has a BA
in Art History from Skidmore College, 1987, and a MA degree in Performance
Studies from New York University, 1994. earthcelebrations.com
Rajasekaran
Jesudasan, Co-Founder/Co-Director is
a Trustee of Arunachalam Jesudasan Trust and Field Director CM Centre Madurai
Services for International Scholars, Educators, Researchers & Students in
South India, where he is currently on a sabbatical for a year until May 2015.
He served for more than 25 years as Resident Coordinator for the University of
Wisconsin’s College Year in India Programme, Madurai, and during that time also
assisted a great many visiting scholars from USA and European Universities. As
Field Director at CM Centre, Sekar organizes every resource necessary to
provide for the needs of scholars and students, ranging from setting up
meetings with government agencies, NGOs, individuals, private institutions or business
houses to interviewing a village shaman. For the past 20 years Sekar has been
researching and documenting the Vaigai River and is Co-Author of Stretch of
Life on the Vaigai River with Peter Nabakov. Rajasekaran as Co-Director of
the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project will coordinate with DHAN
Foundation and Earth Celebrations, engage collaborating community partners,
artists, and performers, and manage production logistics. Sekar is also a
social activist and a musician who performs throughout Tamil Nadu, including
the Hard Rock Cafe in Madras. He has a B.A. degree in English Literature from
American College in Madurai . cmcentre.org
Dr. M.P. Vasimalai,
Phd, Co-Founder/Co-Sponsor is the
Founder/ Executive Director of the DHAN Foundation in India. Mr. M.P.
Vasimalai, Executive Director of DHAN Foundation is a post graduate in
Agriculture and a management graduate from the Indian Institute of Management,
Ahmedabad. He has over three decades of experience in development work and is one
of the key people in setting up Professional Assistance for Development Action
(PRADAN). He was instrumental in setting up DHAN Foundation in 1997. He has
specialized in community organization, designing development interventions in
the fields of natural resource management, livelihood promotion and
institutional development. He has traveled extensively within and outside India
and has presented papers on these themes. He is also holding various positions
in national and international forums, working groups, task forces and missions
of Central and State governments on these themes. He was instrumental in promoting
various network organizations. His areas of interest are institution building,
leadership development and promoting various development themes for poverty
reduction. 
Dr. David Blake
Willis, PhD, Project Advisor, Professor of Anthropology, Fielding Graduate University, Santa
Barbara, USA Doctoral faculty – School of Human & Organizational
Development.  Lived and worked in Madurai, South India, and lived 35 years
in Asia, including Kobe, Japan, where rivers are a prime cultural/ecological
feature of the landscape. 
Dr. Geeta Mehta, PhD, Project Co-Sponsor, Founder/President
of Asia Initiatives.
Geeta is the Adjunct Professor of Architecture and Urban Design at Columbia
University in New York.  She serves on
the advisory board of Millennium Cities Initiatives at the Earth Institute at
Columbia University. She has worked on community focused design and poverty
alleviation projects in India, Ghana, Kenya, Jamaica, Brazil, and Colombia. She
is also the Co-Founder of “URBZ: User Generated Cities” (www.urbz.net), a think tank committed to empowering people at the
community level to improve their own neighborhoods. Geeta is the past President
of the American Institute of Architects’ Japan Chapter. asiainitiatives.org
We also invite others throughout the world who
appreciate the Vaigai River and its deep history around Madurai to join us.FUNDINGAt this point we need funding to make this project possible. Our campaign is here specifically to fund our Educational Community-Building Workshop Series that is part of the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project.
The Future of the Vaigai RiverWith your support, the Vaigai River will be renewed with creative inspiration and collaborative efforts of the community as well as the support of the many individuals and organizations in Madurai and beyond who care about the future of the rivers, natural resources, ecological sustainability, and water on which we all depend for our future survival.

top:Boys jumping in Vaigai River, Henk Oochappan, TrekEarth, middle: K K Sundar; Through the Xpress Lens, bottom: Continents InsolitesHow You Can Make an ImpactShare our mission with your friends and networks.DONATE NOW! Your support will enable us to launch the Vaigai River Restoration Project!
A donation of $1,000 or $5,000 includes a wearable art scarf by Indian artist Siona Benjamin.http://artsiona.com/sionaware.php
Wearable art scarf by Siona Benjamin, 72" x 22"

Felicia Young

story:
Prvi put u historiji Bosne i Hercegovine ulaže se u obnovljive izvore energije pomoću grupnog finansiranja, a Vi možete postati dio te historije!

Ova kampanja ima za cilj ulaganje u sunčevu energiju za potrebe Zavoda za zbrinjavanje mentalno invalidnih osoba „Drin“.

Ideja je vrlo jednostavna. Ovoj ustanovi potrebna je topla voda 24 sata dnevno i to 365 dana u godini. Dio te energije može se dobiti korištenjem sunčeve energije, te je upravo to ono što možemo postići ovom kampanjom. Na ovaj način smanjiti će se troškovi za energiju ove Ustanove čime pomažemo njenim korisnicima!

Zavod za zbrinjavanje mentalno invalidnih osoba „Drin“ Fojnica osnovan je 1955. godine  i predstavlja  centar za socijalno i zdravstveno zbrinjavanje, produženo liječenje i rehabilitaciju, obučavanje za samostalan život osoba sa smetnjama u razvoju i osoba sa smetnjama u duševnom zdravlju. Ono što ovu Ustanovu čini jedinstvenom jeste da je to jedina ustanova ovog tipa u Bosni i Hercegovini koja zbrinjava i novorođenčad.

Danas, ova Ustanova ima oko 500 korisnika koji tu žive, te 250 zaposlenih. Cilj ove Ustanove je da omogući svojim korisnicima human boravak, da im poboljša kvalitetu življenja, te da kreira ambijent i atmosferu toploga doma.

Liječenje i rehabilitacija samo su dio priče o Drinu koji zapravo predstavlja veliku porodicu koja se svakodnevno suočava sa izazovima života, ali i mnogim drugim problemima. Jedan od problema svakako su i veliki računi za električnu energiju. Godišnje se za električnu energiju izdvaja preko 250.000 KM. 

Kako bi smanjili troškove za energiju i novac mogli investirati za druge potrebe, ova porodica treba nas, zajednicu! 

Ideja je uložiti novac za nabavku solarnih kolektora za potrošnu toplu vodu koji će se instalirali na krovove ove Ustanove. Solarna energija, za razliku od fosilnih goriva, dostupna je u neograničenoj mjeri i ne proizvodi štetne emisije. Instalacijom solarnih kolektora moguće je ostvariti uštede i do 60 % za pripremu potrošne tople vode,  što će povoljnije uticati i na okoliš. 

Sa učešćem u ovoj kampanji omogućiti ćete ovoj velikoj porodici da smanji svoju potrošnju, te novac od ušteda uloži u druge, njima potrebnije stvari!!! 

Angažmanom u ovoj kampanji učestvujte u nabavci i instalaciji solarnih kolektora. 

Za ovaj poduhvat potrebno nam je minimalno 20.000 KM, odnosno 15.000 USD. 

Pripremili smo i ručno rađene poklone. Svi pokloni su dizajnirani i kreirani od strane korisnika ove ustanove. 

Ukoliko niste spremni finansijski podržati ovu kampanju molimo Vas da slanjem e-mailova Vašim kolegama i prijateljima, te postavljanjem ove kampanje na društvenim mrežama, učestvujete u ovoj održivoj priči! 

Promocija inicijativa za građansku energiju, obnovljivi izvori energije i energijska efikasnost su budućnost Bosne i Hercegovine.

Pokažimo da je moguće finansirati projekte građanske energije kako bi se u budućnosti povećao  broj inicijativa. 

Energija mora i treba biti u rukama građana i iz tog razloga želimo da stavimo građane u centar dešavanja.

Vrijeme je da energiju vratimo građanima, vrijeme je za inicijative za građansku energiju.

#BuditeDioHistorije
#GradjanskaEnergija

Pozivamo vas da budete dio ove velike porodice! 

Hvala vam.

For the first time in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is possible to invest in renewable energy sources through group financing, and you can become part of that history!

The aim of this campaign is to invest in solar energy for the needs of the Public Institution for Placement of Persons with Mental Disabilities „Drin“, Fojnica.

The idea is very simple. This institution needs hot water 24 hours a day and for 365 days a year. Part of this energy can be obtained by using solar energy, and that is exactly what we can achieve with this campaign. In this way the energy costs of this institution will reduce, which will directly help its users.

Public Institution for Placement of Persons with Mental Disabilities „Drin“, Fojnica was established in 1955. and is a centre for social and health care, extended treatment and rehabilitation, training for the independent life of people with developmental disorders and persons with mental health problems. What makes this institution unique is that it is the only institution of this type in Bosnia and Herzegovina that cares for the new-borns.

Today, this Institution has about 500 people-beneficiaries living there and 250 employees. The purpose of this Institution is to enable its beneficiaries to live in a humane environment, improve their quality of life, and create the ambiance and atmosphere of a warm home.

Treatment and rehabilitation are just part of the story in “Drin”, which is actually a big family that faces everyday life challenges, as well as many other problems. One of the problems is certainly big electricity bills. Electricity costs are over 250.000 KM (125.000 EUR) per year.

In order to reduce energy costs and invest money in other pressing needs, this family needs us, the community!

The idea is to invest money for solar hot water collectors that will be installed on the roof of this institution. Solar energy, unlike fossil fuels, is available to an unlimited extent and does not produce harmful emissions. By installing solar collectors, it is possible to save up to 60% for the preparation of hot water, which will also have a positive effect on the environment.

By participating in this campaign, you will enable this great family to reduce their expenses, and invest in other, more necessary things!!!

By engaging in this campaign, you will participate in the procurement and installation of solar collectors.

For this, we need a minimum of 20.000 KM (or 15.000 USD).

If you are not prepared to financially support this campaign, please send this email to your colleagues and friends. By sharing this campaign on social networks you are participating in this sustainable idea!

Promotion of citizens’ energy, renewable energy sources and energy efficiency initiatives are the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Let us show that it is possible to finance citizen energy projects in order to increase the number of similar initiatives in the future.

Energy must and should be in the hands of citizens, and for that reason we want to put citizens in the centre of this event.

It's time to bring energy back to citizens, it’s time for citizen energy initiatives.

#Bethepartofhistory

#CitizenEnergy

We invite you to be part of this great family!

Thank you.

#BuditeDioHistorije#GradjanskaEnergija
Pozivamo vas da budete dio ove velike porodice! 
Hvala vam.


For the first time in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is possible to invest in renewable energy sources through group financing, and you can become part of that history!
The aim of this campaign is to invest in solar energy for the needs of the Public Institution for Placement of Persons with Mental Disabilities „Drin“, Fojnica.
The idea is very simple. This institution needs hot water 24 hours a day and for 365 days a year. Part of this energy can be obtained by using solar energy, and that is exactly what we can achieve with this campaign. In this way the energy costs of this institution will reduce, which will directly help its users.

Public Institution for Placement of Persons with Mental Disabilities „Drin“, Fojnica was established in 1955. and is a centre for social and health care, extended treatment and rehabilitation, training for the independent life of people with developmental disorders and persons with mental health problems. What makes this institution unique is that it is the only institution of this type in Bosnia and Herzegovina that cares for the new-borns.
Today, this Institution has about 500 people-beneficiaries living there and 250 employees. The purpose of this Institution is to enable its beneficiaries to live in a humane environment, improve their quality of life, and create the ambiance and atmosphere of a warm home.
Treatment and rehabilitation are just part of the story in “Drin”, which is actually a big family that faces everyday life challenges, as well as many other problems. One of the problems is certainly big electricity bills. Electricity costs are over 250.000 KM (125.000 EUR) per year.

In order to reduce energy costs and invest money in other pressing needs, this family needs us, the community!
The idea is to invest money for solar hot water collectors that will be installed on the roof of this institution. Solar energy, unlike fossil fuels, is available to an unlimited extent and does not produce harmful emissions. By installing solar collectors, it is possible to save up to 60% for the preparation of hot water, which will also have a positive effect on the environment.
By participating in this campaign, you will enable this great family to reduce their expenses, and invest in other, more necessary things!!!

By engaging in this campaign, you will participate in the procurement and installation of solar collectors.
For this, we need a minimum of 20.000 KM (or 15.000 USD).
If you are not prepared to financially support this campaign, please send this email to your colleagues and friends. By sharing this campaign on social networks you are participating in this sustainable idea!

Promotion of citizens’ energy, renewable energy sources and energy efficiency initiatives are the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Let us show that it is possible to finance citizen energy projects in order to increase the number of similar initiatives in the future.
Energy must and should be in the hands of citizens, and for that reason we want to put citizens in the centre of this event.
It's time to bring energy back to citizens, it’s time for citizen energy initiatives.
#Bethepartofhistory
#CitizenEnergy
We invite you to be part of this great family!
Thank you.

story:
Do you remember the day you first connected with nature?

"This little girl experienced the wonders of nature for the first time at the Happy Earth Festival 2014.  Her eyes are bright and her heart is expanding in oneness with the mother duck flowing gracefully across the pond.  She turns to see if there is someone she can share this experience with.  Someone who will understand this new and amazing feeling inside of her; this need to connect with all that is around her.  To love and cherish this place that she is in."   

Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

Working together to share and grow education for sustainability in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.

The Happy Earth Environmental Education & Sustainability Forum (Happy Earth Forum) is a Voluntary Association comprising environmental educators from organisations working within the diverse field of environmental education.  We work collaboratively throughout the year to provide opportunities to connect children to nature and develop a positive environmental ethic.  

Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

A campaign to connect 1000 children to nature!

As chairperson of the Happy Earth Forum I would like to encourage you to participate in our campaign to connect 1000 children to nature at our annual Happy Earth Festival outreach at the KZN National Botanical Gardens in Pietermaritzburg on the 16th & 17th April 2015.  

Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

What is the Happy Earth Festival!

Environmental Educators from over twenty different organisations prepare hands-on experiential activities and environmental lessons that help children bond with nature and develop a positive environmental ethic.   We set up activity stands in the beautiful setting of the KZN National Botanical Gardens.  We have the help of around 60 volunteers from the University of Kwazulu-Natal and Working on Fire. 

We have great fun sharing these activities with children from schools from all over Pietermaritzburg.  Activities include 'The Greatest Race', a 'Scavenger Hunt', Interpretive trails, exploring wetlands and river health with MiniSASS (Stream Assessment Scoring System) and many more covering a wide range of environmental issues.  We would like your contribution of 10 dollars to ensure 1000 children develop positive attitudes, environmental knowledge and skills while having fun connecting with nature!

Join heads, hands and hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

Creating opportunities for positive mentorship and environmental learning.

We would like your help to raise 10 dollars per child to make the Happy Earth Festival a most special day in the lives of 1000 children.  A day that they can look back on with wonder and share with others.  A day that brings these children hope and the start of a wonderful and caring relationship with nature.

Join head, hands & hearts and help to connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

Making a collective difference to the critical state our planet is in.

This is our first crowd sourcing campaign and it is very exciting to know that in sharing our work through Indiegogo, we can build new networks, new friends and colleagues, and strengthen our collective potential to make a difference to the critical state our planet is in!    

Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

A dire need for funding outreach environmental education programmes

Children from poor urban schools cannot afford transport or food to come to the event. We love working together as a Team on collaborative outreach projects but our operational budgets do not include provision for these activities.  

Building positive relationships between children and our Earth.

At 10 dollars per child the money will be used to offset costs to organize the event,  provide transport, food, educational resources and requirements, so that together, we can help children build positive relationships with our Earth.  You can help connect a child to nature!  We need 1000 people to support our Happy Earth Environmental Education and Sustainability Forum Indiegogo Campaign!  

Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

A brand new way of seeing and experiencing the Earth.

We want to foster a different way of perceiving and experiencing the Earth. Children from impoverished and challenged socio-environmental circumstances have limited opportunities to explore nature. They are often caught up in the degraded surroundings they grow up in. On the other hand children from more affluent backgrounds are mostly  caught up in consumerist lifestyles, governed by the excessive use of technology and an over structured schooling system. Both groups are separated from the harmonious, healing and holistic lessons that nature holds for them.  

Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

Early positive nature-based experiences leads to environmentally responsible behaviour.

 We've learnt from our own experience that early childhood experiences in which children are introduced to a friendly earth, lead to life-long environmentally responsible behavior. 

Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

An urgent educational intervention is necessary to heal an Earth in crisis

Like the rest of the world, South Africa is facing serious socio-environmental issues that undermine the ability of natural eco-systems to support life.  The over-consumption of resources, degradation of the environment and climate change are challenges to which we need to respond urgently at an educational level.  Teachers need to understand these inter-related issues sufficiently to engage and guide learners to find better ways of living and working, through developing critical thinking, imaginative problem solving processes, creativity and innovation.

Join heads, hands & hearts and help to connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

What will happen if we don't make our target funding?

This is our third Happy Earth Festival event and the Happy Earth Forum's organizing committee is confident of meeting all expectations for a successful event.   With our appeal going out locally to family, friends and colleagues we are counting on lots of home grown support as well as encouraging many new friends from around the world to support our work.  Should we not make our target funding of  10 000 USD , we will still work hard at making our event accessible to as many schools and learners as possible and providing what we can on the day. 

On the other hand, if we exceed our expectations! 

Should we exceed our funding expectations, we would be delighted to use the additional funds for our second annual outreach event, the Happy Earth Sustainability and Food Gardening Exhibition, held as part of The Garden Show in Pietermaritzburg, in September.   This is another exciting opportunity to connect children to nature through showcasing environmental education, sustainability and gardening projects!

Who has helped us already!

We have received contributions from the following organisations:

  • SANBI KZN National Botanical Gardens - Venue
  • Rotary Pietermaritzburg Club 416.82 USD (R5000) for schools transport
  • KZN Botanical Society 416.82 USD (R5000) for schools transport
  • PMMBT P.E.A.C.E. Project 416.82 (R5000) for catering for volunteers
  • Sunshine Bread Bakery - 500 loaves of bread for sandwiches 
  • Parklane Spar - 41.68 USD (R500) for sandwich fillings
  • Mdeni Meats - 300 Vienna Sausages, 4kg polony & 300 cans Juice
  • Oasis - 4 Filter Water Dispensers
  • WESSA Eco-Schools PMB (Rand Merchant Bank)   Eco-Schools Award Ceremony
  • WESSA Eco-Schools KZN 857.82 USD (R10 000) for Eco-schools transport
  • The Installation Guys - Sound System & Technician 293.24 USD (R3 500) 
Join heads, hands & hearts and help connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

What is our vision?

It is the vision of the Happy Earth Forum to act as a platform, for networking and collaborative action, that supports environmental educators in reconnecting society to the natural environment and to support resilience and sustainability, within and beyond the Umgungundlovu District, Kwazulu-Natal, South Africa.  


Where can you get more information?

Website address: https://happyeartheesforum.wordpress.com
Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/happyearthforum 

I will keep you updated as our campaign progresses.  We have chosen to launch our campaign for the month of April.   In this way we can bring you the excitement of the build-up, all the action of the event and stories and activities that we would like to share with you thereafter.  

Do encourage all your family, friends and colleagues to join us as we celebrate our Happy Earth Festival in April!

Kind regards,
Pandora Long
Join hands in helping to connect 1000 children to nature at the Happy Earth Festival 2015 by contributing 10 dollars today!

story: Colorado
story_txt: Colorado

story:
Where we learn matters.

Green schools are more than buildings. They are places where children learn the wonders of the world and teachers prepare the next generation of leaders and citizens. Not all schools are built and operated to be full of clean air and sunlight and to be free of toxic materials and harmful chemicals. 

We seek to change that by helping Wisconsin schools become more green. For the 2014 Green Apple Day of Service, the Wisconsin Green Building Alliance's Green Schools Committee wants to give support to Wisconsin schools to host interactive projects focused on recycling and waste reduction for the 2014 Green Apple Day of Service. Green Apple Day of Service is officially on September 27, 2014, but projects will be held within a 4 - 6 week span of the date. Here are a few examples of the types of projects your donation may fund:

  • A waste stream sort to learn about where trash goes and the importance of recycling and reusing
  • Creation of a new recycling program or a recycling campaign
  • Planning and implementation of a solid waste management policy
  • An e-waste recycling drive

What We Need

The Wisconsin Green Building Alliance's Green Schools Committee is collecting donations to support Wisconsin schools participating in Green Apple Day of Service. Our goal is to raise $7000 by May 31, 2014. We hope to give 60 schools $100 towards a project that helps to green their school.

Whether we reach our goal, all funding raised through this campaign will go to Wisconsin schools.

The Impact

  • More than 20% of public schools in the U.S. report having unsatisfactory indoor air quality. Controlling exposure to indoor environmental factors, such as carbon monoxide, dust, and pollen, could prevent more than 65% of asthma cases among elementary school-age children.
  • When ventilation rates are at or below minimum standards, an associated decrease of 5-10% occurs in certain aspects of student performance tests.
  • A green school with acoustical ceiling tiles, lined ductwork and HVAC systems with appropriately placed vents, provides an environment that lessens distractions and encourages participation.
  • Comfortable indoor temperatures enhance productivity and keep students more alert. 
  • Green schools use 33% less energy and 32% less water than conventionally constructed schools, significantly reducing utility costs over the average 42-year lifecycle of a school.
  • Students can become ambassadors of social and environmental responsibility, educating their family, friends and community about the value of sustainable lifestyles.
  • Green schools provide a clear opportunity to connect students with curricula in environmental and science technology engineering and mathematics (STEM) education, and can serve as a tool for interactive lessons across all subjects.

Other Ways You Can Help

Visit http://www.wgba.org/wgbagados to volunteer at a local school and find resources to tell your school about how they can participate in 2014 Green Apple Day of Service.

story:
ABOUT COORC.ORG

We are fund-raising for coastal clean-ups world wide. Come join us. 


First we are happy to announce that every donation will be matched up to the goal amount when reached! So your $10 donation becomes $20 for COORC and so on and so on.  COORC stands for CLEAN OUR OCEANS REFUGE COALITION.  We are a non-profit organization that I founded shortly after watching the feature length documentary film "Trashed". This documentary which is produced by and stars Jeremy Irons is an eye opener to the awful truth and health problems being caused around the world by this ocean pollution problem. I was so moved by this film that I felt a call to action.  I answered that call when I formed COORC and I am here today to tell you more about what we are up to and how you can play your part in the solution. 

Today COORC.ORG is an organization with zero salaries given to our board members and is 100% transparent. In addition to managing our own projects we give aid in various forms to other organizations and individuals that share our goals.


Matching donations until the goal amount is reached


About COORC & TCOM



Team Building

Meanwhile, on our to-do list is building a team of volunteers world wide via social media which will organize beach clean-ups. The waste collection from these beach clean ups will be shipped  to the TCOM plant located in Hawaii. COORC not only has a goal to build a team of volunteers but to also  work with corporations that will help fund our clean-up processes in the long term. We are about community and long term improvements that last. 

One solution out of the many we  incorporate into our plans is TCOM Biomass technology. TCOM  stands for Thermo Combustion of Organic Material.  A long term goal of COORC is to establish self sustaining power plants in remote areas of the world that can revolutionize the value of debris and plastic in our oceans and on our shores. Please be sure to check back here on our IndieGoGo pages to have a look at our updates for more information on TCOM. 

Two Donation Perks We are Offering Qualify You for On-Screen Title Credits in the Documentary

Imagine having an Internet Movie Database listing as an associate producer or  producer that you can point your friends, family, and clients to. Imagine going to film festivals and being part of the filmmakers panel and receiving awards and having your name credited in news and magazine articles. Here you can help a great project and build a new career in the film industry with your first title credit or add to your film resume by being the support funding for this film project.  Shooting and editing is underway. 


Our Good Works

COORC Is Proud To Sponsor Algalita Marine Research Institute.  With help from COORC Captain Moore and the crew of the Alguita  set out from Long Beach, CA in July, 2014, to live in the Garbage Patch for six weeks.  The team of scientist conducted research to compliment Captain Moore's 15 years of research and sampling the GPGP. COORC.ORG is happy to have  sponsored Moore with new sails for the voyage along with a new Satellite System for ship to shore communications.  COORC also hired a Master of Advanced Studies, Marine Biodiversity and Conservation Scripps Institution of Oceanography graduate as a videographer and helping hand on board the Voyage.  The footage that she collected in the process of documenting the story of these scientists out there on this scientific journey will be part of a feature length documentary being produced by COORC.  This voyage has data sampled the largest segment of the ocean to-date. They discovered a whole new, seven ton, unnatural, ecosystem made out of Hi-Zex buoys in the middle of the Pacific, fish mutations, and startling  levels of pollution. COORC has other projects on-going that give support to things like the testing of samples and collecting and documenting the story of people's 'body  burden' which will become part of our documentary. Your body burden is a term that describes the levels and types of toxic chemicals in your body; some of those chemicals are there to stay.



The Impact


A Bit Moore Info ;-)

COORC is is very happy to have the opportunity to support an extensive research voyage like this in  the Pacific Gyre.  The voyage, as said, is lead by Captain Charles Moore, who is as we see it a true life hero.   And with him on this voyage is his co-skipper and expedition leader Dale Selvam. Moore is the top expert in the problem of ocean plastic pollution and has been a guest on CNN, Colbert Nation, The David Letterman Show, and TED Talk, just to name a few. He is also the author and co-author of numerous scientific papers and the book, Plastic Ocean.

In Closing

 Just as it takes a village to raise a child it takes team work and networking to tackle this problem of ocean plastic pollution. By working together, and having community organizers, we get a step closer to improving the situation of ocean plastic pollution.  Work in the oceans is expensive.  Ships must be maintained, crewed, and fueled and there are fees to be paid for hauling trash around. People involved need to eat and IP hosting fees have to be paid.  Information is shared to the masses with the use graphics, motion graphics, video, meetings, social media and people get moved around and beaches get cleaned up.

 In this process new generations will learn to care for their Earth while others will be inspired to start other projects that will affect the oceans.  By funding this campaign you will be sending money into the community in the form of paid jobs in addition to the volunteers who will be coming forward to help. By making a tax deductable donation today you are helping to save the oceans, people and communities by helping us take trash off the beaches and out of the oceans.  Thank you.

Matching donations up to reaching the goal amount. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Use the IndieGoGo share tools to help us get the word out. Visit http://coorc.org/ for more information, to contact us, to follow Captain Moore's ocean voyage blog, or to become a volunteer.

Imagine going to film festivals and being part of the filmmakers panel and receiving awards and having your name credited in news and magazine articles. Here you can help a great project and build a new career in the film industry with your first title credit or add to your film resume by being the support funding for this film project.  Shooting and editing is underway. 


Our Good Works
COORC Is Proud To Sponsor Algalita Marine Research Institute.  With help from COORC Captain Moore and the crew of the Alguita  set out from Long Beach, CA in July, 2014, to live in the Garbage Patch for six weeks.  The team of scientist conducted research to compliment Captain 
Moore's 15 years of research and sampling the GPGP. COORC.ORG is happy to have  
sponsored Moore with new sails for the voyage along with a new Satellite System for ship to shore communications.  COORC also
 hired a Master of Advanced Studies, Marine Biodiversity and  Conservation Scripps Institution of Oceanography graduate as a 
videographer and helping hand on board the Voyage.  The footage that she collected in the process of documenting the story of these scientists out there on this scientific journey will be part of a feature length documentary being produced by COORC.  This voyage has data sampled the largest segment of the ocean to-date. They discovered a whole new, seven ton, unnatural, ecosystem made out of Hi-Zex buoys in the middle of the Pacific, fish mutations, and startling  levels of pollution. COORC has other projects on-going that give support to things like the testing of samples and collecting and documenting the story of people's 'body  burden' which will become part of our documentary. Your body burden is a term that describes the levels and types of toxic chemicals in your body; some of those chemicals are there to stay. 





© 2014 This image is from a GoPro mounted on a drone. We are seeing the size of the Hi-Zex floating ecosystem.



 The Impact


© 2014 This image shows just some of the larger pieces of plastic trash pulled from the Pacific Ocean waters by Capt. Moore in July, 2014 as part of the data sampling. 


A Bit Moore Info ;-)




COORC is is very happy to have the opportunity to support an extensive research voyage like this in  the Pacific Gyre.  The voyage, as said, is lead by Captain Charles Moore, who is as we see it a true life hero.   And with him on this voyage is his co-skipper and expedition leader Dale Selvam. Moore is the top expert in the problem of ocean plastic pollution and has been a guest on CNN, Colbert Nation, The David Letterman Show, and TED Talk, just to name a few. He is also the author and co-author of numerous scientific papers and the book, Plastic Ocean. In Closing Just as it takes a village to raise a child it takes team work and networking to tackle this problem of ocean plastic pollution. By working together, and having community organizers, we get a step closer to improving the situation of ocean plastic pollution.  Work in the oceans is expensive.  Ships must be maintained, crewed, and fueled and there are fees to be paid for hauling trash around. People involved need to eat and IP hosting fees have to be paid.  Information is shared to the masses with the use graphics, motion graphics, video, meetings, social media and people get moved around and beaches get cleaned up.  In this process new generations will learn to care for their Earth while others will be inspired to start other projects that will affect the oceans.  By funding this campaign you will be sending money into the community in the form of paid jobs in addition to the volunteers who will be coming forward to help. By making a tax deductable donation today you are helping to save the oceans, people and communities by helping us take trash off the beaches and out of the oceans.  

Thank you. 
 


Matching donations up to reaching the goal amount. 
  Other Ways You Can HelpUse the IndieGoGo share tools to help us get the word out. Visit http://coorc.org/ for more information, to contact us, to follow Captain Moore's ocean voyage blog, or to become a volunteer.

story:
| About the trip

Introducing Kate Zrim from Australia, Galyna Tymoshenko from Kiev/Paris and Thalia Hernandez from Mexico City. We are all keen philanthropists, travellers and colleagues at Bain & Company, and although we work on opposite sides of the globe, there is one major thing we all share that brought us together, our love of planet Earth.  We are all super enthusiastic, totally motivated and absolutely 100% passionate about sustainability and saving Antarctica, the last great wilderness on Earth.

Luckily for us, we aren’t the only ones who care and want to make an impact! You may have heard of an organization called 2041; if you haven't, check them out, they are doing incredible things! It is an NGO led by polar explorer and sustainability leader Robert Swan OBE, the first man to walk to both the North and South Poles who has dedicated his life to the preservation of Antarctica. The mission of 2041 is to inform, engage and inspire the next generation of leaders to take responsibility, be sustainable, and know that now is the time for action in policy development, sustainable business generation and future technologies.

The International Antarctica Expedition (IAE) is one of 2041’s key events. We have won 3 of the ~80 places on the ship through a competitive selection process and we are excited to be joining the IAE team in March 2015.

  • As a team, we will work together to create change in our families, companies, communities and countries.
  • We will provide information, knowledge and insight from around the world to forge new relationships.
  • We will sail to the most fragile continent on earth to learn not only about the challenges Antarctica faces for survival, but also how we can shape ourselves as responsible leaders of the future and to face our own personal challenges.

| What We Need & What You Get

Please help us get on the ship! Our total fundraising goal is £30,000 to cover two things, a contribution to 2041's running costs (support for 2041’s ongoing work to support the protection of Antarctica and champion sustainability more broadly) and the expedition costs (enrollment in Robert Swan’s “Leadership on the Edge” program, passage on the Sea Spirit, and other supplies).

We will be funding as much as we can on our own (airfare, gear, other incidentals) – but it is not enough. In order to meet our goal and support this incredible cause, we really need your help to reach our target! 

We’ve come up with a long list of incentives to thank those of you who help support our mission.  Ranging from a postcard sent to you from Ushuaia (Capital of Tierra del Fuego and southernmost city in the world) to a 1-on-1 session to discuss your personal initiatives to promote a sustainable world with one of us. You can read the full descriptions of these incentives on the right (and contact us if you have any questions or comments).

| What will we be doing throughout the program / on the journey?

We will be taking part in Robert Swan’s “Leadership on the Edge” leadership, education, survival and sustainability program along with over 80 other participants ranging from business and social sector leaders to the most promising youth activists from around the world.

During the program, we will also be conducting 1-to-1 sessions with many attendees to personally coach and help them polish their innovative plans for sustainability initiatives they intend to implement in their home countries. Whether they plan to increase recycling or implement sustainable sourcing of materials, we are committed to ensuring that our fellow expedition members leave the ship with their very own “Results Plan” to help maximize their impact upon returning home.

Help us, help you, make an impact!

| What else can you do to help?

We appreciate your support and we encourage you to please help us in more ways than one.

  • Share this page with your colleagues, family, friends and people you know are passionate about sustainability, climate change and saving Antarctica

  • Share the link on your social media pages to help us spread the word

  • Please contact us if you have any suggestions on ways we can further get our message out there and gain support


| Where can you find more information about the expedition and Robert Swan?
  • The link to 2041's website: http://2041.com/ 
  • The link to Robert Swan and 2041 Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/2041robertswan
  • The link to Robert Swan's book "Antarctica 2041: My Quest to Save the Earth's Last Wilderness": http://www.amazon.com/Antarctica-2041-Quest-Earths-Wilderness/dp/0767931750

Thank you for your time, enthusiasm and generosity,

Kate, Galyna & Thalia

story:
Hello,

My name is Johnathan F Mendez. I am currently involved with a small local group of people who are teaching kids and adults alike about the importance of keeping our planet clean. Every week  10 students from different public schools are chosen for our project. What we do is basically get these uninformed children and bring them to places that need to be cleaned Beaches,Metropolitan areas,Business areas, Parks,fields etc. Basically anywhere that our group
might find things to clean we stop and get to work. Some children have a hard time understanding why we do what we do. Many kids never even comeback. But some of them do return and help us randomly. What we are trying to teach these children is basically to get things done sometimes you just have to do it yourself. Meaning do not toss that water bottle out of your car when your on the highway because it will probably be there years to come. So that is where The Quest Project comes in to play. These kids come from all walks of life from the least fortunate to the 16 year old the shows up to help us in his brand new BMW every week. Yes that is one of our best stories. We meet this young individual while cleaning up a river close to a main street. When all of a sudden a bottle comes flying on to a raft we were using. But then for some reason this young man comes walking up to us and says " hey sorry about that did i hit anybody?" I was in shock that he actually got out of his car. And i was pretty mad. Long story short he asked what the heck we were doing and i simply said cleaning up. Next thing out of his mouth was and those little kids over there there not supposed to be down here. I said to him yes they are part of our group. Basically this kid had all he ever wanted but no real friends. I noticed this and offered him a spot to help us clean. He actually accepted and started helping us right there. 8 months later we have became very good friends and he now helps us weekly even buys the kids lunch once in a while.

Sorry for the story but if you knew me personally you would understand it a little more.

These Funds i am asking for is to be able to purchase many things to keep on helping these kids out. I am young my self i recently finished College this year and see nothing better to do with my life right now but to help out these children. Not all of them show up with funds to buy a snack neither do i have transportation to pick them up all at the same time. Sometimes they meet up in groups and ride the public bus together to get to where we all meet. I would really like to be able to purchase a vehicle large enough for the kids and junk we acquire weekly. I am not sure if this website really works but you don't know until you actually try. There will be a YouTube page made soon showing what we do and how we do it so stay tuned and enjoy life that's all we really have.

 

i will figure out what type of perks i can give people as of right now i really dont know..

story:
Meet Fester


Due to a fire at our offices March 21st we are pausing this campaign. We are unable to access our server to reach the audience that would likely support building this new friend to assist communities fighting fracking harms. 

Stay tuned we'll be back when our offices are fully functional.  Thank you for your support.

The Center for Health, Environment & Justice has organized a campaign to prevent fracking harms, and we need a mascot to be the face of our campaign.

Why a dinosaur?

Because fracking is a dinosaur technology, both literally and figuratively. Fracking feeds our reliance on fossil fuels, and it accesses the hydrocarbons that are a result of the decay of plant and animal life from the time of the dinosaurs. We should move toward clean, green, alternative energy technologies instead of spending money on dinosaur technologies like fracking.


Fester the Frackasaurus will be an 15-foot high inflatable character, and will provide the large, visual representation of our campaign necessary to get people's attention and drive coverage of our work. Fester will provide people a focal point to raise awareness surrounding fracking harms. Fester will travel the country and be set up at rallies, information sessions and public events to generate conversation about fracking. He'll be hard to miss on roadsides across America!

Fester will be made out of nylon, a PVC-free synthetic material. He will have grey skin with black spots and will be wearing a yellow hard hat, orange vest, and construction boots, helping to represent the oil industry. He will be built by Gene Stilp, who previously constructed an existing inflatable mascot for us.

Why Fight Fracking?

Short for hydrofracturing, fracking is the process of injecting a mixture of water, sand and chemicals into deep, horizontal wells under very high pressure in order to fracture rock deep underground, releasing trapped hydrocarbons and bringing them to the surface. Fracking presents a wide range of human and environmental health issues, much of which revolves around contamination of drinking water and disposal of the toxic waste generated by fracking operations. Additionally, it reinforces our reliance on archaic fossil fuel technology.

Why We Need Your Help

We believe Fester will be a valuable resource in our campaign against fracking. We have successfully utilized Betty the Be Safe Ducky, our existing inflatable mascot, to generate interest and traffic as part of our precautionary action campaign on issues like PVC in children's toys and school supplies.



Inflatable mascots are a fun and very visible way to generate interest, and attract both children and adults to informational sessions at which they are deployed. They can be easily deflated, stored and transported to events, but once activated raise themselves and our campaigns to a whole new level of visibility.

We at CHEJ believe passionately that grassroots organizations play a key role in the environmental movement, and we work to organize, train and assist those on the ground with a variety of tools. Fester will be one item in our toolbox available to organizations and activists resisting fracking across America.

What We Need

We need $7,500 to construct Fester. $6,975 of this will go directly to Mr. Stilp for Fester's construction, while the remaining $525 will cover the shipping fees associated with moving Fester to community events and the costs of hosting this campaign.  Funds raised above $7,500 will be used to further reduce the shipping costs to groups who want to use Fester at their events.

*Remember that your donation is tax-deductible! You will receive more information and the necessary form after donating*

Fester will only enhance our campaign, and will give the American public and affected communities a lasting image associated with our efforts. Fester will be hard to forget when viewed in all his inflated glory, and that is exactly what we need. Those negatively affected by fracking can never forget what happened. Our national campaign strives to be as unforgettable in the minds of everyone: we have the power to stop dangerous fracking practices, and Fester the Frackasaurus will help ensure our message gets across, loud and clear.

Other Ways to Help

We understand that not everyone can make a monetary donation — but don't feel like you can't help! We need everyone to spread the word about our campaign to construct Fester, and our work across the nation to prevent fracking harms. Use the links on this page to share this campaign via Facebook and Twitter (don't forget to like our page while you're at it)! The more people that know about our work, the more money we can raise and the closer we are to achieving our goal of bringing Fester to life.

Who We Are

We are the Center for Health, Environment & Justice, working for more than three decades to organize grassroots movements that address environmental health and justice issues from the ground up. We work with the people and groups on the ground, dealing with issues from pollution to children's health to hydrofracturing operations — which is where you and Fester come in.

The more people that know about our work, the more money we can raise and the closer we are to achieving our goal of bringing Fester to life.
Who We Are

We work with the people and groups on the ground, dealing with issues from pollution to children's health to hydrofracturing operations — which is where you and Fester come in.

story:
Short Summary

www.fishreef.org 

The bottom line, is  the very best thing we can do to enhance and restore our marine ecosystem is to build well designed fish reefs.  Any envrionmental project in the ocean must have the support of the fishermen and environmental groups in order to work. The Fish Reef Project has broad based support.

 

Many natural reefs have been impacted from human use. By creating new ones, we can revive many areas of the seafloor that are currently unhealthy.

The Reefs will convert empty mud seafloor into thriving kelp and coral ecosystems. They will work by allowing  a fraction more plankton to find hard bottom to settle on, and then grow into greater plants and animals. 

The Fish Reef Project will create a series of five acre reefs in California and later in Hawaii. Each reef will quicly grow kelp and coral. The reefs are made from igloo shaped cement reef balls and they provide ample feeding and breeding ground  for fish, lobster, abalone, sea birds and marine mammals. The reefs unite the ocean community, they cost no tax payer dollars to maintain or enforce. We will place them on muddy seafloor that has likely already been compromised by human use over the years. The Fish Reef Project is cutting edge and the only operation of its kind in California and Hawaii.

 

Other benefits:

 

-help protect natural reefs

-restore and enhance fish stocks

-protect local and sustainable fisheries

-provide study ops

-create bridge between enviro and fishing community

-sequester Co2 from the atmosphere

-reduce local ocean acids levels

-help clean the water

-help ocean life thrive

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

The next  steps includes working towards creating a smaller scale pilot project and to continue with permitting for our first  five acre master project off Santa Barbara.

 

The pilot project will consist of about 40 reef balls placed near an outfall pipeline. We want test to see if the growth on the reef balls can reduce runoff pollution. We will also be able to further guage how quickly new marine life colonizes the reef balls.

 

You get a healthier ocean!

The Impact

 

There will be nine billion humans on the earth soon- we must find innovative ways to help the ocean be stronger and by using its own mechanisms to do so- reefs are one way off-setting human impact while helping ocean life thrive. The reefs will leave a long term positive life giving legacy for all who help to support them.

The Fish Reef Project has already placed two reef balls off Santa Barbara. We were able to see they kelp grow in just  four month and lots of fish came to make the reef balls thier new homes. We have managed to a create strong, highly qualified  working group and coalition of experts to carry us through the creation of the first five acre reef.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Send people to www.fishreef.org to donate and learn more- use indiegogo share tools
