story:
English | Français

English version

Short summary

Undae is an educational and environmental-friendly video game (only for Windows for the moment).

The main character (Undae) is a water drop with super powers used to clean the pollutants it will encounter during the game.

It takes place all along the water cycle: beginning in the ocean, then going to evaporation, condensation, precipitation, runoff and finally going back to the ocean.

In the 35 playable levels, you will find about 100 pollutants including:

  • Everyday life wastes such as fruit peeling, cardboard boxes, plastic bags
  • Heavy fuels, oils,
  • Various gas,
  • Particles,...

Each pollutant will have its card on the web site to learn more about it.

Cleaning will have a cost in terms of money (crystals) and will give money according to the correctness of the weapon used. When Undae is touched by a pollutant, it loses some life and dies when it's out of life.

There are 5 ways to deal with pollutants:

  • Burrow: representing the easiest way to get rid of pollution: burrowing it, throwing it away. Easy and cheap but limited and give few money.
  • Fire or Burn: representing incinerating. It works on a lot of pollutants but can create new (worst) pollutants: toxic gas and micro particles.
  • Filter: representing filtering or collecting the micro particles and oils.
  • Recycle: self-explanatory, it is used on pollutants whose components can be reused.
  • Separator: some pollutants cannot be processed without having been separated first.

And what more?

The game is based on an open homemade engine. That means that everybody can create the same kind of game with no special computer knowledge.

All the game is about some text files describing objects and behaviors (+ images and sound in common formats). It is quite simple to have a few interacting characters but it can become hard to build a full game. In order to make it the simplest as possible, we worked on a graphical editor to allow everybody to be able to create any simple game, and improve it to something sophisticated.

The editor even includes features that were not used in Undae such as 2D physics. It could be quite straight forward to clone a level in the "Angry Bird" style for example.

The editor will be free and we would want everyone to be able to create simple games and distribute it via our/their web site. This tool would be aimed at associations who want to have promotion product or any individual just for fun. Of course it is not intended to compete with the market leaders. 

As we're mostly working on the game, the editor is not completed yet. But it will be the next improvement, along with including Mac and Linux compatibility.

About us

We are Aurélie and David. We have been working on creating Undae for several years. We decided to start with it in 2008 because we were feeling helpless facing the news about increasing pollution, climate change and every environmental concerns.

Thinking about what we could do to help, we considered a game for children (and everybody else) to learn about pollution while playing a video game.

Unfortunately, we are now stuck because the game is nearly finished but we still need to spend time and money to complete it and the web site on one hand, and to promote it and to meet our clients on the other hand. 

Unlike "classic" games, we need to find the people concerned about environmental issues and also interested in video games. So a lot of time is required to find them and show them our project.

Our business model is based on collaboration with associations and NGOs. When someone buy the game, he chooses an association and 25% of the price will be donated to the association. It is mostly to help, and work with, smallest ones. Also, we think this model could be a way to help a lot of small associations and we would want to prove it can work so that other project creators could do the same.

What We Need & What You Get

To complete the game, we need to perform some tests to ensure it works on people's computers and do the corrections where needed. Also we must finish and populate the web site with game help. In the meantime, we need to go and show the game to the associations, during exhibition etc... It is a lot of time we need to spend and we're now out of money.

Helping us, you will get game product keys and you will be able to suggest associations to work with. Of course, best donators will be credited at the game ending and on the dedicated web site page.

If we can't reach the entire goal, we will still make the game available for download, but depending on the amount, we won't be able to correct installation/compatibility issues and develop the editor. Every product key will be delivered in any cases.

The Impact

Undae is an usual game, having hero, weapons and enemies. But, here, every action can cause ecological disaster if it is not the good one, and rewards the player otherwise. Even if the child doesn't think about what he is really doing, he will understand quickly which the worst pollutants are, which are easy to clean, and which ones are dangerous and hard to clean. 

The well documented website will contain the pollutants descriptions and the way to deal with them. This is where parents can be involved by helping children to understand why such action have such consequence.

During the development, we have been brought face to face with children and parents. Children are like hypnotized by the game, so hopefully it can have a positive impact on them. Parents, of course are often a bit reluctant to let children play with another computer game. But when we showed them the concept, and we explained that a lot of children will anyway play with video games, they often realize that it is even better to, at least, learn something while playing.

On the other-hand, we want to be part of a brand new business model where smallest associations can have the means to act, being supported by other small companies. It's a win-win process where associations are purchasing advisor with little investment (such as flyers/e-mails for their members), and the product creator can access their clients for a low price.

Doing that allows to avoid mainstream medias that could be biased and, in any cases, are far too expensive.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can't give money ? We mostly need reputation. We need it for that campaign of course, but we also need it for our project. Having a lot of visitors on the website will give us confidence. Like us on Facebook and share the website link with your friends. 

Also, talk about us, try the demo and send us your feedback (via the website).



Version française

Résumé du projet

Undae est un jeu vidéo éducatif et environnemental (seulement pour Windows pour l'instant).

Le personnage principal (Undae) est une goutte d'eau dotée de super pouvoirs lui permettant de nettoyer les polluants qu'elle rencontrera pendant le jeu.

Le jeu se déroule le long du cycle de l'eau: il commence dans l'océan puis se déroule lors de l'évaporation, la condensation, les précipitations, le ruissellement, et enfin revient dans l'océan.

Durant les 35 niveaux jouables, vous trouverez une centaine de polluants dont:

  • Les déchets de tous les jours comme pelures de fruits, emballages en carton, sacs en plastique,
  • Pétrole, huiles,...
  • Divers gaz,
  • Particules,...

Chaque polluant aura sa fiche sur le site web pour en savoir plus à son égard.

Nettoyer aura un coût en monnaie du jeu (cristaux) et récompensera en conséquence de l'arme utilisée. Quand Undae est touchée par un polluant, elle perd de la vie et meurt quand elle n'a plus de vie.

Il y a 5 moyens d'action pour traiter la pollution:

  • Enterrer: représente le moyen le plus facile de se débarrasser de la pollution: l'enterrer ou jeter les déchets. Facile et pas cher mais limité et n'apporte que peu de monnaie.
  • Brûler: représente l'incinération. Cela marche sur beaucoup de polluants mais peut causer de nouvelles pollutions encore pires: gaz toxiques et micro-particules.
  • Filtrer: représente la filtration et la collecte de micro-particules et d'huile.
  • Recycler: utilisé sur tous les polluants dont on peut récupérer les matières.
  • Trier: certains polluants ne peuvent pas être traités avant d'avoir été trié.

Et quoi d'autre?

Le jeu est construit sur un moteur fait maison. Cela signifie que tout le monde peut créer le même type de jeu sans connaissance particulière en informatique.

L'ensemble du jeu ne tourne qu'autour de quelques fichiers textes qui décrivent les objets et les comportements (+ les images et les sons dans des formats courants). Il est assez facile d'avoir quelques personnages en interaction mais il peut devenir plus difficile de construire un jeu complet. Dans le but de faciliter cette tâche, nous avons travaillé sur un éditeur graphique permettant à tout le monde de créer n'importe quel jeu basique et de l'améliorer en quelque chose de plus abouti.

L'éditeur inclue même quelques fonctions qui n'ont pas été utilisées dans Undae comme la gestion de la physique 2D. Cela permettrait de facilement cloner un niveau dans le style de "Angry Bird" par exemple.

L'éditeur sera gratuit et nous aimerions que tout le monde puisse créer des jeux simples et les distribuer via notre site ou le leur. Cet outil sera à destination des associations qui veulent un produit d'appel ou n'importe qui d'autre juste pour s'amuser. Bien sûr, il n'est pas question de concurrencer les gros acteurs du secteur. 

Comme nous travaillons en priorité sur le jeu, l'éditeur est loin d'être terminé. Mais il sera la prochaine amélioration avec l'ajout de la compatibilité pour Mac et Linux.

A propos de nous

Nous sommes Aurélie et David. Nous travaillons sur la création de Undae depuis plusieurs années. Nous avons décidé de nous lancer dans ce projet en 2008 car nous nous sentions impuissants face à tout ce qui concernait l'augmentation de la pollution, le changement climatique et toutes les questions environnementales.

En réfléchissant à ce que nous pourrions faire de notre côté, nous avons pensé à un jeu pour les enfants (et n'importe qui d'autre) leur permettant d'apprendre des choses sur la pollution tout en jouant à un jeu vidéo.

Malheureusement, nous sommes maintenant bloqués car le jeu est presque terminé mais nous avons encore besoin de  temps et d'argent pour aller au bout de sa réalisation et de celle du site web d'une part, et d'autre part d'en assurer la promotion et de rencontrer nos clients d'autre part. 

Contrairement aux jeux "classiques", nous avons besoin de trouver les gens à la fois intéressés aux questions environnementales et aux jeux vidéos. Nous avons donc besoin de beaucoup de temps pour les rechercher et leur présenter le projet.

Notre modèle économique est basé sur la collaboration avec les associations et les ONGs. Si quelqu'un achète un jeu, il peut choisir une association et 25% du prix est reversé à l'association. Ceci dans le but d'aider et de travailler avec les plus petites structures. De plus, nous pensons que ce modèle peut être un moyen d'aider un grand nombre de petites associations et nous aimerions prouver qu'il peut fonctionner. Ainsi d'autres porteurs de projets pourraient en faire autant.

Nos besoins et vos compensations

Pour terminer le jeu, nous avons besoin d'effectuer des tests pour s'assurer de son bon fonctionnement sur les ordinateurs de tout le monde, et faire les corrections adéquates le cas échéant. Nous avons aussi besoin de finir et remplir le site web avec notamment la documentation du jeu. Dans le même temps, il faut montrer le jeu aux associations, sur des salons/foires etc... Cela représente beaucoup de temps et nous sommes à court de crédits.

En nous aidant, vous obtiendrez des clés pour utiliser le jeu et la possibilité de proposer des associations partenaires avec lesquelles travailler. Et bien sûr, les meilleures donations seront créditées sur le site, voire dans le jeu.

Si nous n'atteignons pas le but, le jeu sera de toute façon mis à disposition en téléchargement, mais selon les cas, il nous sera impossible de corriger les problèmes de fonctionnement ou de développer l'éditeur. Dans tous les cas, les clés de produit seront délivrées.

L'impact

Undae est un jeu normal, avec un héro, des armes et des ennemis. Mais ici toutes les actions peuvent causer un désastre écologique en cas d'erreur et récompensent le joueur en cas de bon choix. Le joueur comprendra rapidement quels sont les polluants les plus dangereux, quels sont ceux les plus faciles à nettoyer et quels sont les plus toxiques et les plus difficiles à débarrasser, le tout sans même y penser.

La documentation du site contiendra la description des polluants et la manière de les traiter. Ainsi, les parents peuvent participer en aidant les enfants à comprendre pourquoi telle action a telle conséquence.

Pendant le développement, nous avons pu rencontrer les enfants et les parents. Les enfants sont captivés par le jeu, ce qui laisse entrevoir un impact positif sur eux. Les parents sont souvent récalcitrants à laisser leurs enfants jouer à encore un jeu vidéo. Mais après quelques explications sur le concept et sur le fait que les enfants sont de toute façon confrontés aux jeux vidéos, ils réalisent souvent qu'il vaut mieux que, au moins, ils apprennent quelque chose en jouant.

D'autre part, nous aimerions faire partie d'un nouveau type de modèle économique dans lequel les plus petites associations peuvent avoir les moyens d'agir en étant supportées par des petites entreprises. Dans cette vision tout le monde est gagnant: les associations étant prescriptrices à bas coût (prospectus ou messages électroniques à leurs membres), et les porteurs de projets peuvent toucher directement leurs clients pour des sommes raisonnables.

Ce faisant, nous évitons les médias principaux qui peuvent être biaisés et, quoiqu'il en soit, sont bien trop chers.

Les autres moyens de nous aider

Vous ne pouvez pas donner d'argent ? Avant tout, nous avons besoin d'être connus. Nous en avons besoin pour la campagne bien sûr, mais nous en avons aussi besoin pour le projet. Un grand nombre de visites sur notre site web nous donnera confiance. Faites "J'aime" sur Facebook et partagez le lien vers notre site avec vos amis. 

De plus, parlez de nous, essayez la démo et envoyez nous vos commentaires (via le site web).

story:
Take your home a step closer to sustainability and save money by building graywater reuse and rainwater catchment systems with our step-by-step video course.  Cut your water bill to zero while doing good for the planet. 

Take a moment to view the video above - it explains everything about this world-changing project.  We're creating an instructional step-by-step video manual on how to build your own rainwater catchment and graywater reuse systems.  This will be a complete guide to eliminating your water bill by meeting the majority of your annual water needs by capturing the water from your roof and then designing water reuse cycles through graywater filtration.   

Support this world-changing campaign!

To cover our production and marketing costs, we're offering you the opportunity to get the e-book and the DVD set at a huge discount. Pre-order the DVD set for just $125 (regular rate will be $195) or  get the 4-DVD Rainwater Catchment and Greywater Reuse set plus the full Permaculture Design Course DVD set (18 DVDs) for just $325 total. 

To make your rewards even better, if you pre-order the DVD set through this campaign, we will also include the Permaculture Fundamentals e-Book and cover the cost of shipping.  That's up to $245 in savings to thank you for supporting this world-changing campaign! 

What's the big deal about water catchment?

The combination of harvesting rain combined with graywater reuse can literally save the world while definitely saving you money.   Did you know that reusing greywater can save well over 50% of the average American family’s household water usage -- and that's without harvesting rainwater? This is an astounding figure when we consider how vital water is to our planet’s health and well-being. We can cut our water usage in half by designing smart water systems, and let the planet keep more clean water to maintain its ecosystems.  

Water reuse fundamentals

Household wastewater is classified into two groups - greywater and blackwater. Greywater refers to the wastewater from your shower, laundry machines, and bathroom sinks. It contains bacteria, fiber particles, and dead skin cells, which is very nourishing for your garden plants, and doesn’t pose a huge health risk.  Blackwater refers to the wastewater from your toilet and kitchen sink, because it is loaded with feces and grease. It can contain animal parasites and excess nitrogen that will pollute the environment.  Greywater can be fed directly to your garden plants, whereas blackwater needs deeper filtration to be safe for returning to the ecosystem.

Harvesting rainwater off of your roof can fulfill one-third of your household water needs each year. Add that to a greywater system that reuses your household water to water your garden and lawn, and you’ve basically met close to two-thirds of your household water needs. How’s that for saving money on water?

About the Regenerative Leadership Institute

We are an eight-year old sustainable living and permaculture design school.  We brought you the world's first completely free online permaculture course, a project that completely redefined the way permaculture education is done. We change people's lives by fundamentally reconnecting with nature and themselves, remembering our collective heritage and creating a beautiful, thriving future.  

Our instructors are some of the most well-known leaders of the sustainability movement.  Here is what one of our program participants said about the extraordinary caliber of instruction she received:

"Never in my life have I been able to interact with such a group of instructors who are not only passionate about what they are doing but also about sharing it with us and empowering us to act upon our values and visions.  I am deeply grateful for this experience, and I do feel like it has changed my life for the better.

The program was intense, and challenging, but also rewarding. I can't really say enough good things about it. I will never be able to look at the world through the same lens again, and for that I am grateful. " -Sarah T.

We are rated A+ by the Better Business Bureau and have over a hundred-fifty testimonials posted on our website.   Our track record of extraordinary innovation and delivery of world-changing projects speaks for itself.  

Support this world-changing campaign

Get your DVD set today, but more importantly please share the link with your friends on Facebook and Twitter.  Join us and let's change the world!

Take a moment to view the video above - it explains everything about this world-changing project.  We're creating an instructional step-by-step video manual on how to build your own rainwater catchment and graywater reuse systems.  This will be a complete guide to eliminating your water bill by meeting the majority of your annual water needs by capturing the water from your roof and then designing water reuse cycles through graywater filtration.   
Support this world-changing campaign!
To cover our production and marketing costs, we're offering you the opportunity to get the e-book and the DVD set at a huge discount. Pre-order the DVD set for just $125 (regular rate will be $195) or  get the 4-DVD Rainwater Catchment and Greywater Reuse set plus the full Permaculture Design Course DVD set (18 DVDs) for just $325 total.  To make your rewards even better, if you pre-order the DVD set through this campaign, we will also include the Permaculture Fundamentals e-Book and cover the cost of shipping.  That's up to $245 in savings to thank you for supporting this world-changing campaign!

story:
WE CAN HELP POLAR BEARS


Did you know that most of the 1000/year hunt is legal and condoned by those supposedly responsible for keeping polar bears safe in the face of climate change and an uncertain future? And that the community of stakeholders is covering up the facts, disguising the numbers, manipulating the picture, in order to safeguard commercial interests rather than polar bears?

Would you like to do something to change this?

I have written a book documenting the reality of failed polar bear conservation. The book will be published late April 2015. The more help I get with the financing, the wider the message can get out. This will hopefully be the beginning of a worldwide campaign to save polar bears. 

In this impassioned book Morten raises very important, provocative questions that are not being addressed by the international environmental groups. Questions we must pay attention to lest the legacy of our generation be one of being forewarned without acting in the face of species extinction.
Art Wolfe, Award-winning conservation photographer


What’s the problem?

Polar bears are threatened from many sides. Most people think that the only really big problem they face are the effects of climate change. This myth is being perpetuated by almost all the persons and institutions who have a say in polar bear matters. But in the meantime, a completely unsustainable and anachronistic hunting regime is being allowed to continue. Polar bears are indeed facing extinction. But it is not because of global warming alone - it is because that while global warming continues, we are allowing them to be shot out! 

It is quite simple: The numbers do not add up. There are possibly fewer than 20.000 polar bears in the world today, their recruitment rate is almost certainly less than 4% per year, and yet we purposefully shoot about 5% of them per year. Polar bears are knowingly and systematically being extirpated.

A convergence of interests leads to this being condoned by the majority of the polar bear nations, Inuit leaders, elite scientists, polar bear managers, and our largest conservation NGOs. The precautionary principle is not applied to polar bear management, and there is no arms-length principle between hunters, managers, scientists and politicians. Conservation efforts are symbolic at best and totally insufficient.

Even without the hunt, the species’ survival chances in the wild are on thin ice. Every individual living polar bear increases the survival chances of the species. Every dead polar bear is worth nothing.



By supporting the production and distribution of my book, you will be supporting efforts to make a change. To expose the current failed management scenario and raise an appeal for those in charge to change the policies. If the truth is not told, and if it is not known by the public, the polar bears will slowly but surely disappear. If together we demand action and change, we can still save them.


What I Need & What You Get

Your help in getting this book produced and distributed as widely as possible is very important. The book has been written, it has been designed, it is being printed. It will also be made available as an e-book.

The difference lies in the distribution. The budget of this campaign is based on getting the first 1000 copies out to media and other relevant parties. It will be sent initially to major news outlets in all of the Arctic nations and a few other large nations. It will also be sent to the main offices of major environmental NGOs such as WWF, Greenpeace, IFAW, Traffic, IUCN, CAFF and others. The book is expected to be available internationally to the general public directly from the author (ursmar2015@gmail.com), and via Nozomojo.com, the publisher (spitsbergen-svalbard.com), NHBS.com, Amazon.com, Amazon.co.uk and iTunes.com - and possibly other outlets.

To ensure that at least the first 1000 copies reach their audience, a necessary sum of US$ 16.500,- has been calculated. 

The breakdown is expected to be approximately:

Book design: US$ 5.000,-
Book printing (1000 copies): US$  5.000,-
Postage (500 copies worldwide): US$  5.000,-
Perks: US$ 1.000,-
Postage perks: US$  500,-
Total: US$ 16.500,-

The stretch-goals of this campaign are initially to simply print more books. Should the goal be surpassed, perhaps even by several 100%, the book will be printed in more copies, and efforts will be made to reach an even wider audience.

Potential excess funds obtained beyond those needed for world-wide distribution of the book will be directed towards true polar bear conservation efforts that are consistent with the recommendations contained in the last chapter of the book.


Contributions and perks

The greatest perk for anyone who contributes any amount is the knowledge and assurance that you will be contributing to informing the world about the real dangers that polar bears are facing. And informing at the same time about possible solutions to save the polar bears from extinction in the wild.

Also: Even if you cannot, or you decide not to, contribute financially to this project, there is so much else you can do. Sharing this campaign link with others is one. Accessing and reading the book, once it is available, is another. Joining into the public debate is valuable too. Questioning those authorities, institutions and persons who could be but are not acting to save polar bears is the next.

If you think that "little you" won’t be able to make a difference in a big world – consider the effects that just one little mosquito has in any bedroom, once the lights are out!

All contributions up to US$ 20,- will be rewarded with a postcard of one of the cutest photographs in the book (below).

All other contributions and their perks are described next to this column.


A bit more about the book

This book explores the minefields between the many lobby groups, from Inuit hunters to conservation institutions to governments, and it explores the failures to adhere to international agreements and conventions. This book is an eye-opener and should kick off extensive debates. 
Dr. Thor S. Larsen, professor emeritus, member of the IUCN Polar Bear Specialist Group 1968-85


"Polar Bears on the Edge" reveals several interesting and worrying realities that most people do not know about.

In the first chapter of the book, I reach the conclusion that polar bears were previously more numerous than is generally described, putting the current demise of the species into an even darker perspective than that usually envisioned. I also document that the current polar bear management community is rather systematically covering up the protection and conservation failures by manipulation the numbers, both the historical ones and the current ones.


An example spread from the book


In the second chapter, the direct human destruction by shooting every year of about 1000 polar bears is put into perspective. Alongside all the other human-caused stress to polar bears, this hunting scenario is documented here to be the one major threat to polar bears that could immediately be changed if there was enough will to do so.

In the third chapter of the book, the claimed successful conservation and management of polar bears is pulled apart, country by country and sub-population by sub-population, to reach the clear but sad conclusion that polar bear conservation is non-existent – the bears are being hunted out of existence.

In the fourth chapter of the book, the commercialization of polar bears, how they have been and are being reduced to commodities, to money-makers, to rugs – is described, but also how this commercialization of the species is corrupting even those who do not stand to gain directly from the hunting and trading. The chapter describes the scandal that allows the continuation of international trading in polar bear body parts, that allows the continuation of trophy hunting, and that allows the continuation of rampant poaching in some areas.

The book’s fifth chapter is an analyses of the complexities and paradoxes of modern Inuit identity – and how this is being used and abused by polar bear stakeholders for individual gain and political status quo, instead of changing our policies to safeguard the bears.


Another couple of the book's  pages


After so many rather depressing and negative conclusions, the final chapter of the books concludes what the actual state of polar bear management is on a worldwide scale, but also finds that there are actually ways out of this situation. A long string of very clear and precise recommendations for immediate action are listed at the end, giving everyone from hunters to politicians, managers to scientists, as well as any concerned citizen anywhere, an opportunity to decide, act - and make a difference.


Who am I?

I have been travelling since childhood and have seen many places – but I have been returning to the Arctic yearly for almost two decades. I have worked in small-ship expedition cruise tourism, as guide, lecturer, Zodiac (small inflatable boat) driver, and expedition leader. I have focused my attention on the biological, ecological and environmental aspects of the area, studying the changes occurring, and educating about them. I have seen local changes happening in my lifetime, changes in sea-ice quality, sea-ice cover and glacier cover, species diversity and abundance, and changes in human activity. I have been involved in tourism management, guide management, impact management and species data collection. I have met and made friends with scientists, managers, politicians, operators, guides, local inhabitants, hunters, consumers, and tourists – and I have had many discussions with them about these matters. I am committed to continue doing my part to ensure a viable future for polar bears. Writing this book is not the end, but rather the beginning.

story:
Homa Therapy Foundation, a non-profit organisation, is building an environmental, educational healing centre - Centre of Light. It is being  built on the grounds of our Ecovillage Bhrugu Aranya, where education is given about how to create a sustainable future for our planet through direct action.

We envision Centre of Light manifesting into a place where healing, organic farming and creative expression through arts and music will find their venue. And the influx of others of like mind and heart will inspire, uplift and unify all who come.

  • Learning ancient Ayurvedic techniques to bring nature back to balance and heal the atmosphere
  • Practicing Yoga and meditation

    • Practicing creative arts to heal mind body spirit

    • Learning about how to form and live in small communities
    • Using folk medicine, wild and organically grown herbs for healing and wellness 

    • Implementing green architecture and building with sustainable materials

    • Organic food growing, organic beekeeping and sustainable agriculture

    • Organic vegetarian cooking for wellness and rejuvenation

    Over the years, we have been able to educate and share our collective skills and environmental healing methods with literally thousands of people. Now has come the time for major expansion in order to accommodate the increasing numbers who wish to learn and experience life at our Ecovillage.


    Through our continued practice of ancient Ayurvedic science over the past 20 years, we provide the living proof that we can offer workable solutions which help correct, heal, nourish, and restore balance to whole eco-systems.

    So far we have completed the first phase of the building, which include foundations and basement. Now we are crowdfunding the next stage of this amazing project. We need to raise a total of $108,000 USD.

    Once this next phase is finished, we will be able to offer clay building workshops, invite volunteers to learn and work with sustainable building techniques, and help complete the structure of our Centre.

    Any additional funds raised will go into the next phases of building.

    Ecovillage Bhrugu Aranya is a blossoming international Homa organic farm community in Poland. At present, 14 adults and 4 children reside here. Residents range in age from 8 to 91, and are an eclectic group of artists, healers, writers, filmmakers, musicians, therapists, gardeners, teachers and herbalists. We are a collection of international pioneers who want to heal the planet from the grass roots up!

    Members of Ecovillage Bhrugu Aranya

    Using ancient Vedic farming practices and non-violence to all living things, we try to tread lightly on the Earth and help to create an atmosphere of healing. Our mission is to heal the atmosphere and treat Mother Nature with the respect she deserves. This is a place where ecology meets spirituality.

    To find out more about us, check out this video:


    Our Ecovillage with concentric circle mandala gardens as seen from above

    Gai's Garden Produce and friends!

    Please donate in whatever way you can. You can choose from our amazing Perks selection or just make a donation of your choice. 

    If you are from the US and would like a tax deduction, please contact us directly through one of our friendly administrators!

    We welcome people to bring their skills to our community too! Should you wish to volunteer your time or skill sets you can find out how by visiting our website, here: 

    http://homatherapypoland.org/en/about-us-en/volunteer


    From the humble beginnings of two people (Jarek and Parvati) Bhrugu Aranya has grown into a wonderful healing oasis. In the beginning, there was only an old log cabin without electricity and running water, and a dilapidated barn inside a magical ancient looking apple orchard. There was barely a road leading up the mountain to the secluded location overlooking the valley below.  

    Today, Ecovillage Bhrugu Aranya is a thriving community of 14 adults and 4 children, a hoard of happy animals including cows, cats, ducks, dogs, horses, bees. We are dedicated to the practice of non-violence by treating our animals with love and respect, being vegetarian, and teaching future generations about living harmoniously with nature.
    We grow an abundance of organic veggies and fruits which we share amongst ourselves and preserve for the winter months.
    We offer free teachings on Homa Therapy & Homa organic farming all year round.

    Natural log cabins and strawbale house


    Celebrating Helen's 91st birthday!

    What we've done already

    • Building Project Documentation and Permission:
    • Excavation work
    • Foundations and Basement 
    • Foundations – form and concrete work 
    • Basement walls and floor slabs - ongoing
    • Insulation
    • Drainage

    What we need to do to complete the next stage of building

    • Skeletal Structure 
    • Roof Construction 
    • Roof Tiles
    • Drain and Water Pipes

    If we can manage to raise the funds, we can complete the structure and the roof so we can start our workshops on building straw, wood chip and clay walls. These walls will incorporate all natural materials, and be a great opportunity for many people to learn practical skills in this ecological building technique.

There was barely a road leading up the mountain to the secluded location overlooking the valley below.  

Today, Ecovillage Bhrugu Aranya is a thriving community of 14 adults and 4 children, a hoard of happy animals including cows, cats, ducks, dogs, horses, bees. We are dedicated to the practice of non-violence by treating our animals with love and respect, being vegetarian, and teaching future generations about living harmoniously with nature.We grow an abundance of organic veggies and fruits which we share amongst ourselves and preserve for the winter months. We offer free teachings on Homa Therapy & Homa organic farming all year round.



Natural log cabins and strawbale house





Celebrating Helen's 91st birthday!








What we've done already



Building Project Documentation and Permission:

Excavation work


Foundations and Basement 


Foundations – form and concrete work 


Basement walls and floor slabs - ongoing


Insulation


Drainage


What we need to do to complete the next stage of building


Skeletal Structure 


Roof Construction 


Roof Tiles


Drain and Water Pipes


If we can manage to raise the funds, we can complete the structure and the roof so we can start our workshops on building straw, wood chip and clay walls. These walls will incorporate all natural materials, and be a great opportunity for many people to learn practical skills in this ecological building technique.

story:
Short Summary

Help stop a company from Houston, Texas from drilling a yard-wide fracked methane pipeline under the iconic Suwannee River and through the Springs Heartland of Florida, risking our drinking water in the Floridan Aquifer, economy, and property rights.

We have an attorney! And now we need to pay for him.


WWALS is in legal proceedings to stop the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FL-DEP) from issuing a permit for Sabal Trail to drill under the Suwannee and other rivers and wetlands.

When: 10 AM Monday 19 October 2015

Where: Hamilton County Board of Commissioners Chambers, 207 NE First Street, Jasper, Florida 32052

Spectra Energy wants to gouge its Sabal Trail pipeline from Alabama, under the Chattahoochee, Flint, Ochlockonee, and Withlacoochee Rivers in Georgia, then under the Suwannee, Santa Fe, and Withlacoochee (south) Rivers to Orlando. FPL claims the fracked methane is for power plants south of Orlando and at Duke Energy's Crystal River plant. But Sabal Trail would connect to another pipeline to Martin County, where there are four already-authorized liquid natural gas export operations.

This is David vs. Goliath: tiny all-volunteer WWALS versus a $3 billion pipeline project. We will aim as high as needed, deposing any corporate or government officials relevant to the case. Attorneys, expert witnesses, depositions, etc. cost money, so we turn to you, the citizens of Florida, Georgia, Alabama, the U.S., and the world. Stop one new pipeline and help stop them all!

What We Need & What You Get

The funds will go to attorneys and expert witnesses, plus court recorders, process servers, and other legal expenses.

The only chance to win is to try. We have beaten the odds already by getting a hearing. Please help us see it through.

What you get is the opportunity to add your support to this pipeline opposition and to stand up for safeguarding our rivers and water supply. If we win, you win. Thank you for any small or large donation! Everything helps!

Any funds raised beyond those used for this case will go to support other WWALS conservation projects, including other methods of opposing this unnecessary, destructive, and hazardous pipeline.

Please help us to say No to the pipeline and Yes to solar power for the Sunshine State!

What is at Stake?

Property rights, environment, and economy, are all threatened by an unnecessary pipeline for the profit of a few corporate executives and investors.

Property rights:

  • of those from whom Sabal Trail would take an hundred-foot wide easement;
  • of anyone within the more than 1,000-foot blast radius;
  • of anyone whose well might get polluted or whose land might develop a sinkhole due to pipeline drilling;
  • of taxpayers who would end up paying for leaks, sinkholes, or explosions.
 

Environment: the pipeline would go right through the most vulnerable area of the fragile karst limestone which houses our springs and the Floridan Aquifer, the source of a large part of our drinking water. Plus threats to wildlife, to native plants, and of introduction of invasive species.

Economy: tourism is one of Florida's major industries, and everything from agriculture to drinking water depends on the Floridan Aquifer; all threatened by this pipeline.

WWALS petitioned FL-DEP to deny that permit, and has been granted an administrative hearing to argue many of these points.

Why Florida? Why DEP?

While Sabal Trail has applied to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) for a permit for this interstate pipeline, FERC required Sabal Trail to get state permits such as this one from FL-DEP.

So it appears that without that DEP permit, there can be no pipeline.

According to DEP, without resolution of these proceedings, there can be no permit.

Low-lying Florida is the state with the most at risk from climate change, due to sea level rise, methane is 25 times worse than carbon dioxide as a greenhouse gas according to the EPA, and fracking, pipelines, and LNG export all leak methane.

As the Sierra Club chapters of Alabama, Georgia, and Florida said back in March 2014, Florida doesn't need to become even more dependent on gas pipelines. The Sunshine State should go directly to solar power, which is faster, cheaper, and far cleaner and safer than any pipeline.

Who is WWALS?

WWALS Watershed Coalition, Inc., a Waterkeeper® Affiliate, is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation that advocates for conservation and stewardship of the Withlacoochee, Willacoochee, Alapaha, Little, and Upper Suwannee River watersheds in south Georgia and north Florida through awareness, environmental monitoring, and citizen activities.

WWALS represents not only its own members, but also the members of the public in the areas where the pipeline is to be drilled, who will derive no benefit from the pipeline whatsoever, but will bear the burden of damage to the waterways and natural environment, degradation of springs and water quality, adverse effects on wildlife, and the risks of explosions.

WWALS has been fighting this pipeline since at least November 2013, and has been an intervenor on the FERC docket since December 2014.

Two WWALS members were instrumental in getting Sabal Trail to move off of the Withlacoochee (north) River in Florida.

Now WWALS wants Sabal Trail off the Suwannee River, out of Florida, and cancelled.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? There are other ways you can help.

First, if you are a directly-affected landowner, or have experience with pipeline safety, geology, or other related topics, contact us about testifying.

Second, help us share our Indiegogo campaign! On facebook, twitter, instagram, google plus, email lists: send it to folks who would be interested.

Third, write letters to the editor, call in to radio talk shows, ask to be a talk show guest, or to get interviewed. Or send them to us.

Fourth, oppose Sabal Trail through one of many other efforts; see WWALS Issues page about Sabal Trail pipeline.

Help stop one pipeline; help stop them all: fracking, new pipelines, and LNG export!

You can help the sun rise on solar and wind power for Florida, the southeast, and the world!

On facebook, twitter, instagram, google plus, email lists: send it to folks who would be interested.Third, write letters to the editor, call in to radio talk shows, ask to be a talk show guest, or to get interviewed. Or send them to us.Fourth, oppose Sabal Trail through one of many other efforts; see WWALS Issues page about Sabal Trail pipeline.Help stop one pipeline; help stop them all: fracking, new pipelines, and LNG export!You can help the sun rise on solar and wind power for Florida, the southeast, and the world!

story:
Short Summary: "Click"

“Click.”  It’s the sound of fitting together two jagged pieces of a delicate, crystalline cave formation known as gypsum.  New Mexico natives Jim Werker and Val Hildreth-Werker volunteer in Mammoth Cave National Park’s Crystal Cave, diligently searching for that “click”, repairing damage that occurred in 1995 when three vandals broke formations along a mile of passageway.  

The Werkers are seasoned cave restorers; the couple literally wrote the book on cave restoration – CaveConservation and Restoration describes innovative techniques to repair damaged formations.  They “click” with this job!

The restoration process is intricate and time consuming.  Gypsum is extremely brittle and heavy, making it difficult to handle.  The Werkers and their team often put in 8 to 10-hour days as volunteers. They must find the matching pieces, glue them back together, and attach the finished product to the wall using stainless steel rods.

“The big thing is figuring out how to rig it so it will stay in place,” said Jim. “We use a lot of bungee cords and small clamps.  It takes several days for the glue to set.” Once the epoxy is dry it can withstand 50,000 pounds per square inch of pressure. Afterwards the seams and bolts are undetectable. The completed walls are even dusted with a loose powdering of cave dirt so that the colors match.

Legendary cave explorer Floyd Collins discovered Crystal Cave in 1917.  In January of 1925 he brought attention to the cave region when he became trapped in Sand Cave and died there. Restoring the splendor of Crystal Cave is no walk in the park.

"Crystal Cave has long been famous for its beautiful gypsum crusts and flowers," said Mammoth Cave Superintendent Sarah Craighead.  "Restoring Crystal Cave is incredibly important to the park. We truly could not do this without a team of skilled volunteers. "

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Werkers volunteer their time to repair damage to Crystal Cave, and have done so on more than ten previous restoration efforts. The Friends of Mammoth Cave are raising money to cover their costs for a restoration session in October, 2015.

  • $2,500 for supplies ($500), groceries ($500), camp-style lodging ($700), and travel ($800), for 6 volunteers for 12 days 

  • For Donors and Friends at the $500 level and above, we will offer a “See the Work” Trip into an area of the cave that is closed to the public. Trip to be scheduled during the week of October 12-18, 2015.
  • For Donors and Friends at the $200 level and above, we will offer a complimentary DVD of "Mammoth Cave: A Way to Wonder," an Emmy award-winning documentary.
  • Every donor will receive our thanks and a shout-out on social media.
  • If we don't reach the entire goal, any funds raised will go toward priority costs, beginning with supplies.

The Impact

This campaign will give conservation-minded donors an opportunity to observe delicate cave conservation work in progress.

  • Vandalism of our unique natural resources is an unfortunate fact. Jim and Val Werker have developed a system to restore damaged gypsum cave walls.
  • The Werkers have generously contributed their time to restore a spectacular cave passage, but it is a slow and pain-staking process, requiring several volunteers, and numerous work sessions over many years.
  • The Friends of Mammoth Cave support conservation initiatives, along with education and recreation.
  • We are so proud of this important restoration project; we hope to share the process with like-minded cave enthusiasts!

Risks & Challenges

The restoration work can be both pain-staking and back-breaking. Several more work sessions may be required to complete the restoration of Crystal Cave. To overcome these challenges:

  • The Werkers have the skill and determination to continue to the work. 
  • The Friends of Mammoth Cave are committed to supporting this and other conservation efforts at Mammoth Cave National Park.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to contribute, there are other ways you can help!

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Help to stop vandalism by reporting suspicious activity on public lands. 
  • Enjoy your public lands!

Thank you for your time and your consideration!

story:
SUSTAINABLE GIVING

Soap & Water's goal is to launch a responsibly manufactured "green" personal care brand with 100% of after-tax profits donated to EarthEcho International and Water.org.

EarthEcho International's mission is to empower youth to take action that restores and protects our water planet. 

Water.org's mission is to provide safe water and the dignity of a toilet for all.


Soap & Water Personal Care Collection

Body Scrub, Body Butter, Hand Soap, All Over Lotion, Shower Cream, Bath & Body Oil, Hand Cream, and Facial Cleanser.

Our products are developed and manufactured with the environment and sustainability as a priority. The formulations contain essential oils and organic and/or naturally derived ingredients. Free from Phthalates, Sulfate and Paraben. No animal testing. 

Our personal care collection is offered in the four everyday fragrances; Lavender & Mint, Oatmeal & Honey, White Tea & Verbena, and Citrus & Sage.


Soap & Water Soap Collection

Offered in four everyday fragrances and four additional aromatherapy fragrances; Rose Petals & Bergamot, Apricot & Vanilla, Cypress & Cedar, and Vetiver & Cardamom. The soap case is made of 100% recyclable pressed pulp.

 

Soap & Water Fragrance Collection

Plant wax Scented Candle, Body Mist, Room Spray, and Roll-on Perfume. Offered in four everyday fragrances.


Soap & Water "Waterless" Collection

Sensual Solid Perfume, Moisturizing Lotion Stick and Hydrating Lip & Face Balm, all developed to aid in water conservation.  The "Waterless Collection" uses little or no water in the manufacturing process or in use by the consumer.  Truly cutting edge formulations.


SOAP & WATER COMMUNITY

"We are not only about creating beautiful earth-friendly products but about creating a community that cares about our planet and its people."

 

Our Sustainable Product Rating System:


Everyone Can Make A Difference! Be a part of our Clean Water Community!

Hi, Jill Belasco here.....long time manufacturer of all things fragrant and beautiful and activist for clean water for all!  I have been a "water" person for a few years and wanted to find a way to fund, on an ongoing basis, organizations that are successful at environmental programs in the US and globally.  It only made sense to find a way to do that using the expertise I already have and so, last year, Soap & Water was born.  A socially-conscious and environmentally responsible body and bath brand that will help to change the world. (Did I mention that the products are beautiful and good for you?)

Because we have an on-going business in the same category, R & D, product development, sales, back office and manufacturing can all be handled by our current infrastructure.  What we don't have is a budget for marketing and advertising.  We have strong retail partners that are ready to jump on board with us but we need to have a comprehensive marketing strategy to launch the product.  We are looking for $250,000 to help us launch the product in Fall of 2014.  We will use any money raised in the campaign solely for the promotion of Soap & Water.

Contributors to our campaign will get wonderful treats for helping us (we do make some amazing products) but the best reward is that you will help us launch an environmentally, socially conscious brand of beautiful personal care products that will, in turn, fund successful programs that help provide clean water and access to sanitation throughout the world.  We are very careful when we choose the organizations and programs we support and are pleased to partner with EarthEcho International and Water.org. 100% of the after-tax profits from Soap & Water will go to organizations like these. 

My team and I have been in this business since 1994 - and we love it.  We've been honored by our industry on multiple occasions for product excellence and marketing success.  We know how to make beautiful, commercially successful products.  So, you can imagine how excited we are to be working on something that can change the world!  It always feels good to do good - and now you can feel good, too.

We so appreciate your help - even if financial support isn't possible.  Please tell your friends and family about us.  We are going to give it our all - it is so important to us to use our organization and our skills to help others. (And it says I am supposed to remind you to use the Indiegogo share tools). 

Thank you so much!


FINANCIAL MILESTONES:

$10,000 - On-line marketing program

$50,000 - On-line and some regional marketing programs

$100,000 - Limited National marketing program

$250,000 - Global Marketing Campaign

story:
When maintaining 100 hectares of unspoiled countryside, tree poaching is not the first problem one considers.  But in Alentejo, Portugal’s premier wine region, cork oaks are in high demand despite their protected status.  Gephel Ling’s land has been hard hit by illegal tree cutting, with whole hillsides denuded of these small native oaks, some of the only trees hardy enough to withstand the dry, endlessly sunny summers.  It’s heartbreaking to see the freshly cut stumps shining among the lavender.

Gephel Ling is now inhabited full time and the tree cutting has stopped, but the damage must be repaired.  We have started this campaign not only to replace the lost trees but to plant more than were stolen, including fruit trees in order to make the retreat centre more self sufficient.  Soil erosion is a serious problem in this region because of the arid summers, and deforestation only makes it worse.  Additionally, hunting of the native boar and other wildlife is a popular local pastime, and as a Buddhist centre is it our aspiration to create a sanctuary for all living things.  Reforesting our land will help to create that haven.

In order to plant these trees, we need your help.  Every Euro donated will go directly to purchasing trees for planting, with the work being done by volunteers.  This is an ongoing project, and even if we do not reach our goal every month, we can still plant some trees.  Any amount you can afford to give will be greatly appreciated, and if you cannot contribute financially please help by sharing our campaign on Facebook.

Muito Obrigado, from Southern Portugal!

****

Thubten Phuntsog Gephel Ling is a new and growing retreat centre located on 100 hectares (250 acres) in the Alentejo region of Southern Portugal.  It is owned and operated by the Centro de Estudos Tibetanos (CET), Pendê Ling, of the Nyingma school of Tibetan Buddhism in Estoril, Lisbon, under the auspices of Lama Gyurme and Lama Chökyi Dorje.  Gephel Ling currently offers retreat facilities for individuals and groups, and hopes to soon be able to host meditation and other courses, rejuvenating holiday stays, and to offer accommodation including camping, bunkhouses, and rooms in the guesthouse. 

Any profit from these activities will go towards CET’s ambitious projects, including:

-  Community works in Portugal and abroad

-  Raising the profile of Buddhism in Portugal

-  Making the Buddha’s teachings more available to people in Europe

-  Inviting masters from Tibet, India, Nepal, Europe, the US, and beyond

-  Gephel Ling’s maintenance in improving the sustainability of the largest (area-wise) Buddhist centre in Europe

While much work has already been done to realise these goals, there remains a great deal of loving labour to do before these things come to pass.  Please help us achieve the ultimate aim of making this world a more peaceful and compassionate place.  Please visit the Centro de Estudos Tibetanos website for more information about Gephel Ling, our current and future projects, Buddhism, and CET itself.

Thank you for your generosity!

http://www.gephelling.org/

http://www.centroestudostibetanos.org/
story_txt:
When maintaining 100 hectares of
unspoiled countryside, tree poaching is not the first problem one
considers.  But in Alentejo, Portugal’s premier wine region, cork oaks are
in high demand despite their protected status.  Gephel Ling’s land has
been hard hit by illegal tree cutting, with whole hillsides denuded of these
small native oaks, some of the only trees hardy enough to withstand the dry,
endlessly sunny summers.  It’s heartbreaking to see the freshly cut stumps
shining among the lavender.Gephel Ling is now inhabited
full time and the tree cutting has stopped, but the damage must be
repaired.  We have started this campaign not only to replace the lost
trees but to plant more than were stolen, including fruit trees in order to
make the retreat centre more self sufficient.  Soil erosion is a serious
problem in this region because of the arid summers, and deforestation only
makes it worse.  Additionally, hunting of the native boar and other
wildlife is a popular local pastime, and as a Buddhist centre is it our
aspiration to create a sanctuary for all living things.  Reforesting our
land will help to create that haven.In order to plant these trees,
we need your help.  Every Euro donated will go directly to purchasing
trees for planting, with the work being done by volunteers.  This is an
ongoing project, and even if we do not reach our goal every month, we can still
plant some trees.  Any amount you can afford to give will be greatly
appreciated, and if you cannot contribute financially please help by sharing
our campaign on Facebook.
Muito Obrigado, from Southern Portugal!****
Thubten Phuntsog Gephel Ling is
a new and growing retreat centre located on 100 hectares (250 acres) in the
Alentejo region of Southern Portugal.  It is owned and operated by the
Centro de Estudos Tibetanos (CET), Pendê Ling, of
the Nyingma school of Tibetan Buddhism in Estoril, Lisbon, under the auspices
of Lama Gyurme and Lama Chökyi Dorje.  Gephel Ling currently offers
retreat facilities for individuals and groups, and hopes to soon be able to
host meditation and other courses, rejuvenating holiday stays, and to offer
accommodation including camping, bunkhouses, and rooms in the guesthouse.  Any profit from these activities will go towards CET’s ambitious projects,
including: 

-  Community works in
Portugal and abroad
-  Raising the profile of
Buddhism in Portugal 
-  Making the Buddha’s
teachings more available to people in Europe
-  Inviting masters from
Tibet, India, Nepal, Europe, the US, and beyond
-  Gephel Ling’s
maintenance in improving the sustainability of the largest (area-wise) Buddhist
centre in EuropeWhile much work has already been
done to realise these goals, there remains a great deal of loving labour to do
before these things come to pass.  Please help us achieve the ultimate aim
of making this world a more peaceful and compassionate place.  Please
visit the Centro de Estudos Tibetanos website for more information about Gephel
Ling, our current and future projects, Buddhism, and CET itself. 
Thank you for your generosity!http://www.gephelling.org/
http://www.centroestudostibetanos.org/

story:
Expand our Study: Help us Tag more Broadwings!

The Broad-winged Hawk is a common raptor but its numbers are decline. In 2014, our team tagged four birds in Pennsylvania using satellite telemetry: three juveniles and one adult were tagged, including siblings from the same nest. Now, the birds are moving more than 4,000 miles from Pennsylvania to Central and South America. The tags allow us to track the birds for up to two years.

View the tracking maps now:  www.hawkmountain.org/birdtracker

NEW: We need to expand this research:
Supporters will help us to observe 8 new broadwing nests from different forest types, and to satellite-tag 10 new birds to expand the data set in 2015. Does food and behavior vary by habitat? Do birds from different areas have similar migration timings? Will the birds winter in the same region? Your support will help answer these questions and more. We also hope to compare adults to juveniles, and (new!) males to females. 

Challenges on Migration:
Large numbers of broadwings make them highly vulnerable on their migration journey. Many may not survive, and more than half of all juveniles will perish. The dangers they face include:

*Human persecution
*Industrial wind farms
*Pesticides and other environmental contaminants
*Lack of forest roosting habitat
*Hurricanes and other natural threats

Challenges in Pennsylvania and the Tropics:
Broadwings need large forests to nest and in Pennsylvania, the birds are leaving southern counties and other places as forests disappear. Little is known about habitat use during migration or wintering periods, but deforestation of Neotropics may also limit roost sites, providing yet another challenge to weary migrants.

Work to Date
In the 2014 pilot year, we collected detailed observations and video on four nests to identify prey and quantify parental care in Appalachian forest. We placed four satellite transmitters on three juveniles and one adult Broad-winged Hawk which are now being tracked at our website, see www.hawkmountain.org/birdtracker. 

Interesting Findings
In 2014, the adult female we tagged immediately departed after her young left the nest, leaving the male to bring food and protect the recently fledged young. Is her behavior typical of female birds or just an anomaly? We don't know  without tagging additional adults.  In 2014, two of the juveniles we tagged were from one nest, but the birds did not migrate together although they did move along parallel tracks.  We need to mark additional juveniles to see if nest mates will stay together after fledging and during migration.

Your support is vital to completing this exciting project successfully.  We  must match funds donated through the Pennsylvania Game Commission, dollar for dollar, with private donations or Hawk Mountain funds.  In 2015, we need to raise funding for two or more transmitters and for two additional field personnel to  locate and observe  nests,  We  also need funding to pay our graduate student and contract tree climbers as the nest trees are often quite high and the nest difficult to access. 


The Project Staff 

Hawk Mountain Sanctuary biologists and collaborators began working on this project in April 2014.  During the winter, we will be busy analyzing data and tracking the four tagged birds.  In April 2015, when  broadwings return from Central and South America, we will launch our field crews in two or three study sites depending on funding available.  They will work nonstop through July, collecting observations and helping to tag adult and juvenile birds.

 Introducing the Broad-winged Hawk Project crew:

 Rebecca McCabe, a Hawk Mountain Graduate Student, will conduct the bulk of field work and data analyses assisted by Keith and Laurie. She will oversee the field crew and volunteers  in nest searching and observations, and compile findings and weekly reports for donors and for use in her Master's thesis. Rebecca became 'hooked' on learning about broadwings while conducting nest observations at Hawk Mountain in 2013 for her undergraduate independent study.


Dr. Laurie J. Goodrich, Senior Monitoring Biologist at Hawk Mountain Sanctuary will co-direct and coordinate field work along with Rebecca. Laurie has observed migrating Broad-winged Hawks in Pennsylvania and Mexico for more than 25 years. Together with collaborators and donors, she looks forward to uncovering answers to the many mysteries of broadwing migration. She is particularly keen to learn where Pennsylvania broadwings spend their winters.
 

                       

Dr. Keith L. Bildstein, Sarkis Acopian Director of Conservation Science at Hawk Mountain, will co-direct project with Laurie. Keith is the author of Migrating Raptors of The World: Their Ecology and Conservation published by Cornell Press (2006) and a world-renown raptor biologist recognized by scientists for his leadership in raptor migration study. He directs long-term studies on migration ecology and conservation of vultures and caracaras around the world. He is seen above tagging one of his study birds, a Striated Caracara in Falkland Islands.


David Barber, Research Biologist and GIS Analyst at Hawk Mountain will place the telemetry units on birds, archive and manage the migration data, and work with others to produce maps of their migration journey. David once counted 7,000 Broadwings passing over Hawk Mountain and hopes to learn more about their migration pathways from this project. He has marked and studied migration in Turkey and Black Vultures throughout North America and assists with studies of Striated Caracaras in Falkland Islands.

    


Why Broad-winged Hawks?

The Broad-winged Hawk nests in large, unbroken forests of eastern and central North America. Each autumn they vacate North America and travel thousands of miles to winter in Central and South America. Although highly secretive and rarely seen during nesting, broadwings are conspicuous on migration, forming impressively large flocks, numbering thousands of birds. Nearly the entire world's population will pass through eastern Mexico and Central America on their way to southern wintering areas.

                 

Because of their amazing concentration, broadwings  face multiple threats during migration and on the wintering grounds, including shooting, deforestation, and contaminants. Moreover, despite the abundance of data on migration numbers recorded by hawkwatchers in North America, very little is known about their habitat use, migration, wintering and nesting behavior, and their conservation threats. Such data are critical to the long-term conservation of this iconic migrant and its migration spectacle.

The Broad-winged Hawk Project has three main goals:

  1. Identify Broad-winged Hawk migration routes and migration behavior in autumn and spring, identify the stop-over and over-wintering sites, overall range, and habitat used during migration and winter periods.
  2. Compare nesting behavior, migration patterns and timing of birds from within the same nest and from nests of the same region, including departure and arrival times, distance traveled daily, migration routes, and wintering region.
  3. With data gathered, publish and publicize results, work with government officials, local residents, and conservation organizations across the regions used by the birds to protect critical migration and wintering habitats. 

Hawk Mountain also intends to use the project as a tool to educate the public on the value and beauty of Broad-winged Hawks and other long-distance migrants. See www.hawkmountain.org/Broadwing Project.

   


Hawk Mountain follows the guiding principal of its founder Rosalie Edge, who stated: "The time to save a species is while it is still common." 

Guided by this philosophy, biologists can protect species *before* a severe population declines and to avert conservation emergencies--which ultimately become difficult and costly to remedy. 

The Broad-winged Hawk currently nests throughout northeast and north-central forests, but faces threats and challenges throughout its life cycle and may be in decline in some regions. By expanding our understanding of this amazing long-distance migrant, we can ensure it continues to fill the skies each autumn and spring.

Project Schedule and Plan:
April through June 2015: Locate eight nesting pairs of Broad-winged Hawks in two to three forest areas of Pennsylvania and conduct daily observations and videos using nest cameras.

July 2015: Trap the five adults and five juveniles and affix light-weight telemetry units on each bird to  track movements after they leave the nest. 

August through November 2015: Track ten  Broad-winged Hawks as they migrate south through North America, Mexico, Central America and possibly South America. Routes and locations will be mapped online and shared with schools, general public, and donors. 

Winter 2015-2016: The wintering range of each bird will be mapped, and in spring we will follow birds as they return north, assessing where they choose to spend their first winter and measuring how fast they migrate and other factors. Transmitters may last several years so data will be collected and analyzed as long as possible.


What We Need:

Funding for this project would support tagging two additional Broad-winged Hawks, the associated data download fees, and cost of field support and supplies. Eight additional Broad-winged Hawks will be tagged using funds from state grant and other Hawk Mountain donations. If additional funds are located we may tag as many as six juveniles and four adults allowing us to compare behavior among adults and juveniles and from different regions. 

Budget:  

GSM-GPS satellite tracking units.....................$4,000 each  x 2 = $8,000

Satellite tracking data downloads.....................$1,200 each  x 2 = $2,400

Graduate Student summer stipend................$1500/month  x 4 = $6,000

Two Field Assistants wages............................$1500/month x 4 = $12,000

Expert Tree Climbers for accessing nests.........................................$2,000

Total.................................................................................................= $30,400

Hawk Mountain Sanctuary is a non-profit 501 3c organization with a mission of conserving raptors worldwide. Every dollar donated to this project will directly support this exciting investigation. Hawk Mountain will support the project by providing housing, vehicle, office support, and covering project co-director's salaries.


Supporting a great cause is rewarding on its own, but who doesn't love supporting a cause that provides great perks?!? We have created several project sponsorship levels, all with donor benefits in thanks for their generous contribution. From visits to the world-famous Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, to naming a bird and following it through its life cycle, there are opportunities for everyone. Check out the "Select a perk" section on the right-hand side of the page for a full listing of donor levels and benefits.

If the project goal of $30,400 is not met, all funds will be applied to cover vital project costs, although less nests and birds may be followed.

The Impact

Although the Broad-winged Hawk can be observed by the thousands during their migration, little is known about their ecology and conservation needs.  As deforestation continues throughout its range and other potential threats heighten, it is important we understand more about its biology and ecology throughout its life cycle.

Hawk Mountain Sanctuary is well-suited to successfully implement this exciting project. We are a non-profit organization with a mission of conserving raptors worldwide and an 80-year history of successful wildlife conservation and outreach (see www.hawkmountain.org). We manage 2,500 acres of Appalachian forest and host education programs for 70,000 visitors annually. Our successful international conservation science trainee program boasts more than 300 graduates across the world, who in turn offer global collaboration for the outreach component of this project. We have former trainees in nearly every country traversed by broadwings. In the past decade, we have tracked Black and Turkey Vultures across similar landscapes and shared data through online and print publications.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us reach our goal by sharing this link with friends, family and fellow conservationists or bird lovers!  Please help us to spread the word.

story:
Have you ever heard someone talking about an "island of trash" in the ocean made up of plastic bottles, bags, and debris that spreads over an area the size of Texas?

Well, unfortunately they are correct!  There are 5 large ocean currents that have gathered a large portion of the estimated 7.5 million tons of plastic debris in our oceans, into highly concentrated gyres. 

This pollution directly kills hundred of thousands or even millions of aquatic animals each year.  It promotes harmful algae, invasive species, and serves as a way for pollutants (including PCB and DDT) to accumulate in the food chain.

What's the solution??  I believe a young man named Boyan Slat has come up with an amazing idea!!!  He is in the middle of a feasibility study on his project.  The study is due to be complete around the end of this year.  His TEDx Talk can be found at http://www.boyanslat.com/TEDx/ (and above at the video link). Please watch how he proposes we help the oceans clean themselves!

This campaign is to allow me join Boyan and his crew on an 8 day sailing expedition from Bermuda to St. Thomas this fall.  We will be towing a multi-level trawl that will allow us to measure plastic concentrations at eleven different depths at the same time.  We will be working day and night to gather new information to help complete his study and ultimately - if everything goes according to plan - lead to the largest ocean clean up project ever!  The funds raised here will pay for my time on the boat, airfare, and accommodations so I am able to directly help with this project.

I hope you will join me in supporting this cause, helping this voyage, and providing a solution to a major problem that our oceans are facing.  Thank you for reading this and becoming more aware!

(This campaign is independently organized by Dan Pinder)

story:
Hello all! My name is Lauren "Ren" Reilly and I am a senior at USF St. Petersburg. For the past 2 years I have been working at the USF College of Marine Science on the BP Deepwater Horizon (DWH) oil blowout.

This past summer, I was given my own research project to do - which is a BIG DEAL for an undergrad to conduct their own research and do a study that will hopefully become published.

I have been comparing the stable isotope ratios of Benthic Foraminifera calcium carbonate tests (shells from single-celled planktonic animals that live on the seafloor) and have found evidence that petroleum byproducts from the DWH event have been incorporated into the tests.

SO NOW I WANT TO SHARE MY RESEARCH WITH OTHER SCIENTISTS!

The best way to do this is to go to conferences and present my poster. Following are links to the 2 conferences that I want to attend next January and February:

http://gulfofmexicoconference.org/ (waiting to hear if my poster has been accepted)
http://www.sgmeet.com/osm2014/default.asp (poster has already been accepted)

I have requested funding from my university, but the contributions have been slim for the amount that I need. The College of Marine Science funding went out to post-docs and grad students. I will have having other fundraisers on my campus as well to help make ends meet. 

Please help by donating. Funds will go to travel, lodging, transportation, and food.

All people who donate will receive (via e-mail) a pdf of the poster that I am going to present. Also an experience journal of my trip so y'all can read about how presenting my posters goes and the life changing experiences I have from being able to attend these conferences.

Your contribution helps and will be appreciated more than words can say! Every amount adds up quickly so please help with what you can.

THANK YOU!
