The College of Marine Science funding went out to post-docs and grad students. I will have having other fundraisers on my campus as well to help make ends meet.  Please help by donating. Funds will go to travel, lodging, transportation, and food. All people who donate will receive (via e-mail) a pdf of the poster that I am going to present. Also an experience journal of my trip so y'all can read about how presenting my posters goes and the life changing experiences I have from being able to attend these conferences.Your contribution helps and will be appreciated more than words can say! Every amount adds up quickly so please help with what you can.THANK YOU!

story:
Introduction

Have you ever seen a film documenting the extreme beauty and diversity of our coral reef ecosystems and wondered what you could do to ensure that these places stay healthy for future generations? Then you’ve come to the right page. Have you ever read an article about the devastation of the world’s reefs due to anthropogenic causes and wished you could do something to protect and restore what’s still there? Then you’ve clicked on the right link. Have you ever thought about the huge disparity in income between our citizens and the coastal citizens of less developed nations and wanted to help? Then you’re still in the right place. SEASMART gives us a global solution to these issues through sustainable coastal development strategies that can be applied anywhere on the planet that there are both people and water. Please be involved in starting this “sea change” with us in a place that’s considered the center of marine biodiversity: the Coral Triangle.

UPDATES

New picture files were added 10/14 showing our successful efforts on the ground in Mati, Philippines. We have already made great progress with the IndieGoGo funds deposited directly into our PayPal account, so thank you all for making this happen! SEASMART represents a new and better way of life for many of these people, and they're excited to start training and collecting. Stay tuned for more exciting updates!

NEW VIDEO FROM MAGUM IS UP! 10/15

Goal

The immediate goal of SEASMART is to transform the marine aquarium trade, first in the Philippines and then on an international scale. This industry right now is predominately a high volume, low value, price driven industry with little regard for fishers or for the environment. SEASMART is capable of changing this.  It is our intention to help transform the marine aquarium trade into a force for the global conservation, restoration and sustainable use of the world’s precious coral reefs. SEASMART will help to lay the ecosystem, resource and community-based management foundations for the sustainable use of all fisheries within a management area further expanding SEASMART’s management and marketing benefits at little additional cost.

Without the adoption of sustainable management systems put in place through a transformative process, many reef spawning grounds will be harmed beyond repair, fishers and their coastal communities will decline further economically, and the purchasing public will have access to fewer, less affordable fish. Your funding support will permit EcoEZ SEASMART to take its Papua New Guinea pilot to the next level. With this proposed Stage 2 project, SEASMART will scale up its tested methodologies and evaluation systems as it seeks high rates of adoption by fishers. The initiative will provide guidance and affirmation that the SEASMART approach is replicable, is scalable, and can have global positive economic and environmental impacts.  SEASMART Marine Aquarium Life is Sustainable, Equitable, Profitable, and Affordable.

Our main project objectives are to: 

1) protect and sustainably manage reefs through a public-private sector approach to the marine aquarium trade;

2) enable historically marginalized fisher households to earn substantially higher incomes through first-time ownership and management of their marine aquarium trade;

3) improve awareness and demand for ecofriendly branded marine aquarium practices and products; and

4)  supply affordable, healthy marine aquarium fish and corals to consumers.

Some of our anticipated results  are:

1) widespread adoption of ecologically sustainable fish and coral harvesting best practices via coastal communities ownership;

2) sustainable SEASMART management systems are operational and succeeding;

3) increased number of hectares of marine habitat, number of species of marine life, and hectares of protected areas under management;  

4) marine aquarium buyers expand purchases of SEASMART-sourced marine aquarium life; and

5) substantially higher incomes among primary beneficiaries (fishers, coral farmers, and reef restorers) and secondary beneficiaries (packers, trainers, drivers)

Please join us on this adventure to one of the most beautiful and diverse places on earth in an effort to protect, conserve, and restore these irreplaceable coral reef habitats, usher in a new way of life for these coastal peoples along with a higher standard of living, and bring a much-needed paradigm shift to the concept of true sustainability. We look forward to bringing a sustainable, equitable, and profitable marine aquarium trade to the Philippines and hope that our collective goals develop into a successful partnership that we feel is waiting just beneath the waves.

Why are Coral Reefs so Important?

The Coral Triangle (CT) covers approximately 2.3 million square miles of ocean and encompasses six countries in the Indo-Pacific: Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, the Solomon Islands, and Timor-Leste. An unbelievable amount of biodiversity is condensed into less than 1% of the world's ocean surface area: The CT is home to one-third of the world’s coral reefs, 75% of known coral species (~600 species of corals), nearly 3,000 species of fish, half of the world’s seagrass and marine mollusk species, 75% of known mangrove species, six of the world’s seven species of marine turtles, and more than 22 species of marine mammals. We would like to focus our attention on the most northern point of this triangle, the Philippines, a place that, according to leading authorities in the taxonomy world, contains “the center of the center of marine biodiversity”.

Why did SEASMART choose the Philippines for Stage 2 Expansion?

The Philippines is comprised of 7, 107 islands and is a place of remarkable diversity and immeasurable importance that is considered top priority for conservation along with the Amazon, Arctic, Galapagos Islands and Madagascar. SEASMART proposes to help conserve this oasis of life by sustainably developing a trade that this place is uniquely equipped to support: the marine aquarium trade.  The SEASMART program will operate in the Philippines with the sole agenda of developing a sustainable, equitable, and profitable marine aquarium trade that would benefit all involved. SEASMART would give coastal inhabitants the opportunity to abandon destructive fishing practices such as fishing with dynamite and cyanide that yield immediate but detrimental results, for a livelihood that fosters sustainable development and proper management of an immeasurably important natural resource. 

Why is the Marine Aquarium Trade Important to the Future of the World’s Coral Reefs?

UNEP estimates that global trade in marine aquarium fish and coral is $200-330 million annually, mostly in sales to some 2 million marine aquarium owners primarily in the U.S. and Europe. The trade provides income for tens of thousands of local fishers and a substantial source of foreign exchange to poor countries, yet fishers are routinely exploited and their environments are often degraded beyond repair. Most marine aquarium organisms are not harvested sustainably or in ways that benefit local communities, fishers or buyers. 

What are the Problems that SEASMART Fixes?

In the Philippines and Indonesia, where 85% of the world's supply of live products are sourced, most exporters and wholesalers have little regard for coastal communities or interest in sound environmental stewardship. Local fishers are paid little and have virtually no ownership, control, or say in an industry that is characterized by a high loss rate from collection methods that employ cyanide and other chemicals to stun fish for capture. The U.S. and Europe may ban imports unless fish and coral are proven to be from sustainably managed sources. If bans are imposed, the result would be economic catastrophe for local fishers and their communities. The importing countries are concerned over the lack of science-based fishery area management plans, destructive fishing practices, and trade in endangered species.

Without sound reef management, the very resource needed to sustain the trade and produce fair prices and income for fishers, could be depleted permanently. SEASMART strives to ensure that this fate does not befall the world’s coral reefs. The marine aquarium trade can be managed in economically sustainable and environmentally sound ways as a supplier of healthy fish and coral to consumers. UNEP claims that the marine aquarium trade has the highest potential to provide sustainable resource management and economic prosperity to coastal communities.

When ecosystems are protected and managed properly, the marine life proliferates and monetary value is added to an area, making it even more desirable to conserve. Investing in SEASMART offers a unique opportunity to drive global change starting with the marine aquarium trade. This trade faces growing threats to its future, and the SEASMART program is truly a force for the global conservation, protection, and sustainable use of the world’s coral reefs and associated ecosystems.

EcoEZ's SEASMART approach overcomes destructive imbalances in the trade's value chain through branded, innovative, practical solutions. Its Papua New Guinea SEASMART pilot improved protection of reefs through a profit-driven approach: incomes rose among first-time ownership by historically marginalized households and demand for ecofriendly marine practices and products also grew. Further testing can show widespread impact, scalability and replicability. SEASMART fish are healthy and sustainably caught with no chemicals using only hand nets, providing customers confidence that their fish are collected, handled and shipped in accordance with best practices through the efforts of fisher-owners and dedicated exporters such as our partner company, SeaStrong.

How Will We Accomplish these Goals?

SEASMART’s mission is to establish a marine aquarium fishery in the Philippines that is sustainable, equitable, and profitable and we can do this with the implementation of five key program components: Resource Assessment & Management (RAM), Management Area Planning (MAP), Fisher and Fishery Development (FFD), Mariculture, Aquaculture & Restoration (MAR), and SeaStrong (Export and Branding). Each one of these components is integral to the development of Fishery Management Areas (FMAs), geographically defined and resource mapped coastal marine areas whose boundaries are determined by traditional local community resource ownership or local government boundaries. 

Sustainability is an absolute necessity for the success of a marine aquarium trade in the Philippines and all five of these components can make it a reality. SEASMART’s RAM programing has the ability to provide vital information on the abundance of a FMA’s marine aquarium resources, as well as data on food fish species, and the health of each FMA’s marine ecosystems. Our MAP development process results in a plan capable of growth and change depending on the current needs of an area, and is an essential step towards ensuring the sustainable management of fish stocks and reef health.  SEASMART’s FFD programming provides fishers and fisher communities training in correct fishing, holding, handling, and husbandry techniques and management. Our MAR programming is primarily an activity run by women that provides coral farmer training in coral cultivation methods and reef restoration, and is worth half of the trade’s potential value. SeaStrong programming provides the necessary organism traceability, husbandry, shipping, and marketing needed to maintain the SEASMART goal of a less than 1% organism mortality rate, an extremely low number considering the industry average is between 15-35%. All these components will ensure that the Philippines’ priceless natural resources are protected, conserved, and restored where necessary.

We are dividing our funding efforts into two phases in order to better manage the immediate v. future needs of the SEASMART project by ensuring that each need is met in the necessary order.

Phase One:  Site Preparation - $75,000

  • Resource Assessment & Management (RAM)

The RAM component conducts the resource assessment of applicant FMA communities; coordinates and trains fishers and locals on resource management; produces Total Allowable Catch (TAC) values for every marine aquarium species surveyed; coordinates with Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (BFAR) GIS personnel on FMA mapping; evaluates potential sites; provides data to TRADE Management database; identifies suggested no-take areas; and develops FMA site-specific “non suitable species” or “no-take” lists for endangered, rare, dangerous, or inappropriate species. Inappropriate species are those that don’t do well in captivity or shipping, eat corals, or have living requirements that make them unsuitable for aquarium living.

  • Management Area Planning (MAP)

The MAP component leads the development of an FMA community’s Management Area Plan; coordinates with all SEASMART Divisions to ensure implementation of site assessment recommendations; coordinates and trains local FMA MAP Committees; assists in MAP certification process; coordinates implementation of certification corrective action plans with regards to MAP development; and monitors and evaluates potential sites for future selection.

  • Fisher & Fishery Development (FFD)

The FFD component provides fisher skills training and extension in marine aquarium organism identification, habitat, lifecycle, capture, handling, holding, husbandry and transport; ecosystem conservation and harvest area rotation; fisheries management planning and implementation; Fisher Training and Extension Manual development and adaption; fisher association development and management; and fisher preparation for Marine Aquarium Council (MAC) or equivalent certification.

  • Mariculture, Aquaculture and Restoration (MAR)

The MAR component provides fisher skills training and extension on in situ cultivation of coral species primarily to women that allows them to have a major role in generating income for their families. Different methodologies of coral cultivation are trialed including methods that also act as vehicles for reef restoration such as the use of low cost, community produced Coral & Fish Aggregation Devices (CFADs). The focus will be on producing market quality corals with fairly easy reach of the coral-farming managers (primarily community women).

 

Phase Two: SeaStrong - $75,000

  • Export Facility Development (EFD)

The EFD component supports the development of export facilities including screening, transport, holding, handling, husbandry, packing, and shipping as well as promotion and marketing assistance for the export of product.

  • Smart Business Development (SBD)

The SBD component provides fisher skills training and extension in small business development; personal financial management training; fisher banking and bank account set-up (paperless and cashless payment system); and support for application to lending institutions and Government managed development funds in support of their marine aquarium fishing activities.

  • TRADE Management Database-Traceability Systems

The TMD component supports the development and implementation of TRADE Management Software ensuring all product traceability mechanisms are functional and robust.

 

And a few notes on donation:

We have a lot of great perks that you can buy, but there is of course always the option of buying the perk just for the sake of donating to our cause. If you don’t feel like you want/need any of the items you bought, we certainly won’t be offended. Donating just because you truly believe in something is probably the greatest reward of all. We also don’t expect everyone to be able to donate, but if you think you know someone who would be interested in our campaign, please tell them about us!

If you decide to contribute and you do it via PayPal, you will see that you'll be transferred to the site of a sister organization, Panda Mountain (they love corals too!). Rest assured that your funds will be going to us at SEASMART; we are currently sharing a PayPal page with them becasue it's easier for both of us. Also, if you use PayPal instead of a credit card, the funds are availbale to us quickly. The Team wants to start work right away, and you make this possible by paying through PayPal.

If you happen to be a marine aquarium hobbyist or industry contributor, we are offering the option of converting your real dollars and perks into “fish dollars”. 25% of the money you donate over $50 could be “redeemed” and essentially converted into fish purchases as animals become available over the next year.

story:
Save the Vrain Regional Park Effort

  • Save The Vrain is a Colorado non-profit corporation whose sole purpose is to create a regional park and preserve 817 acres of beautiful ranchland with a unique ecosystem. This proposed regional park already has a rail trail waiting to be constructed which will connect the town of Firestone to Milliken, Platteville, and beyond. The ranch is home to nesting bald eagles, a heron rookery, many birds and wild animals; and the St. Vrain River which meanders within it's boundaries. 

  • Our goal is to make this regional park into a world-class park with walking, bicycle and equestrian trails, as well as canoe trips up and down the river. What better way than to have the partnership of The Greenway Foundation to assist us in finding the right people, and organizations for donations and/or grants that will help us in this endeavor. 
  • We are a group of citizens that consist of 150 neighbors of the ranch and beyond.  Some of us are 3rd, 4th, and even 5th generation ranchers. We have naturalists, bird enthusiasts, businessmen and women, oil and gas professionals, cattlemen, farmers, environmentalists, and more.  What makes our group unique is the breadth of background we bring! 
  • We have already led a successful effort to protect the property from being turned into a gun range!  It was slated to be built 900 feet from the Kurtz Ranch bald eagle's nest, which is illegal. But, this is not enough.  The property is still for sale and could be developed into any number of uses.  We believe that the neighboring towns would greatly benefit from a regional park! The towns of Mead, Platteville, and Milliken already have given their support to this effort.

  • The ranch is 4 miles from Mead and Platteville, 5 miles from Firestone, 7 miles from Johnstown, and 9 miles from Milliken. It is easily accessible as it is east of I-25 at Exit 243; approximately 4-miles due east at the intersection of County Road 17 and Colorado State Highway 66, in Weld County, Colorado. The proposed regional park would be on the Northeast corner of CR 17.

  • We are partnering with The Greenway Foundation; the firm that reclaimed, restored and revitalized over ten miles of the South Platte River, a portion of which is now known as Confluence Park in Denver, Colorado. The Greenway Foundation has a world-wide reputation and has led efforts with over 20+ parks and natural areas and has constructed more than 100 miles of hiking and biking trails. 

  • You can help too! You may give online which is fast, easy and secure. Gifts in any amount(s) may be made and an e-mail confirmation will be provided. We are sponsored by the Greenway Foundation who is a 501(c)3, so any donations are fully tax deductible.

  • If you want to volunteer, please ask! Our membership is currently 250 strong and growing.

  • Spread the word! Please share our fundraising effort with your friends, family, colleagues, and anyone else who might want to contribute to this fantastic effort! 

  • If you have questions, you may contact us and someone will respond within 24-hours.

  • Save The Vrain!!! 

 

Eagle landing! photo by Larry Kniskern

What We Need and What You Get:

Thus far, we have been funded by private donors.  We have raised over $100,000, but the time has come to expand our net.

We are in the process of getting the property under contract, with earnest money promising the seriousness of our efforts to raise the funds to purchase the park. We are hoping to offer significant tax benefits as well as a significant amount of cash.

We hired The Greenway Foundation in order to use their expertise to help us identify specific grants and guide our fundraising efforts. However, there are many smaller fees that we will need much sooner than we'll need the entire purchase price raised. We estimate that we will need a minimum of $60,000 to fulfill these preliminary expenses.


 

By contributing to this campaign, you will be able to get some very exciting gifts (listed to the right), and you'll be supporting an incredible grassroots effort to create a regional park! 

St. Vrain River winter panorama - Photo by Larry Kniskern.

The Impact

The area surrounding the proposed park includes the fastest growing communities in Colorado, with five small towns surrounding the ranch.  This rapid urbanization has not included an opportunity to recreate and enjoy all that a large park has to offer.  The trail on an abandoned rail bed will connect the communities.  The park is approximately two miles long and a mile wide. The St. Vrain River winds through it, providing a variety of recreational activity, while also providing habitat for a wide range of birds and animals.

The Platte River Greenway is generally recognized as one of the premier trail systems in the country.  The principals of that effort are heading the efforts to secure the funds to purchase this almost pristine Ranch and develop it to its highest and best use: a regional park.

 

Mama snapper

Heron rookery - photo by Larry Kniskern

Swallows - photo by Larry Kniskern

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean that you can’t help!

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Tell your friends! And, remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Location of Proposed Regional park

Aerial photograph of the proposed 817 acre regional park

The proposed park in reference to surrounding towns and roads
This is where the proposed park is in relation to the
Front Range towns within an hour of the property

Thanks so much!  We hope you can come visit our regional park sometime!
story_txt:
Save the Vrain Regional Park Effort


Save The Vrain is a Colorado non-profit corporation whose sole purpose is to create a regional park and preserve 817 acres of beautiful ranchland with a unique ecosystem. This proposed regional park already has a rail trail waiting to be constructed which will connect the town of Firestone to Milliken, Platteville, and beyond. The ranch is home to nesting bald eagles, a heron rookery, many birds and wild animals; and the St. Vrain River which meanders within it's boundaries. 


Our goal is to make this regional park into a world-class park with walking, bicycle and equestrian trails, as well as canoe trips up and down the river. What better way than to have the partnership of The Greenway Foundation to assist us in finding the right people, and organizations for donations and/or grants that will help us in this endeavor. 

We are a group of citizens that consist of 150 neighbors of the ranch and beyond.  Some of us are 3rd, 4th, and even 5th generation ranchers. We have naturalists, bird enthusiasts, businessmen and women, oil and gas professionals, cattlemen, farmers, environmentalists, and more.  What makes our group unique is the breadth of background we bring! 

We have already led a successful effort to protect the property from being turned into a gun range!  It was slated to be built 900 feet from the Kurtz Ranch bald eagle's nest, which is illegal. But, this is not enough.  The property is still for sale and could be developed into any number of uses.  We believe that the neighboring towns would greatly benefit from a regional park! The towns of Mead, Platteville, and Milliken already have given their support to this effort.


The ranch is 4 miles from Mead and Platteville, 5 miles from Firestone, 7 miles from Johnstown, and 9 miles from Milliken. It is easily accessible as it is east of I-25 at Exit 243; approximately 4-miles due east at the intersection of County Road 17 and Colorado State Highway 66, in Weld County, Colorado. The proposed regional park would be on the Northeast corner of CR 17.



We are partnering with The Greenway Foundation; the firm that reclaimed, restored and revitalized over ten miles of the South Platte River, a portion of which is now known as Confluence Park in Denver, Colorado. The Greenway Foundation has a world-wide reputation and has led efforts with over 20+ parks and natural areas and has constructed more than 100 miles of hiking and biking trails. 



You can help too! You may give online which is fast, easy and secure. Gifts in any amount(s) may be made and an e-mail confirmation will be provided. We are sponsored by the Greenway Foundation who is a 501(c)3, so any donations are fully tax deductible.



If you want to volunteer, please ask! Our membership is currently 250 strong and growing.

Spread the word! Please share our fundraising effort with your friends, family, colleagues, and anyone else who might want to contribute to this fantastic effort! 


If you have questions, you may contact us and someone will respond within 24-hours.



Save The Vrain!!!

We are in the process of getting the property under contract, with earnest money promising the seriousness of our efforts to raise the funds to purchase the park. We are hoping to offer significant tax benefits as well as a significant amount of cash.
We hired The Greenway Foundation in order to use their expertise to help us identify specific grants and guide our fundraising efforts. However, there are many smaller fees that we will need much sooner than we'll need the entire purchase price raised. We estimate that we will need a minimum of $60,000 to fulfill these preliminary expenses.

 
By contributing to this campaign, you will be able to get some very exciting gifts (listed to the right), and you'll be supporting an incredible grassroots effort to create a regional park! 

St. Vrain River winter panorama - Photo by Larry Kniskern.

The Impact
The area surrounding the proposed park includes the fastest growing communities in Colorado, with five small towns surrounding the ranch.  This rapid urbanization has not included an opportunity to recreate and enjoy all that a large park has to offer.  The trail on an abandoned rail bed will connect the communities.  The park is approximately two miles long and a mile wide. The St. Vrain River winds through it, providing a variety of recreational activity, while also providing habitat for a wide range of birds and animals.
The Platte River Greenway is generally recognized as one of the premier trail systems in the country.  The principals of that effort are heading the efforts to secure the funds to purchase this almost pristine Ranch and develop it to its highest and best use: a regional park.

story:
@bruce.c.melton

 

An Art Film on Climate Change
Because  Traditional Documentaries on Climate Change
Have Not Made A Big Difference
Coming in 2020

 

The Climate Change Now Initiative (nonprofit 501c3) is the oldest independent climate science education organization in the world (EIN 90-1006128.) Founded in 2005, we do things a little differently. And now, four years in the making, we've upped the ante on this film.

We've put together a team. We have a new Executive Producer with a substantial philanthropic donation. We have a new film production, post production, and creative professional to guide, implement and polish. We now have academic, political and cultural resources. This is big. It has to be. There is no planet B.

It's obvious. Past climate science education strategies have not worked out so well. The new science of global warming psychology says we have to create learning through pathways that are different from our old left brain strategies because, the old pathways have been corrupted by money, propaganda, fear, and good sounding ideas that are just not good sound ideas.

This idea of right brain learning is not new. Mr. Rodgers was doing it 55 years ago. Right brain learning uses more of the brain to create deeper thought --emotional thought-- that is more meaningful, more powerful. 

Even better, we can hear the message through the lyrics in music. Think about the blues. The blues are all bad, but we enjoy the blues as music. Blues are catchy, melodic, and rhythmic. It plays on our inner psychology. We can relate. The blues are perfect for climate change.

This film will not just be another climate documentary. It's an art film -- with the capacity to make a much bigger difference than those traditional left brain strategies that just haven't worked out so well.

So here we are with our cameras and music, with 27,700 miles in the can and 15,000 coming up, and a big new motivated team.  We are ready to usher in a new era of climate change outreach, and we need your help.

Climate Change Across America

 ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ 

Your small contributions can make a big difference,
because this film will be unique.

Help us make this effort a success,
for all mankind. 


The Story

It takes place across the spine of North America from Mexico to the Canadian Rockies; from Padre Island to the Outer Banks via Key West; From the California disasters to the Arctic Ocean and Greenland. Global warming psychology says right brain learning comes from stories. This story is about some of the most beautiful and breathtaking landscapes in the world. It's an uncomplicated film, fresh and natural, designed not to frighten but to please. 

It's a story of normal environmental changes that happen every time our climate changes abruptly. It's as beautiful as only the natural world can be, and it's fascinating because nobody has ever seen abrupt changes taking place.

The most exciting part of the story is music. The lyrics carry more water than the narrative. And the narrative: who knew that high altitude forests across North America are now emitting more greenhouse gases than they absorb because of 96 million acres of forest mortality caused by native beetles?  Or that Alaska, because of permafrost melt, is now a net emitter of greenhouse gases? Or that sea level rise is now eroding into the dunes on wild barrier island beaches across America up to 20 times per year during normal twice-yearly maximum high tides?

The best "who knew" however, is that we can remove the already emitted carbon dioxide from our sky using treatment techniques first used to keep our sailors safe from carbon dioxide poisoning in submarines during WW II. These normal pollution treatment strategies are very similar in technology and cost to those used to ensuring safe drinking water across the planet every year. 

This new healthy climate film is different. It's not frightening. It's not about giving things up. It's about our energy infrastructure already being on the best-case scenario pathway of emissions reductions because of ultra-cheap wind, solar and batteries. It's about the solutions that create a better world, a world where we can actually reduce warming AND create a fossil carbon free energy infrastructure.

Check Out Our Flagship
ClimateDiscovery.org – Our Knowledge Base

Over 500 Articles on the Latest Climate Science
Deeply Referenced
Direct from the Academic Literature

 

Executive Producer

Dr. Craig Nazor has joined the team as not only our music consultant, but as an Executive Producer with a substantial philanthropic donation. His vision as a musician and artist matches ours. His lifelong experience as an environmental advocate allows him to understand why right brain science learning is needed. Welcome Dr. Nazor.

 

Post Production

The financial contribution of Dr. Nazor will allow us to retain a film produciton professional to help with production, post production, creative conceptualization and polishing. This is a really big move. Welcome to Ebrahim Ghaeini and Blooming Studios.

 

What Your Donations Will Pay For

This is our fourth year of filming for this project. We netted about $4,000 from our Indiegogo last year, (Yay!) But it wasn't enough and we had to put last year's West Coast trip on hold. But it's a new filming season and along with last year's donations—California to the Arctic Ocean filming begins June 25.

It's not cheap, even for a low budget production that camps the whole way. Our director pays for almost everything out of his own pocket and this year the Ice Melter (see below) has 198,000 miles on it. The repair list is long, but it beats buying a new one and modding it for 4x4 work with high altitude and desert trails, and grueling beach work. Our director has spent $15,500 on maintenance beginning about 2015. Hopefully these expenditures will last a few seasons. 


The "Ice Melter" is a good mini-RV and can go where no RV or town car ever dreamed, usually. At 14 MPG, gas for California to the Arctic Ocean will run about $3200.

Cams: Cameras don't last forever and this year we have replaced about half our fleet. The total bill for cams: north of $5k. The same goes for our HD film work station. Our 2011 "historic" model is showing major signs of degradation; $1500 in repairs in 2017 and 2018, and a new one will be needed in the fall.  

The Band's mixer will also get replaced this fall to begin work on rerecording many of our old tunes. And Yay! The band will be carrying the bulk of the mixer burden. These are just the big things. Camping fees for example, at 7 weeks and $20 a day, is another $1,000. It all adds up. 

 

The Schedule:

It's not likely we will get to post production until next year (post production is the computer studio part of making a film). We still have to do the East Coast wild beach erosion tour, plus a new trip to Greenland. We were last in Greenland in 2007 and are really looking forward to repeat photography there with melt that has only accelerated.  This winter we'll do a couple of new videos (see our latest videos below.)

There's still a chance we can get to post production this year if we can get enough folks to share this Indiegogo! We return from the Arctic Ocean early/mid-August and Greenland's peak filming season is late August. Then we can finish with the coastal work in October/November during the King Tide. Post production this year will mean film festival applications in early 2019. Otherwise, it's the 2020 film festival season.

 

The Interim Products – Music Videos With More Than Just Music

Below are a  couple of new videos:

 

Where We Have Been So Far

Year   Destination                                                      Miles
2014  Padre, North                                                   750
2015  Big Bend, March                                            1500
2015  Padre North and South, April                    1000
2015  Rockies, Texas to Idaho                              7500
2015  Padre North, October                                  750
2016  Big Bend, March                                            1500
2016  Rockies Texas to Wyoming and Utah     7500
2017  Padre North and South, November        1000
2017  Padre, South                                                   750       
2017  Padre, South                                                   750
2017  Hill Country (5 trips)                                    1200
2018  Big Bend, March                                            1500
2018  Big Bend, April                                               1250
2018  Padre South, May                                         750
Total                                                                              27,700

Tell Your Friends, Share, Like and Talk!

Talk about climate change,
we'll get this film done one way or another.
But to return to a healthy climate,
to avoid the frightening things,
we need to talk to one another,
a lot!

 

Team Climate Change Across America

Bruce Melton: Producer, Director, Videographer

Bruce Melton is the brain donor behind this project. He is the director of the Climate Change Now Initiative, author, photographer, videographer, webmaster, etc. His primary research was in stormwater pollution treatment technologies. He is a registered professional engineer, president of Melton Engineering Services Austin, a very small firm  whose revenues support the Initiative. They focus on critical environmental issues, flooding and land development. As a volunteer, he was on the board of the Austin Sierra Club 2010 to 2017,  the State "Lone Star" Chapter of Sierra Club board 2013 to present, and serves as vice chair of the Austin Conservation Committee and cochair of the Lone Star Climate Change Committee. He writes most of the songs for the band Climate Change, sings lead, plays rhythm guitar, and blows a mean harp. When he's not filming, engineering, or volunteering, he tends his native plant and organic vegetable gardens.

Alan Watts: Video Consultant

Alan has an extensive and diverse background in video editing, computer animation, and software development which has garnered multiple awards and recognitions.  He is currently the Technical Director for an online cultural heritage website and creates retro-inspired interactive installations.  In the summer, he can usually be found backpacking in the mountains of New Mexico and beyond to escape the Texas heat. The good-looking one's name is Mesa.

Dr. Carol Cespedes: Owner and President, Halintours, Inc.
Specialist in Environmental and Community-based tourism

Carol has both an M.A.and Ph.D. in Asian Studies with an interdisciplinary focus on development and social change in South and Southeast Asia. Her professional background includes college teaching and administration of nonprofits. She has lived and taught or conducted research in five countries in addition to participating in seven international Global Village projects of the Habitat for Humanity.  In 1986 she moved to Costa Rica and founded one of the first ecotourism companies, offering environmentally responsible travel throughout Latin America.  Making her home today in Austin, Texas, she continues arranging responsible and innovative travel programs  while also active in community and environmental causes with a primary emphasis on climate change.

Dr. Craig Nazor: Executive Producer and Music Consultant

Dr. Craig Nazor has been involved with the arts and environmental activism for his entire life.  After obtaining a BA in Music (Piano Performance) from a joint program between Case Western Reserve University and the Cleveland Institute of Music, Craig moved to NYC where he spent 7 years accompanying and composing for many major dance companies. On the way, he took up modern dance and choreography, and ended up touring with the Erick Hawkins Dance Company. After leaving NYC, he earned a MM from Northwestern State University in Natchitoches, Louisiana, and taught music and dance on the faculty there for 3 years. While in Louisiana, Craig composed two commissioned works for the Shreveport Symphony orchestra. He also found time to help form the Natchitoches Chapter of the Audubon Society, and was the Director of Education for Friends of the Alexandria Zoo. With the Audubon Society, Craig spearheaded a campaign to stop the Red River Waterway Project, an expensive 1980s environmental boondoggle whose intent was to make Tulsa, Oklahoma a deepwater port (you can’t make this stuff up!). Craig moved to Austin, Texas in 1987, where he earned his Doctor of Musical Arts in Theory/Composition and has been teaching Music at Austin Community College ever since. He has performed in numerous bands and other ensembles in the Austin area. He is a member of the Conservation Committee of the Sierra Club, Austin Regional Group, is Vice Chair of the Conservation Committee of the Lone Star Chapter of the Sierra Club, In his spare time he is a member of the Austin Animal Advisory Commission, president of the Cycad Society (a national plant society), consultant for the Hartman Prehistoric Garden at Zilker Botanical Gardens,  and a member of the Austin Cactus and Succulent Society.

John Hrncir: Legislative Liaison

Photo

XXXXXX

Ebrahim Ghaeini: Consultant for Production, Post Production and Creative Design

Ebrahim is an independent filmmaker & editor living in Salt Lake City, Utah. After graduating from the University of Utah with a BA in Film Studies, he founded Blooming Studios LLC, a production company, with two other founders. Ever since he has worked across the nation doing freelance work  with names such as Bonnie Story (High School Musical - Choreographer) & Brian Sullivan (Wind River, Bicentennial Man - Camera Operator). His directorial short film, Moments of Clarity, went to win awards at film festivals in Utah as well as Italy & Ireland.  In his free time he loves to travel, hike, backpack, and explore the globe. He also participates in photography, acrylic painting, sculpting, guitar, piano, and poetry. Above all he strives to become a better story-teller.

 

The Band Climate Change

The band got started in 2001 as just another non-gigging Austin therapy group (these groups are pretty thick in Austin). By 2007, Melton was writing climate songs (an engineer singer song writer...) and had taken over the lead singer position. They have self published three albums. The band has a studio concert just about every Friday and plays a few special gigs a year. Drop by any time. Use the band entrance around back. If the house is a rockin, don't bother knockin, come on in ~ ~ ~ Left to right above: George Hadash - lead guitar, Philip Fulton - bass, Bruce Melton - rhythm guitar, harmonica, Ken Atwater - drums, Tom Williams - keys, everybody sings.

The Band Climate Change

 

The Rewards

T-shirts!

Get one of our unique and thought-provoking t-shirts for a donation of $35.00 or more. If you don't want one, click the red "Back It" button top right. The shirts are standard, high quality screen print, 100% cotton, printed by Surfwater Promotions, Myrtle Beach South Carolina. The shirts themselves are Comfort Colors' 1717 prewashed, prefaded, garment dyed, top of the line. Click here to see a larger image.

Screen Saver

Everyone gets a screen saver. It's a folder of photos from Climate Change Across America that you configure for Window's or Mac's on board screen savers. Nothing to buy, simple instructions provided.  See a pdf proof sheet here with 229 photos from just some of our previous 27,000 miles with more to come. 

ClimateChangeTshirts.org

Want more T-shirts? Climate Change t-shirts was founded by the Initiative to help fund operations. There are about 120 different designs over a dozen different types of apparel. These designs are digitally printed by Scalable Press and very durable (tested by Melton, an inveterate t-shirt wearer.) They are actually the most durable digital prints he has ever encounter. Costs are very affordable for name brand apparel ranging from $16 to $19.

Get More T-shirts!

Lots of Art!
(Click Image for high resolution)

 

Please Share on Social Media
Let's Go Viral
We Can Do Something About The Weather!

Team Climate Change Across America
Bruce Melton: Producer, Director, Videographer

Bruce Melton is the brain donor behind this project. He is the director of the Climate Change Now Initiative, author, photographer, videographer, webmaster, etc. His primary research was in stormwater pollution treatment technologies. He is a registered professional engineer, president of Melton Engineering Services Austin, a very small firm  whose revenues support the Initiative. They focus on critical environmental issues, flooding and land development. As a volunteer, he was on the board of the Austin Sierra Club 2010 to 2017,  the State "Lone Star" Chapter of Sierra Club board 2013 to present, and serves as vice chair of the Austin Conservation Committee and cochair of the Lone Star Climate Change Committee. He writes most of the songs for the band Climate Change, sings lead, plays rhythm guitar, and blows a mean harp. When he's not filming, engineering, or volunteering, he tends his native plant and organic vegetable gardens.
Alan Watts: Video Consultant

Alan has an extensive and diverse background in video editing, computer animation, and software development which has garnered multiple awards and recognitions.  He is currently the Technical Director for an online cultural heritage website and creates retro-inspired interactive installations.  In the summer, he can usually be found backpacking in the mountains of New Mexico and beyond to escape the Texas heat. The good-looking one's name is Mesa.
Dr. Carol Cespedes: Owner and President, Halintours, Inc.Specialist in Environmental and Community-based tourism

Carol has both an M.A.and Ph.D. in Asian Studies with an interdisciplinary focus on development and social change in South and Southeast Asia. Her professional background includes college teaching and administration of nonprofits. She has lived and taught or conducted research in five countries in addition to participating in seven international Global Village projects of the Habitat for Humanity.  In 1986 she moved to Costa Rica and founded one of the first ecotourism companies, offering environmentally responsible travel throughout Latin America.  Making her home today in Austin, Texas, she continues arranging responsible and innovative travel programs  while also active in community and environmental causes with a primary emphasis on climate change.
Dr. Craig Nazor: Executive Producer and Music Consultant
Dr. Craig Nazor has been involved with the arts and environmental activism for his entire life.  After obtaining a BA in Music (Piano Performance) from a joint program between Case Western Reserve University and the Cleveland Institute of Music, Craig moved to NYC where he spent 7 years accompanying and composing for many major dance companies. On the way, he took up modern dance and choreography, and ended up touring with the Erick Hawkins Dance Company. After leaving NYC, he earned a MM from Northwestern State University in Natchitoches, Louisiana, and taught music and dance on the faculty there for 3 years. While in Louisiana, Craig composed two commissioned works for the Shreveport Symphony orchestra. He also found time to help form the Natchitoches Chapter of the Audubon Society, and was the Director of Education for Friends of the Alexandria Zoo. With the Audubon Society, Craig spearheaded a campaign to stop the Red River Waterway Project, an expensive 1980s environmental boondoggle whose intent was to make Tulsa, Oklahoma a deepwater port (you can’t make this stuff up!). Craig moved to Austin, Texas in 1987, where he earned his Doctor of Musical Arts in Theory/Composition and has been teaching Music at Austin Community College ever since. He has performed in numerous bands and other ensembles in the Austin area. He is a member of the Conservation Committee of the Sierra Club, Austin Regional Group, is Vice Chair of the Conservation Committee of the Lone Star Chapter of the Sierra Club, In his spare time he is a member of the Austin Animal Advisory Commission, president of the Cycad Society (a national plant society), consultant for the Hartman Prehistoric Garden at Zilker Botanical Gardens,  and a member of the Austin Cactus and Succulent Society.
John Hrncir: Legislative Liaison
Photo
XXXXXX
Ebrahim Ghaeini: Consultant for Production, Post Production and Creative Design
Ebrahim is an independent filmmaker & editor living in Salt Lake City, Utah. After graduating from the University of Utah with a BA in Film Studies, he founded Blooming Studios LLC, a production company, with two other founders. Ever since he has worked across the nation doing freelance work  with names such as Bonnie Story (High School Musical - Choreographer) & Brian Sullivan (Wind River, Bicentennial Man - Camera Operator). His directorial short film, Moments of Clarity, went to win awards at film festivals in Utah as well as Italy & Ireland.  In his free time he loves to travel, hike, backpack, and explore the globe. He also participates in photography, acrylic painting, sculpting, guitar, piano, and poetry. Above all he strives to become a better story-teller.
 
The Band Climate Change

The band got started in 2001 as just another non-gigging Austin therapy group (these groups are pretty thick in Austin). By 2007, Melton was writing climate songs (an engineer singer song writer...) and had taken over the lead singer position. They have self published three albums. The band has a studio concert just about every Friday and plays a few special gigs a year. Drop by any time. Use the band entrance around back. If the house is a rockin, don't bother knockin, come on in ~ ~ ~ Left to right above: George Hadash - lead guitar, Philip Fulton - bass, Bruce Melton - rhythm guitar, harmonica, Ken Atwater - drums, Tom Williams - keys, everybody sings.
The Band Climate Change
 
The Rewards
T-shirts!
Get one of our unique and thought-provoking t-shirts for a donation of $35.00 or more. If you don't want one, click the red "Back It" button top right. The shirts are standard, high quality screen print, 100% cotton, printed by Surfwater Promotions, Myrtle Beach South Carolina. The shirts themselves are Comfort Colors' 1717 prewashed, prefaded, garment dyed, top of the line. Click here to see a larger image.

Screen Saver
Everyone gets a screen saver. It's a folder of photos from Climate Change Across America that you configure for Window's or Mac's on board screen savers. Nothing to buy, simple instructions provided.  See a pdf proof sheet here with 229 photos from just some of our previous 27,000 miles with more to come. 

ClimateChangeTshirts.org
Want more T-shirts? Climate Change t-shirts was founded by the Initiative to help fund operations. There are about 120 different designs over a dozen different types of apparel. These designs are digitally printed by Scalable Press and very durable (tested by Melton, an inveterate t-shirt wearer.) They are actually the most durable digital prints he has ever encounter. Costs are very affordable for name brand apparel ranging from $16 to $19.
Get More T-shirts!

Lots of Art!(Click Image for high resolution)

 
Please Share on Social MediaLet's Go ViralWe Can Do Something About The Weather!

story:
Who Are We

Hi, We are Mark and Tom, a father son team in the Detroit area. In 2010 when we started doing volunteer work picking up trash in Detroit parks.  This year we started picking up trash on the water.  We treat this volunteer work like a sport, in fact we think we may have invented a new sport.  We call this sport " Trash Fishing". 

What Is Trash Fishing?

Trash Fishing is competitive environmental cleanup.  It is like regular fishing, but instead of fishing for fish, we fish for trash.  The competitions are modeled after competitive fishing contests.  Contestants go for largest, most, and weirdest trash.  There is even a World Champion!   Our contests encourage other people to come out and fish for trash.  The result is a fun time and a big, combined environmental cleanup.  

Are You Like Environmental Huckleberry Finns?  

Sorta. People have accused us of tricking people into doing work. The difference is that Trash Fishing is actually a lot of fun.  Of course it does do great things for the health of our waterways.

Support The 2019 Trash Fishing Season

For 2019 we are committed to pulling more unwanted trash out of the water by increasing the amount of people who come out and fish for trash.  We think it is entirely possible for us to remove over 2,000 pounds of trash from the Detroit River in 2019.  We'd like your help making this possible.  

Encourage People To Have Fun Collecting Trash

Your pledge will go to hosting the 2019 Trash Fishing World Championships where people will clean up our environment.  We expect to have somewhere between 5 and 8 Trash Fishing events in 2019.

3 Reasons Trash Fishing Is More Fun Than Fish Fishing 

  1. You stay busier when trash fishing.  It isn't unusual to pull 100 pieces of trash into the boat in a couple of hours.  Any fisherman would be jealous of how much we catch.
  2. The variety of trash is incredible.  We've pulled in a water ski, a garden hose cart, pool noodles, a construction barrel, trash can, more than one car tire, and even a buoy that the US Coast Guard used to track dead bodies.  It's like a treasure hunt out there!
  3. The result is better.  After a day of Trash Fishing you can really feel great about what you've done.  

Mark and I Are Contributing Too

Personally, we are so enamored with Trash Fishing that we've spent $5,000 on it this year.  We financed the 2018 season ourselves and we just spent a bunch more to buy a better trash fishing boat.  Our prior 9 foot dinghy couldn't fit an afternoon's worth of trash, so we bought a used 15 foot Boston Whaler off of Craigslist.  We are poised to lead the charge in 2019 and carry hundreds of pounds of trash.  We apologize for asking for contributions, and would like you to know that we have skin in this game too.

What Will Your Pledge Be Used For?  

It will be used to host between 5 and 8 Trash Fishing events in 2019.  We want to encourage others to give Trash Fishing a try. Your pledge will make it easy and rewarding for people to come out and clean up the environment.   Here is where the budget will go:

1.  Hosting 5-8 events we call "The 2019 Trash Fishing World Championships".  The World Championships will be open to the public, free to enter, and will be announced and supported on the Trash Fishing Facebook Page:  http://www.Facebook.com/TrashFishing  

2.  We will provide free "Gripper Grabbers." A good grabber is the only tool you need to acquire in order to try Trash Fishing.  Free Grabbers means that anyone with a boat, canoe, or kayak can instantly become a Trash Fisherman and start cleaning the environment.  Our favorite grabber, the "Nifty Nabber" is $17.99 at Home Depot.  We expect to spend about $550 on them for the event.  

3.  Free Donuts.  As the planning organization, we think it is our duty to supply the donuts.  We know a good place.  They are $11.40 a dozen and they taste like heaven.  We expect to spend about $150 on donuts.  

4.  Trash Fishing T-Shirts.  Do you know what separates a real trash fisherman from an amateur?  The T-Shirt.  You won't be able to buy a Trash Fishing t-shirt though, you can only earn them by collecting trash.  We will give away a shirt to people who show up to two Trash Fishing events.  It'll be an exclusive bunch, but not everyone cleans up trash for fun.  We expect to spend $300 on T-Shirts.

5. Sunblock, water, rubber gloves, gasoline and contractor trash bags are all things we use.  We expect to spend another $500 on these expenses. 

Stretch Goal $1,800: If we raise $1,800 we will throw an end of the year banquet where we will pay for the burgers and beers.  

Stretch Goal $2,500:  Instead of wasting time and gas trailering our boat to the water every time, we will rent a slip at a budget marina so our trash fishing boat is always ready to go.  Less time loading up the trailer will mean more time removing trash from our waterways. 

Ultra Stretch Goal every $2,000 beyond $2,500:  We will bring Trash Fishing to another US City.  Mark and I will tow our little boat to or rent a boat in another US city and host an additional trash fishing event there.  Cleveland? Chicago? Baltimore? Boston? New York City?  Who knows where we will make friends next?

story:
“I remember when I, along with the other kids, would play in the stream that formed in the village every monsoon season. Now the kids in the village don’t play in the stream because there is no stream anymore, there is no monsoon.”

The Background

Thousands of smallholder farmers in India - caught in debt because of unsustainable agricultural practices and climate change-related problems - committed suicide during the last ten years. Farmers in the project area report prolonged drought as the monsoon rains often fail to appear. The frequency and intensity of rainfalls are changing as well and farmers can no longer rely on consistent precipitation events for farming. As a result of climate change and the extensive use of chemicals, soil erosion and degradation have significantly increased. This has caused yields to further decline, and the vulnerability of crops to pests and diseases to increase.

Who we are

Toranam is a project founded and run by a team of graduates from India and around the globe in cooperation with the NGO Movement for Rural Emancipation (MORE). The cooperation began in December 2015 and emanated from the joint visit of project members to a conference. That meeting included a discussion about the possibilities for organic agroforestry as a means to combat the negative effects of climate change and ways to achieve socio-economic welfare. This has led to the start of the implementation of the Toranam project in October 2017 with an aim to increase the food and nutritional security and sustainable income generation for famers in the Madanapalle, Andhra Pradesh region (Southern India) through agroforestry.

The problem

The agricultural sector makes a large percentage of India’s Gross National Product (GNP) and sustains the livelihood of nearly 70% of the population. The so-called Green Revolution, that saw most of Indian agriculture undergo radical changes in the seventies and eighties of the last century, has had a severe impact on the environment and the socio-economic and cultural situation of people, especially in rural areas. Madanapalle, the project region, is an important center for agricultural products and famous for producing tomatoes, mangos, groundnuts and silk. In Andhra Pradesh, like in other Indian states, facing the hopeless reality of debt, scarce workforce and highly fluctuating market prices, many small-scale farmers choose suicide as the last way out. Climate change has a negative impact on this semi-arid area with increasingly absent rainfalls. Extreme heat, dry soil and water shortage reduce crop productivity and demand more resources. The groundwater level has gone down dramatically in recent years. At this moment, more than 60% of the borewells have dried up and most villages are without secure water supply.

Another core issue is the dependence on hybrid seeds and chemicals. Big agrochemical companies push famers into a vicious circle of debt by making them dependent on hybrid seeds and expensive pesticides.

The third issue is  unstable markets. The market situation in Madanapalle region is characterized by heavy fluctuations in prices related to peaks of harvest, weather conditions and labor shortage. Most farmers grow crops in monoculture and are thus very vulnerable to low prices and crop loss.

The solution

Toranam is an agroforestry and climate change adaptation project promoting sustainable development practices and environmental education in Southern India. The focus is on smallholder farmers, whose livelihoods are affected by climatic and socio-economic changes. The primary aim is the establishment of an economic and educational center with a demonstration farm which will show smallholder farmers how organic agroforestry can achieve good yields despite drought, how value can be added to farm produce through further processing, and how smart marketing approaches benefit farmer cooperatives. In addition to ecological agroforestry, Toranam plans to pioneer an e-learning approach to agricultural and environmental education, which is new in the region, to engage with young people with an affinity to technology.

The demonstration farm is already being set up as well as the e-learning center. The next step is now to set up processing facilities and actively involve farmers.

Agroforestry and processing

Agroforestry is a technique where trees are integrated on farmlands in a systematic manner. The trees provide shade, nutrition, biomass and several other benefits to the crops as well as produce that can be converted to value added products. To demonstrate the model for sustainable development, pilot plots with organic agroforestry are established on various farmlands. The pilot plots are designed to be well-adapted to local socio-ecological conditions and climatic mutability. From these locations, a farmer’s cooperative is set to be established with purchase guarantees from Toranam for all produce they harvest with the newly established organic agroforestry.

Value addition will be achieved through processing of those crops. It will create a system with increased shelf life and participating farmers will be able to sell their produce for a fixed and fair price independently from the market. The center will also offer eco tourism facilities for additional income generation.

This holistic approach will not only benefit the farmers directly, but also tackle the issue of climate change and water scarcity. Through the plantation of trees and better water management on farmlands, effects of climate change will be mitigated, and climate resilient systems can be developed.

The Impact and our goals

The main groups profiting from Toranam are small farmers, students and consumers longing for healthy produce from regional and traceable cultivation. Smallholder farmers can achieve better, diversified yields and hence a more stable income and can emancipate themselves from the chokehold of large agrochemical companies as well as loan sharks. Schools and students also benefit from the Environmental Education Center where soft skills and green business ideas can be developed.

The success of this project means that the people can earn decent livelihoods instead of having to migrate to cities in search of petty jobs and live in subhuman conditions. It means that your contribution has aided in helping a village transition to a sustainable and climate resilient type of farming, which is the need of the hour. The effects of climate change are being felt everywhere now and it is the poor and the downtrodden that is the most vulnerable to these changes. As privileged human beings, it becomes our moral imperative to make an effort towards helping those in need.

Risks & Challenges

The primary hurdle that we currently face and will face in the future is the lack of rainfall in this region.

The project team here at Toranam comprises of young local and international graduates who have pursued their studies in the field of sustainability, environmental planning, resource management. MORE is a local NGO with more than 30 years of experience in rural development.  We also have a volunteering structure where we accept students to do internships or write their research papers in context to the project we’re working on. This allows us to document the information well and offers new insights to any problem through detailed field research work.

To minimize the risks associated with water shortage, we have successfully installed rainwater harvesting systems on every roof on the project site and are storing the rain water for the dry season. We are also applying traditional water catchment systems by using the slope of the lands and building trenches. We hold workshops with farmers where we display these systems to them and help them in implementing the same in their own lands.

How your contribution will help

With your help we will be able to set up processing units and facilities for eco-tourism to make the project economically independent. By processing locally, we will be adding much more value to the harvest compared to solely selling the harvest directly to the middlemen. Since our project is a social venture, we have decided to procure and use the processing machine within the farmer’s co-operative instead of owning it privately. This means that the processing units would be a common resource for the farmers who will work with us and cultivate organically. The profits made will cover the fixed costs such as salaries of local employees and exceeding profits will go back into the project with an aim of supporting more farmers.

With your help and blessings, we can make this happen!

story:
Dear Visitor,

 

Please help the revolutionary inventor of this machine to continue his work and save our planet from the most dangerous plastic contaminants.

He is an expert scientist who has been developing this technology for 10 years and he has 30 years of experience in the plastic industry.

 

Your contribution shall facilitate the practical implementation of this prototype seen in the movie, which is able to convert otherwise useless dirty plastic garbage (disposed in landfills) into an extremely durable building material.

With this revolutionary recycling technology a special material can be produced, which has several beneficiary applications, such as providing shelter for the homeless or saving people from floods.

But fields of applications are almost unlimited.

 

With your money we wish to build a second-generation mobile machine, suitable for serial production, including the acquisition of all necessary certificates and documentations.

This new machine will be able to move to the location of plastic waste (instead of transporting the waste to the machine). The robust high-performance machine will be built into a mobile container and will produce 2,5 tons of new material per day.

 

We wish to thank you for your contribution.

 

For more information: http://www.plasticwasterecycle.com/
story_txt:
Dear Visitor,
 
Please help the revolutionary inventor of this machine to continue his work and save our planet from the most dangerous plastic contaminants.
He is an expert scientist who has been developing this technology for 10 years and he has 30 years of experience in the plastic industry.
 
Your contribution shall facilitate the practical implementation of this prototype seen in the movie, which is able to convert otherwise useless dirty plastic garbage (disposed in landfills) into an extremely durable building material.
With this revolutionary recycling technology a special material can be produced, which has several beneficiary applications, such as providing shelter for the homeless or saving people from floods.
But fields of applications are almost unlimited.
 
With your money we wish to build a second-generation mobile machine, suitable for serial production, including the acquisition of all necessary certificates and documentations.
This new machine will be able to move to the location of plastic waste (instead of transporting the waste to the machine). The robust high-performance machine will be built into a mobile container and will produce 2,5 tons of new material per day.
 
We wish to thank you for your contribution.
 
For more information: http://www.plasticwasterecycle.com/

story:
Due to rising global warming, Kivalina, Alaska is quite possibly going to become “the first U.S. casualty of global warming”.  This small Native Inupiat community just north of the Arctic Circle first sought legal assistance from the Center on Race, Poverty and the Environment in2001 for help with water pollution from the world’s largest zinc mine, Red Dog Mine. . 

Luke Cole, a Harvard Law School graduate and CRPE’s founder, rejected high salaries in favor of helping disproportionately burdened communities like Kivalina. He regularly took 3 planes to visit his Inupiat clients only to sleep in the sole hotel in Kivalina - the floor of the school. CRPE fought and won a settlement against Red Dog Mine, which was polluting Kivalina’s drinking water and also represented the community along with The Native American Rights Fund and other top trial lawyers by taking on the top 24 U.S. greenhouse gas emitters, claiming that their greenhouse gas emissions directly contributed to the loss of sea ice and erosion of the small island on which Kivalina is located.

http://www.crpe-ej.org/crpe/index.php/campaigns/climate-justice/kivalina-ak

Luke was killed in a head-on collision in Uganda in 2009.  But CRPE lawyer Brent Newell carries on Luke’s work and continues to visit Kivalina (and sleep on the school floor) to help them in their struggle for clean water and climate justice. No one knows how the people of Kivalina will fund their relocation as it will cost up to 400 million dollars.  Right now, Kivalina does not even have a means of evacuation in the event of a major storm.

Brent travels to Kivalina once a year and he is leaving very soon.  I want to join him to photograph and document CRPE's presence and commitment to this community on the brink.  Some photos and media will be given to CRPE for their use and other photos and the story will be pitched to media outlets for a potential story.  (Some people know about Kivalina, but they don't know about CRPE's crucial role).  Eventually, photos will be archived and filed with Corbis so others can witness the lives of the people who lived there and what it looked like after it is gone.

I was formerly on staff with The Chicago Sun Times Company and have also been published in The Chicago Tribune, Hemisphere’s Magazine, The Post Tribune, and UPI.  I am also a contract photographer with Corbis. 

Funding from this campaign will be used to cover travel expenses only.

story:
Creating a Conservation Legacy for the 21st Century

For two decades, The Watershed Center has been working to preserve one of the last best places in Addison County, a rare landscape of geological wonders, wild ponds, fertile bogs, stunning vistas, towering forests, and Native American archeological sites. The result has been a string of successes from the purchase of the original Waterworks woodlands to conservation of nearby Lost Pond Forest. Only one piece of this puzzle remains: a privately-owned 194-acre parcel that would link these two separate expanses and connect their trail systems to create a single education and conservation legacy nearly 1,000 acres strong. Now this parcel is for sale. But the clock is ticking. 

A Once-In-A-Lifetime Opportunity

Recently the price for this land was cut to just $175 per acre, a remarkable bargain for such a beautiful and ecologically valuable place. This once-in-a-lifetime opportunity has just one hitch: We have only a few months to seal the deal. This land will be sold. But what happens then?


Forever Wild or Forever Lost?

In addition to linking the two separate woodlands of the Watershed Center, the “Middle Forest” hosts rare and endangered species like the eastern rat snake and the Indiana bat, uncommon vernal pools, hidden groves of legacy trees, and some of the region’s most scenic overlooks. New owners could log this forest’s old-growth trees, plow its meadow habitat, permit ATVs and other intrusive and destructive motorized uses, and manage it for consumption not conservation and education. 

Together we can create something better: a permanent public preserve that sets aside almost 1,000 pristine acres—over 7% of all the forest land in the Little Otter Creek Watershed—for teaching experiences, student exploration, community programs, hiking, and hunting. This is the Wildlands Project, and its fate is in our hands.

Adopt an Acre. Be a Forestkeeper.

For just $175, you can become a Forestkeeper and place an acre of the Middle Forest under the Watershed Center’s permanent stewardship. Or collect $17.50 from 10 friends and adopt an acre as a group. All Forestkeepers and groups will be honored on a commemorative plaque to be placed at the trailhead to the forest we’ll share. 

Big or small, every tax-deductible donation matters. Please give whatever you can to safeguard this priceless natural resource for future generations of explorers young and old. Every dollar counts! Every acre waits!


Photo Prints taken by Jonathan Blake at the "Middle Forest"

Newt

Owl

Acorn

Flower

Tree

story:
Short Summary

A family forest and farm that has been owned by the same family since the  1940's is being threatened with development. After the conclusion of WWII, a former Navy veteran and his family purchased about 1000 acres of woodlands and hayfields. Through the years the operation of the farm was primarily for the benefit of the family (subsistence farming). They milked a few dairy cows and raised a few beef cows. They raised chickens for eggs and meat, planted a garden for fresh vegetables and canning for the winter months. Firewood was cut for heating the house and the firing up the cookstove. When cash was needed for taxes or other things, they would cut a few pine trees to sell to the mill. It was a sustainable farm. Over the last few years or so it seems that prices have risen so dramatically. Add to that fact the government seems to want more and more. Rising prices and higher taxes are not insurmountable problems. 

What We Need & What You Get

What is needed is a different approach to utilizing this wonderful gift. Instead of utilizing the land as a subsistence type of operation, what is necessary is to look for other operations that can allow the farm to continue intact. We have had a professional Forester develop a Forest Management Plan. We have received approval for a high tunnel by the USDA (greenhouse). This will allow us to extend the growing season by getting crops in the ground sooner as well as extending the harvest. The Forester has developed a plan to sustainably manage the forest to provide a better stream of income while managing the reforestation of the land. He has identified a stand of Sugar Maples from which we can begin to produce Maple Syrup for sale. We are working with the Upper Valley Land Trust to identify the opportunities for enacting any type(s) of conservation easment(s) that might be available to help conserve the land. We are working with Natural Resource Conservation Service (NRCS) to explore the possibilities of the Wetlands Reserve Program (there are over 70 acres of wetlands that provide habitat for many types of birds, animals and amphibians) the land is home to many species of animals. There are deer, bear and moose, beaver, hawks and even Bald Eagles utilizing this habitat. We are continuing to explore the possibilities afforded by programs of the USDA. The goal of this campaign is to help us learn to become good stewards of the land. After all, we can't take it with us! The funds raised by this campaign will purchase farm and logging equipment, renovate or build barns and outbuildings. We will need to purchase equipment to tap the Maple trees and to begin to make maple syrup. Please help us to forge a plan to keep this land intact and make it truly sustainable.

The Impact

The major impact of this campaign will be that we will be able to pass to the next generation a wonderful piece of land that should remain together and not be developed into a subdivision or other wise broken up. The immediate impact is that we will be able to reduce our carbon footprint by transitioning away from our commute to work of over 300 miles per week each (600 miles total for Husband and Wife based on separate commutes).

Other Ways You Can Help

Please contribute what you are able and please pass the word to those among your circle. Remember, the more that become aware and are able to contribute can lessen the required amount needed from each person.

story:
Short Summary


The cottage was an eco restoration which was being sold as the previus owner ran out of funds.

I was looking to move back to North Longford as its where the family are from, and while this is the wrong side of Cairn Hill (these things do matter you know, otherwise your not local!!!) the purchase was of the heart as much as the head.

It featured a rainwater tank which filled from the roof, batteries for power, and all was landed, solar panels, cabling, etc., to put everything together before the fire struck.

Everything was destroyed.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to get the roof on pronto:

  • The walls need to be repaired where cracked.
  • Wallplates need to be built on them.
  • Roof to be raised to give attic access.
  • Seebeck generators to be installed
  • New solar panels (PV and for hot water) for roof
  • Well to be drilled
  • Incinerator toilet to be purchased

The Impact

Everything helps, as we get the project together, we will run further campaigns to get the individual items:

  • The incinerator toilet (from www.ToiletRevolution.ie ) will eliminate the need for septic tank reducing pollution. Its cutting edge in sanitation and eco freindly, runs on LPG..
  • The solar panels will be grid tied, and will also have a windmill, with the seebeck generators linked up. Excess power exported to grid..
  • PLG fridge will use less power and more eco friendly.

Risks & Challenges

This is part one, to get the building itself roofed and the walls strengthened... the seebecks, the incinerating toilet and the LPG fridge are all future projects.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share the campaigns details.
  • If you are round the area and have skills, call by and give us a hand!

More updates to follow!
